HEADLINE: Personal Business; 
Little Ba nks Learn to Compete With Merger Mania

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER BAYOT

 BODY:
THREE years ago, BankAtlantic, a community bank based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., declared its own war of sorts against the big-bank competitors that were swallowing up neighborhood banks throughout its home state.
 To help keep its customers -- and more important, to lure new ones -- it began extending the operations at its 73 branches to seven days a week from six, and it started a grass-roots advertising campaign to let everyone know. 
 There's the walking No.7 mascot that appears regularly at community events and in bank buildings, and the small fleet of cherry red Volkswagen Beetles, called 7-Day Bugs, that outstanding employees are permitted to borrow for a month.
 Whenever BankAtlantic signs up a new customer, its tellers shred unused checks from the customer's former bank and sound a large brass bell to celebrate. In each branch, a poster displays a running number of new customers from various competitors. 
 "Many of these customers feel abandoned by their banks and disillusioned that they have lost personal contact," said Alan Levan, the chairman of BankAtlantic, which has $5.8 billion in assets. "So the banking market was wide open for an aggressive, customer-oriented bank to fill the void that was left." 
 BankAtlantic's efforts seem to be paying off, to some degree. According to Mr. Levan, former customers of acquired banks -- particularly banks bought by Wachovia or Bank of America in the last few years -- account for more than three-quarters of the 144,000 customers his company has gained over the last two years, as well as the 145,000 estimated for this year.
 Of course, a few thousand customers are a drop in the bucket when compared with the millions of customers, and thousands of branches, that banks have gained in the recent spate of acquisitions.
 Bank of America's planned $48 billion acquisition of FleetBoston and its 12 million customers, announced last week, would create what the companies say is the first truly national bank, with 5,700 branches across 29 states, plus 16,500 automated teller machines. 
 BankAtlantic and other community banks do not appear terribly concerned about that prospect. In most industries, the arrival of a large, well-known competitor makes smaller businesses squirm, but not in banking. Smaller banks seem to have discovered over the years that a merger of competitors often signals an opportunity to grow -- and that usually benefits the consumer as well. Quite simply, said Diane Casey-Landry, president and chief executive of America's Community Bankers, a trade association, "what community banks see is an opportunity to go after disaffected customers."
 For some small banks, that means offering better rates on loans, savings accounts and other products. Most focus on improving or personalizing services.
 In Mercer County, N.J., Fleet bought Summit Bank's branches in 2000, while First Union acquired Wachovia in 2001 and applied the Wachovia name to its branches. In response, Yardville National Bank, which is based in Yardville, N.J., and has 20 branches in central New Jersey, sent mailings promising a 3 percent annual yield on its checking accounts for the first six months, plus unlimited check writing. (Fleet offers a rate of 0.10 percent on checking at its branches in central New Jersey.)
 Calling itself "Your Neighborhood Bank," Yardville National also offered to pay people $10 for bringing in the leftover checks from their accounts with other banks. And to show that it could compete in the big leagues, it advertised in national publications, like Time, Newsweek and Sports Illustrated, that allow advertisements within specific regions. 
 When Fleet bought Bank Boston in 1999, Eastern Bank, a community bank also based in Boston, offered free checking. That caught the attention of J. Dayne Lamb, and her husband, Gardner Stratton, both financial planners in Boston and Bank Boston customers. Concerned that service would suffer after the merger, they switched their personal accounts to Eastern, and they have reported no regrets.
 "They offer a truly no-fee checking account," Ms. Lamb said. "The tellers are just fabulous. They have a popcorn machine there, and they always have something like CNBC on TV. I deeply hope that small institutions stay around, because they feel just entirely different." 
 In the two years after Fleet's acquisition of Bank Boston, Eastern won 41,500 new checking accounts -- an increase of 110 percent, it said.
 Fleet's acquisitions inspired smaller banks to band together. Working with the Massachusetts Bankers Association, they formed a fee-free A.T.M. network to compete with Fleet's large network of A.T.M.'s.
 The big banking companies say that the smaller banks do provide valuable services to their communities, but they add that there is room for both types of institutions.
 "We are a global bank, but we compete on a local level," said Eloise Hale, a spokeswoman for Bank of America. "Because of the resources that we have, we have a breadth of products that community banks just can't support -- we have a wealth of lending opportunities." 
 James Schepker, a spokesman for FleetBoston, said that certain customers are entitled to discounts on home equity loans and bonus rates on C.D.'s.
 The entrance of large companies can also spur local branches of smaller banks to broaden offerings. West Bank, which is based in Des Moines and has 10 branches in the area, recently acquired a local asset manager, began offering additional types of home equity loans and raised introductory rates on certificates of deposit. 
 After all, said Thomas Stanberry, the bank's president and chief executive, it is now competing with Wells Fargo, U.S. Bancorp and Bank of America.
 Over all, community banks, which generally include banks with fewer than 100 branches, had a 7 percent increase in deposits during the five years ended in June 2002, according to the First Manhattan Consulting Group in New York. 
 By contrast, the 30 banks with the country's largest consumer divisions gained only 1 percent in deposits after subtracting customers added through acquisitions. James McCormick, First Manhattan's president, attributed the gains largely to a higher level of customer service among the smaller banks. 
 But not all big banks ignore those basics, he added. Bank of America, for instance, has been improving its share of consumer deposits, "largely due to taking a page out of the small-bank book," he said. 
 The company said that it plans to build 550 branches by 2006 and has charged 153 employees nationwide with fostering community ties through such acts as attending service club meetings. 
 Among larger banks, Mr. McCormick said, Commerce Bancorp of Cherry Hill, N.J., has done the best job of winning new customers on its own, as opposed to buying other banks.
 Vernon Hill II, the president of Commerce, said: "Our growth has come from the big players in the market, and it's because the customers are tired of being abused. And every major merger in the Northeast has caused major disruptions in service."
 So look for small-bank promotions when the potential for inconvenience is at its greatest -- as merged banks struggle to blend their operations.
 That happened last year when the BB&T Corporation, based in Winston-Salem, N.C., with assets of $90 billion, acquired the Bank of Louisville and the Area Bank of Owensboro, Ky. The branches of both acquired banks had to close for almost three days and reconfigure their A.T.M.'s as they merged operations. 
 The Republic Bank & Trust Company of Louisville, a competing community bank with 30 locations, ran newspaper advertisements announcing that it was extending its hours for two of those three days and that it would cash any payroll checks. It also offered $50 bonuses to anyone who opened an account that weekend.
 Last winter, as U.S. Bancorp was taking over Bay View bank branches in California, Borel Private Bank and Trust of San Mateo, Calif., sent Valentine's Day cards to people asking, "Looking for a new relationship?"
 The valentines were reminiscent of the newspaper advertisements Borel ran when Wells Fargo acquired First Interstate in 1996. One longtime Wells Fargo customer, Tom Chakos of Hillsborough, Calif., said he thought that the bank was spreading itself too thin through its acquisitions. So after 25 years with the bank, Mr. Chakos eventually took his accounts to Borel, -- as well as those of his three small businesses.-- 
 AFTER BB&T acquired several bank branches in Georgia, West Georgia National Bank, which has seven branches, wanted to help customers switch. So it trained its employees to transfer all of the automatic transfers linked to people's checking accounts, including direct deposits and automatic drafts. It also offered to go to people's workplaces to get signatures for any account or loan openings. 
 "It was an opportunity for us to go out and bring business from the other bank," said Rocky Lipham, an executive vice president of West Georgia National.
 Before the BB&T acquisitions, West Georgia National's slogan was, "We want to be your only bank." After, it changed it to, "Taking your banking personally since 1946."
 Many small banks seem to be adopting similar slogans as they emphasize personalized services, something at which they say they excel. 
 In Connecticut, after Fleet acquired Shawmut National, People's Bank of Bridgeport ran print ads warning, "There's a stranger in town who just got a hold of your bank account."

HEADLINE: Is the Party Ending For Home Builders? 

BYLINE:  By J. ALEX TARQUINIO

 BODY:
BUOYED by low mortgage rates, the housing market has boomed over the last three years and shares of home-building companies have soared.
 This year alone, the Standard & Poor's Supercomposite Homebuilding index, which includes companies like Centex, Lennar and the Ryland Group, is up 87 percent. Because of recent upward moves in mortgage rates, however, investors are divided over whether the sector's good times can continue much longer. 
 Barbara Allen, a senior analyst at Natexis Bleichroeder, a New York investment research firm, warned that the home builders were cyclical companies and that their shares were likely to decline as mortgage rates rose. 
"Investors should be aware that they are essentially betting on the direction of interest rates," Ms. Allen said.
 But several portfolio managers said they remained bullish on the sector. Ken Heebner, manager of the CGM Realty fund, for example, said the stocks of home builders were still a good buy. He said that demand for housing would remain strong even if 30-year mortgage rates, now averaging about 6 percent, rise to 7 percent in the next year or two. And the larger home builders, he said, could keep growing by acquiring smaller companies.
 "If I can buy companies growing at 20 to 25 percent or more, at seven to eight times my estimate of next year's earnings, that's a great bargain," Mr. Heebner said. 
 Sam Lieber, who manages the Alpine real estate funds, said that improved management at the big home builders should let them continue to increase earnings, even in the face of rising mortgage rates. Compared with their situation a decade ago, he said, the companies are "much more streamlined, with something approaching just-in-time manufacturing." 
 Some analysts said that the industry was less tethered to interest rates than it was just a few years ago. "Demographics are on their side," said James F. Wilson, a research analyst at Jolson Merchant Partners in San Francisco. He said that immigration trends should keep the population growing in many regions and that the proportion of home owners should rise as the population ages.
 ANOTHER factor, he said, is a scarcity of land in important markets, partly because of tighter regulations.
 "Go back 10 or 15 years, and it was really only difficult to get land developed in California and New Jersey," he said. But within the last five or six years, some kind of development restrictions have been enacted in 38 states, either statewide or locally, he said. "That gives home builders pricing power," he added.
 Looser lending standards, as reflected in the rise of zero-down-payment mortgages, are also driving demand, said Ivy Zelman, a research analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston. She said she thought this trend would mitigate the negative impact of rising rates.
 Shares of the big home builders tend to move in a pack, but Mr. Lieber particularly likes Ryland because it has expanded by buying land rather than by acquiring smaller construction companies, as many of its competitors have done. This strategy gives Ryland one of the cleanest balance sheets in the business, he said, with a debt level of 33 percent, compared with 40 to 50 percent for many other builders. 
 Ryland intends to stick with this strategy, said R. Chad Dreier, the company's chief executive, who added it could grow significantly without acquisitions. 
 "Organic growth takes a little longer, but I think it's easier to achieve," Mr. Dreier said.
 Despite their high cash flow in recent years, most home builders have kept dividends low; Ryland's yield is only .09 percent. Mr. Dreier said big investors had told him that they preferred share buybacks to dividends; the company is purchasing two million sharesin 2003, he said.
 Lennar, another large builder, broke ranks with the group in September by raising the company's annual dividend to $1 a share from 5 cents, for a current yield of 1.09 percent.
 "We have confidence in our ability to generate significant cash flow, so we felt this was a prudent time to increase the dividend," said Bruce Gross, the chief financial officer.
 But Ms. Allen said the sector was very vulnerable because low interest rates and zero-down-payment mortgages had inflated the housing market.
 "We don't know how much of that stimulated demand that should have happened over the next three years," after first-time buyers saved up for down payments, she said.
 Single-family home construction rose 6.7 percent in 2002, a rate Ms. Allen said was unsustainable. 
 She expects the pace of earnings growth to slow, she said, because the widespread inflation of home prices will ease. In many markets, she said, homes have sold for more than builders expected when construction began. Those quick increases have helped earnings and margin growth. "That's pure gravy, because the cost of building remains the same," she said. 
 But she predicted that prices would level off -- even if mortgage rates did not rise very much -- because homes would become unaffordable for buyers whose incomes were not rising at the same breakneck pace.

HEADLINE: ON THE CONTRARY; 
Why Do Employers Pay for Health Insurance, Anyway?

BYLINE:  By DANIEL AKST; Daniel Akst's column tilts at conventional business wisdom and appears the first Sunday of each month. E-mail: culmoney@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
NOBODY expects employers to provide groceries, housing or clothing, but for odd historical reasons American employers have evolved into providers of health insurance. Nearly two-thirds of Americans under 65 rely on health coverage from an employer. 
 Some of America's largest companies, maybe eager to level the playing field, favor requiring employers to provide insurance. But they have it backward. They should be advocating an end to employer-financed health coverage altogether. 
 Why should we hate the employer-financed system? Let us count the ways:
 It makes it difficult or sometimes even impossible for people to change jobs, not only damping economic efficiency but reducing the competition for labor and, therefore, reducing wages. Without alternative health coverage, there is "strong evidence for job lock," wrote two economists, Jonathan Gruber and Brigitte C. Madrian, in a National Bureau of Economic Research study released this year.
 It suppresses the creation of new businesses because, for many potential entrepreneurs, quitting a job means forgoing health insurance, a risk too big to take.
 It handicaps traditional industries like autos and steel, whose medical burden for retirees is staggering. The estimated lifetime expense for today's steel retirees alone is $14 billion. In the auto industry, General Motors alone provides coverage to nearly one-half of 1 percent of the American people; One analyst, Gary Lapidus of Goldman Sachs, calls Detroit's Big Three "H.M.O.'s with wheels."
 It unfairly excludes the unemployed, the self-employed and low-skilled workers. And it can shortchange single people, whose employers effectively pay higher wages to workers with families when providing dependent coverage.
 On top of everything else, our employer-based system seriously obscures who is paying what, making cost controls difficult. Workers may think they are getting something for nothing, but employer-paid insurance premiums usually are provided in lieu of higher wages. And while companies dislike soaring premiums, at least they can deduct their cost from their income taxes, thus transferring a big hunk of the cost to the federal government. 
 Employers and employees alike, meanwhile, may be unaware that they pay some costs for the uninsured. Hospitals recover the unpaid costs of treating uninsured patients by charging insurance companies more, and insurers then build these costs into employer premiums. 
 There is no good reason for any of this, aside from historical accident. During World War II, federal wage controls prevented employers from wooing workers with higher pay, so companies started offering health insurance as a way around the law. Of course, this form of nonmonetary compensation is still pay. When the war ended, the practice stuck.
 WITH a presidential election campaign under way, it is time for employers to put the issue of national health coverage back on the agenda. Either party might find it appealing: a recent ABC News-Washington Post poll found that, by a margin of almost 2 to 1, Americans would prefer a government system covering everyone instead of the employer-based system. (Support drops sharply if the government plan would limit choice of doctors or mean longer waits for nonemergency treatment.)
 The status quo is untenable. Survey results released in September by the Kaiser Family Foundation found that health insurance premiums rose nearly 14 percent this year, on top of many double-digit increases in previous years, so that the annual cost of a typical family plan -- regardless of who's paying -- now exceeds $9,000. More than one-seventh of all Americans have no health insurance at all. 
 We can expect the numbers of uninsured to rise. The Employee Benefit Research Institute recently asked people what they would do if their medical premiums rose. Two of three respondents said they would drop coverage if premiums rose $200 a month; a quarter said they would cancel coverage if premiums rose $100 a month.
 Ending employer-sponsored coverage, of course, would not stop the cost surge. But a properly designed universal system could help. Plenty of competition would need to be built into it, along with significant individual co-payments. The best path may be to give everyone a voucher good for basic coverage; people could buy more elaborate coverage if they chose.
Such a plan would be expensive, but so is the current system. This year, total spending for private health insurance will top $500 billion, according to the Health Insurance Association of America, a trade group. Why not spend it rationally, and lift the yoke of medical insurance serfdom from employers and employees alike?

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
Beneath The Smiles, A Churning Anxiety

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
WE live in a manic-depressive economy, and right now we're in the manic phase. The annual growth rate, 7.2 percent in the third quarter, was spectacular. The Keynesian-style stimulus has been wonderfully effective. But the depressive phase may kick in again soon, as growth slows and millions of employed and unemployed Americans struggle to make up for lost incomes. 
 They are out there trying now, earning $40,000 or $50,000, for example, rather than the $50,000 or $60,000 they made before they were laid off and took pay cuts to get work again. The Labor Department does not calculate their growing numbers, and neither does anyone else. 
 But who notices these days? Consumer spending carried the economy in the summer and early fall, accounting for two-thirds of the third-quarter growth rate. Tax cuts and mortgage refinancing put hundreds of millions of dollars into people's pockets -- offsetting lost income -- and low interest rates cut borrowing costs.
 The 7.2 percent growth rate is not sustainable. Nearly every forecaster concedes that. A month into the fourth quarter, the growth rate has probably fallen back to 4 percent or so. That is still robust, but not enough to dispel the sadness that will set in as we climb down from euphoria. 
 Part of the sadness lies in the obstacles to re-employment. The corporate sector remains plagued with overcapacity and may require many months of 4 percent growth just to make full use of those currently working. Job creation has to move above 200,000 a month, most economists say, before we can begin to shrink the pool of nearly nine million unemployed. We haven't gotten to six-digit job creation yet, much less sustained it. No wonder the unemployed spend 19.7 months, on average, seeking work, the longest stretch in nearly 20 years. 
 "The breadth of the unemployment is almost unprecedented," said Mark Zandi, chief economist at Economy.com. 
 Of the nine million unemployed, five million were laid off or fired, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. (The remainder are new entrants or people returning to the labor force after a voluntary absence.) Most of those five million will work again, but for less pay. The bureau's wage data, from its "job displacement" surveys done every two years, are clear on this point. Three people are laid off, and three years later only one has regained the lost wage or risen above it. 
 Labor economists describe the process: You are forced out of a $25-an-hour job and, after six months of job hunting, find work at $20 an hour. Two years later, having struggled back to $23 an hour, you are laid off again, and you slip back into the next job at $21 an hour. During this period, your standard of living suffers not only from the lower wage, but also from the income lost during unemployment and the loss of the raises you would have received if you had never been laid off.
 How many millions of people are living this experience? Such a number, if it existed, would be an effective indicator of our standard of living and our ability to sustain economic growth through consumer spending. Among the currently unemployed, most are expected to face lower pay in their next jobs. But how many Americans now working lost one or more jobs in the last 20 years as layoffs spread? 
 The Bureau of Labor Statistics suggests the number is high. It has been tracking 10,000 people, a cross section of the population, since 1979, when most were teenagers and the permanent layoff was just becoming a national phenomenon. They are in their 30's and 40's now, and over the years each has held, on average, 9.6 jobs. The survey does not include reasons for so much job-changing, but the average is high enough to suggest that at least one or two of the jobs followed layoffs. 
 IN a similar vein, Ann Huff Stevens, a labor economist at the University of California at Davis, working with data from a 1992 health and retirement study, found that among men and women 51 to 62 years old who had been laid off, 47 percent had been laid off more than once. 
 Such surveys suggest that tens of millions of Americans are struggling to get their incomes back to where they were. The struggle dampened wage gains even in the booming 90's and has sapped confidence. "They have lost their seniority and their confidence that they can ride out succeeding waves of layoffs," said Katherine Newman, a sociologist at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard. "And they see now that education does not protect them anymore. It used to, but it doesn't anymore. It shakes their faith in their capacity to control their lives."

CORRECTION-DATE: November 9, 2003

 CORRECTION:
The Economic View column last Sunday, about the struggle of the formerly unemployed to make up for lost income, misstated the average time that an unemployed worker spends looking for another job. It is 19.7 weeks, not 19.7 months.

HEADLINE: THE BUSINESS WORLD; 
Does Brazil Have Italy on the Ropes?

BYLINE:  By TONY SMITH

DATELINE: SANTO CRISTO, Brazil 

 BODY:
THANKS to an offbeat wooden chair dreamed up by the Brazilian designers Fernando and Humberto Campana, a tiny family-owned factory in this sleepy town has found itself suddenly -- and somewhat unexpectedly -- at the vanguard of change sweeping through Brazil's furniture industry.
 It took almost a leap of faith for Wilson Schuster, the factory's director, to agree to build the Campana brothers' chair, which is made from bits of leftover timber nailed together apparently at random. It is named Favela, after Brazil's chaotic, haphazardly built shantytowns. 
 "When I first saw the prototype, I must admit I thought they were joking," Mr. Schuster said. 
 Less than a year later, Mr. Schuster, 42, is glad he took the plunge. Favela, now commissioned by Edra, a leading Italian furniture company, was one of the stars of the trend-setting furniture fair in Milan this year. It retails for more than $1,800, and orders are coming in from around the world. 
 Today, six carpenters -- a tenth of the staff at the company, which is also named Schuster -- are building Favela chairs full time at the factory here, deep in southern Brazil near the border with Argentina. Exports, virtually nonexistent last year, will account for 10 percent of revenue this year.
 With their traditional domestic market languishing in recession and the local currency weaker against the dollar and Americans increasingly buying cheaper furniture, more and more Brazilian furniture makers are looking to the North American market.
 But a few, like Schuster, have ambitions that go beyond shipping off containers full of cheap wardrobes, desks and chairs copied from American models, as their Chinese rivals do. Instead, they have in their sights the high-end design furniture industries of Italy and Spain, which are losing out in the United States these days because of the strengthening euro.
 Last year, Americans bought $262 million worth of Brazilian furniture, according to United States government data. Although that was only a quarter of what Italy shipped to the United States and less than 5 percent of the $5.7 billion sold there by China, it was still up 35 percent for the year. And that gain came on top of a 34 percent increase in 2001.
 "The sustained growth indicates Brazilians increasingly understand how to meet the demands of the American market," wrote Brian Carroll, editor of Furniture/Today, a trade magazine, in a recent issue.
 Robson Oliveira, who is preparing to open the Terra do Brazil Design Center, a 12,000-square-foot showroom for Brazilian design in Miami, says he believes that in four years Brazil can match Italy's $1 billion in sales to the American market, which soaked up $14.2 billion of furniture imports last year.
 American manufacturers are already hurt by cheap Chinese imports. More than 47,000 furniture workers have lost their jobs since 2000, according to the American Furniture Manufacturers Association. This month, United States companies are expected to file an anti-dumping petition against China with the Commerce Department and the International Trade Commission, a federal agency.
 But Brazilian exporters say they are not worried because they do not need to keep pace with China. They say they would be more than pleased just to catch up with Italy.
 "What Italy makes, we can make too," Mr. Oliveira said, adding that Brazilian companies used high-quality hardwood but offered prices that were "40 percent lower." The potential for export growth is huge. Although it has traditionally exported more timber than tables, Brazil is the world's 10th-largest furniture manufacturer. But of its $3.5 billion in sales last year, only $500 million came from exports.
 Much of the export drive comes from Brazil's southern states, settled early in the last century mainly by German and Italian immigrants, who brought with them family business traditions of hard work and austerity. Today, 10,000 of Brazil's 13,500 furniture manufacturers are small and still family-owned, like Schuster.
 "Southern Brazil is just like northern Italy -- full of small firms capable of producing quality furniture," said Humberto Campana, who spent three years developing the Favela chair. "Now there is a growing consensus that, instead of copying their furniture, we should be copying their model." 
 Italy's furniture industry invests about 10 percent of its revenue in design and, with brands like B&B Italia, Cappellini and Edra, has nearly a fifth of the global market. Its exports earn the country nearly $13 billion a year.
 In Brazil, the story is different, as the Campanas' experience shows.
 Hailed abroad for their originality and the Brazilian-ness of their designs, the Campanas have four pieces in the permanent design collection of the Museum of Modern Art in New York. But they spent years trying to break into the local market.
 From 1993 to 1998, they managed to sell just five copies of their Red Chair, made from the thick, soft cord used in hot-air balloons, piled on a tubular frame like spaghetti on a plate, at a price of $900 each.
 Then, Massimo Morozzi, Edra's design chief, decided to produce the chair in the company's own factory, improving its components. Today it is a global design icon, gracing not only MoMA postcards but also top hotels, stores and restaurants around the world -- including Brazil. The chair sells for 4,000 euros, or about $4,700, in Europe and the United States, but $7,000 in Brazil because of steep import duties. 
 "That shows our industry has to take design more seriously," said Marilene Bittencourt, Schuster's sales director. "Our manufacturers must see that profit comes from originality, not from copying others."
 For Schuster, the approach seems to be working. Just after the Edra deal, Ms. Bittencourt signed a contract to supply Cliff Young, a distributor in New York, with bedroom furniture and television stands.
 While declining to reveal financial details, Ms. Bittencourt said the two export contracts meant that Schuster would be producing on such a scale that by next year it would be moving to a new factory twice the size of the current one.
 In Sao Paulo, in Brazil's industrial heartland, larger-scale factories with up-to-date technology have also won important contracts from Italian manufacturers.
 Living Divani and Porro, two top-end Italian brands, have furniture made in Brazil for South American markets. It is the first time either company has licensed production outside Italy. The move is a huge vote of confidence in Brazil's furniture industry, said Marcio Barbosa, corporate director of Grupo Atrium, a design furniture distributor in Sao Paulo.
 "Their standards are rigorous, but with the euro rising and the real falling, it makes perfect sense to produce locally," Mr. Barbosa said. "It also shows we are not only strong in artisanal manufacturing, but also in high tech."

HEADLINE: The World; 
New Global Trade Lineup: Haves, Have-Nots, Have-Somes

BYLINE:  By LARRY ROHTER

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO 

 BODY:
THE end of the cold war did away with the East-West split and made fashionable the notion of a North-South divide. Forget Communism versus capitalism. Now it was rich versus poor. But even as negotiators continue seeking a global trading system that might lift economies in both categories, that idea now appears to be coming apart at the seams. 
 Just as old military alliances are changing, familiar trade alliances and rivalries are mutating or dissolving under pressure from forces far stronger than ideology: in this case, competition for profits and markets. 
 This week in Washington and later this month in Miami, trade ministers from across the Americas are to meet again to try to adjust the rules that would govern free trade in the hemisphere, and the exchanges promise to be caustic. The prospect of a global agreement or even a hemispheric pact like Washington's pet project -- the Free Trade Area of the Americas -- seems to be receding, replaced by a fragmented panorama in which resentment and bitterness set the tone.
That became clear in September, when representatives of the 146 nations that make up the World Trade Organization gathered in Cancun, Mexico, for negotiations intended to reduce barriers to trade. The talks broke down amid mutual accusationsof bad faith. One factor was a familiar sore point for nations with what Wall Street likes to call emerging markets: the United States and other industrialized nations insist on a right to continue subsidizing their own agricultural products. 
But there was also a striking new development: the emergence of a coalition of not-so-poor nations that no longer fit the profile of either have or have-not. Calling itself the Group of 20-plus, the bloc was conceived by Brazil and India as a way to bring together large, resource-rich and economically dynamic nations from the South -- a not strictly geographical label since it includes China as well as Indonesia, Thailand, South Africa, Nigeria, Mexico and Argentina.
These countries have the clout to demand greater access to the markets of industrialized nations because together they account for more than half the world's population -- and they also have substantial manufacturing centers of their own.
The United States and Europe, faced with an opposition more cohesive and vocal than they were used to, responded with petulance. "The improvised articulation led by Brazil is something from another planet," said Franz Fischler, the European Union's agricultural commissioner. "They need to come back to earth quickly."
But Charlene Barshefsky, who was United States trade representative in the Clinton administration, sees the Brazilian-led coalition as a logical development -- "an additional power center, much better organized and more savvy," with a stake in the world trading system. 
"Years ago, the North-South divide was largely ideologically based," she said, with the poorer countries looking to shield themselves, through protectionism, from the risks of free trade. Now, she said, there are "floating combinations of countries, in which essential economic interests, and not ideology, are the guidepost."
In that context, the Cancun talks were also notable for the gulf that arose between the Group of 20-plus and the rest of what is known as the developing world. The conference was brought to a halt -- over the question of American and European agricultural subsidies -- not by Brazil and its allies but by a larger, separate coalition of less developed countries, mostly African and Caribbean, that felt disenfranchised and ignored. "If it were just up to the Group of 20-plus, the meeting would have ended with a decision to keep negotiating," said Rubens Ricupero, a Brazilian who is the director of the United Nations Commission on Trade and Development.
Members of the Group of 20-plus, in fact, account for a growing slice of world trade and have a broad range of interests. Brazil, once thought of as just an agricultural exporter, now counts airplanes and automobiles and car parts as its leading export items.
The danger now, especially for the weakest nations, is that trade talks will be transformed into what the economist Jagdish Bhagwati calls a "spaghetti bowl" of bilateral and regional agreements. More than 300 such accords already exist, each with a slightly different set of rules. Dr. Bhagwati, a Columbia University professor, notes that "poor countries are singularly unequipped to cope with the chaotic regime."
The Bush administration's current strategy seems to be divide and conquer. In an article for The Financial Times in September, the United States trade representative, Robert B. Zoellick, warned that "as W.T.O. members ponder the future, the U.S. will not wait: we will move towards free trade with can-do countries."
Members of the new bloc also seem to be taking a patchwork approach, seeking new trade patterns among themselves that make political sense even if at the cost of economic efficiency. India, for example, has bypassed Boeing and Airbus in favor of Brazil's Embraer as it tries to modernize its fleet of government planes.
Whether the Group of 20-plus can continue to hold together is another question. While the coalition has forced the United States, Europe and Japan to take note and rethink their plans, it does not speak with a single voice on all matters. "India and China don't have the same interests as we do in Brazil, because they are not big agricultural exporters, but rather importers," said Felipe Lampreia, a former Brazilian foreign minister. "But that doesn't mean developing countries can't come together on particular themes."

HEADLINE: BULLETIN BOARD; 
Saying 'No, Thanks' to Board Memberships

BYLINE:  By HUBERT B. HERRING

 BODY:
So with all those executives raiding, inflating or otherwise tinkering with the corporate cookie jar, and with "Sue the directors!" the primal reaction of the aggrieved, the question is: Why would anyone want to sit on a companys board? 
 Far fewer people do, apparently. According to a Korn/Ferry International study, 23 percent of Fortune 1000 directors said no when asked to take on additional board seats in 2002, up from 13 percent the year before. 
 As Charles King, an official at Korn/Ferry, put it, "The minimum acceptable participation level keeps rising." Or, more simply, they've got to pay attention now.
 In the last year, board diversity has hardly changed. HUBERT B. HERRING

HEADLINE: The Nation: Guru Nation; 
Every Recession and Every Recovery Has a Nostradamus

BYLINE:  By JOHN SCHWARTZ

 BODY:
SIGNS of economic spring are all around: stocks are up, profits are surging and companies might even be hiring again. 
 Can the gurus be far behind? 
 Back in the bubble days, the gurus were everywhere. There were the market gurus talking up stocks and options and fanciful derivatives, and technology gurus preaching revolution in fat magazines like Wired, Red Herring and the Industry Standard. 
In books like "The Long Boom," by Peter Schwartz, Peter Leyden and Joel Hyatt, new economy gurus promised that high technology would smooth the ups and downs of the business cycle and lead to an age of endless prosperity. 
There were also plenty of examples of that sum of all gurus, the Visionary C.E.O. -- leaders like John F. Welch Jr. of G.E., Bernard J. Ebbers of WorldCom and Kenneth L. Lay of Enron.
Then the business cycle reminded everyone that it was still there. The irrationally exuberant markets crashed and suddenly, the gurus were no longer a big part of the talking-head-ocracy.
"Basically, the only place you see the business gurus is on milk cartons," said Paul Saffo, a research director at the Institute for the Future in Menlo Park, Calif.
Gurus, of course, serve a purpose -- as do cheerleaders, security blankets and Dumbo's magic feather. Some, of course, can offer real insight. But many offer only comfort and courage in an uncertain world. Their fractious community waxes and wanes with the ups and downs of the economy. 
In hard times, their numbers dwindle and they tend to offer hope in the gloom. When the seasons seem ready to change for the better, they re-emerge, passionate about the Next Big Thing. And if the good times become too good, and the bubble bursts, they quietly move away from the spotlight (or, in a few cases, to jail), and bide their time until the economic season of hope comes around again. 
To Mr. Saffo, whose nonprofit research group helps companies deal with uncertainty and risk, the guru class has had little choice but to seek a lower profile, given that so much of what it had to say during the boom of the 1990's was just plain wrong. "The biggest mistake you can make is to confuse what you wish would happen with what you think might happen," he said.
But one of the grandest gurus of all, Tom Peters, a co-author of the 1982 best seller "In Search of Excellence," says the field is too varied to draw simple lessons. 
"Certainly the C.E.O.-as-hero took a hit," he said, but "consulting academics" like himself did not have so far to fall. "If there is a guru industry -- which even though there clearly is, I'm not willing to acknowledge it, because it's such an awful idea -- there are presumably numerous flavors thereof," he said.
Jeffrey Sonnenfeld, the associate dean of executive programs at the Yale School of Management, said that chief executives, especially, have shied from the spotlight. In a recent article for a McKinsey & Company quarterly, he wrote, "The inevitable fall of the once breathless apostles of e-commerce -- such C.E.O.'s of 'the new economy' as Yahoo's former C.E.O., Tim Koogle, Priceline's Jay Walker and Webvan's George Shaheen -- also doomed the appeal of their self-promotional style." 
In an interview, Mr. Sonnenfeld said many of today's baby-boomer executives took the warning of recent history to heart, and "have decided to try to minimize the cult of personality that had grown up around their predecessors."
In fact, he says, the current crop goes too far, and needs to speak out as part of their role in leading their companies. "It's very much part of the job," he said.
This new-found reticence, however, is only proper, said Thomas Frank, a social critic of the boom years. "They should lose their guru cards after their performance in the 90's," he said. 
To Mr. Frank, much of the guru-ification during the go-go 90's was, at its core, not an economic phenomenon but a political one abetted by journalists, in which business was portrayed as rational and trustworthy, and government was portrayed as "the enemy of markets, arbitrary imposer of taxes and regulations."
To Mr. Saffo, however, the audience that lapped up the rosy forecasts and exhortations shares equal blame. "People only listened to the news they wanted to hear," he said.
There may be new siren songs on the way. 
"It has been a period blessedly free of business guru books," Mr. Saffo said, "but I also have no doubt that there is a huge wave coming in over the horizon, and we will be drowning in Guru Inc. before long."
The wave is already rising. Clayton Christensen, whose 1997 book "The Innovator's Dilemma" vaulted him to instant guru status, is back with "The Innovator's Solution: Creating and Sustaining Successful Growth." Mr. Peters, too, has a new book: "Re-Imagine! Business Excellence in a Disruptive Age." And perhaps representing a new guru generation is Jerry Bowyer, a Pennsylvania radio and television talk show host, whose new book, "The Bush Boom," claims that President Bush has repaired the damage done to the economy by Bill Clinton.
As gurus and their publishers start their engines, however, it might be worth noting one other book that is not likely to appear on any best-seller list. It is a 1959 children's classic: "Will Spring Be Early? Or Will Spring Be Late?" by Crockett Johnson. In it, a groundhog mistakes a flower in the snow as a sign of a very, very early spring.
"I have never made a better prediction than this!" he says to himself, excitedly.
The other animals cheer him as a hero -- all except the grumpy old pig, who refuses to accept the single leading indicator as evidence of a broader trend. And in a moment that echoes the end of the great tulip bulb bubble of the 1600's, when a skeptic, according to legend, took a bite out of a bulb to mock the trading frenzy and crashed the market, the pig takes a bite out of the flower, and declares that it is made out of paper and wire. 
"I have a prediction to make," the pig says. "It's going to snow." And it does.
The word guru, by the way, comes from Sanskrit. It forms the root of another common English word: grieve.

HEADLINE: The Nation; 
The Middle Class Spends Its Way to Recovery

BYLINE:  By CONSTANCE L. HAYS

 BODY:
WHETHER the object of desire was a new car, a new coat or a new indulgence, American consumers opened their wallets wide in the third quarter -- helping the economy expand at the fastest rate since 1984, according to the government.
 But after enduring three years of a sluggish economy, what, exactly, were people rushing out to buy? 
 In large part, people were not buying tickets to Paris. Instead, people seemed to be letting loose but in a practical, deliberate way. They were buying necessities: cars, refrigerators, clothing. And this being the American consumer, there was a frivolous little thing (or two or three) thrown in. But even that spending reflects the new priorities of a sober consumer. 
"The rich don't have to put off their purchases," said W. Michael Cox, senior vice president and chief economist of the Federal Reserve Bank in Dallas. "This is the consumption of the masses driving the economy."
Spending on furniture and other items for the home rose 20.7 percent, and automobile spending rose 38.9 percent. Indeed, purchases of durable goods -- meaning any item with a three-year warranty -- rose 26.9 percent in the quarter, said Drew T. Matus, chief economist for Lehman Brothers. 
That spending was a response by consumers comforted by lower interest rates for credit cards and home mortgages. 
"You could look at durable goods as the most interest-sensitive part of the economy," Mr. Matus said. 
But the purchases also showed that consumers are, perhaps, acting more responsibly than in the past. "Spending on durable goods reflected a certain maturity among consumers," said Mr. Cox, of the Federal Reserve. "People waited until they could afford the payments."
Consumers displayed a similar restraint when it came to spending for nondurable goods, a category that includes clothing, food and energy. Spending for nondurables grew 7.9 percent in the third quarter, Mr. Matus said, and in that category, spending on clothing showed the largest gain, growing by 10 percent. 
Spending on services, which includes housing, transportation, medical care and recreation, grew even more modestly, at 2.2 percent.
In other words, consumers weren't spending a lot on personal trainers or facials. "A lot of the service spending seems to be necessities," Mr. Matus said, referring to categories like health care. "Given how the rest of the economy performed, it is not a lot of money."
Practicality, of course, only goes so far. There are signs that recreational shopping also drove spending. But even here, spending was measured.
At Wal-Mart, shoppers carted home toys, electronics, paint and lawn and garden products, a spokesman said. Sales rose 6.6 percent in August, compared with the same month in 2002. The growth for September was more subdued, at 5.6 percent for the five weeks ending Oct. 3.
At Sears, big sellers include plasma and liquid-crystal display television sets, starting at $450 and soaring to $10,000, as well as laser tools for building projects, said Ted McDougall, a Sears spokesman.
Even this high-end electronic gadgetry, it could be argued, is not a complete extravagance nowadays. "Do you know what $2,000 will buy?" asked Mr. Cox, of the Dallas Federal Reserve.
He ticked off a list of almost two dozen items, including a computer, a television, a microwave oven, an MP3 player and a digital camera, that could be purchased together for less than $2,000. 
Consumers are buying with a sharp eye for discounts. Emily Chapman of Locust Valley, N.Y., reported buying a new refrigerator recently. At the same time, she bought clothes at a discount store, like a pair of Pucci trousers for $100, marked down from $1,500.
"The buyers are not necessarily traditional luxury consumers, but people who are very close to scrimping," said James B. Twitchell, a professor of English and advertising at the University of Florida. "Luxury is moving its way down into objects that are chocolate bars or bottled water. They are not out of reach, and that's what makes them so alluring."
Despite their spending in the third quarter, many Americans have not emptied their bank accounts and still seem to be holding onto their cash for the coming holiday season, Mr. Matus said. 
"Almost every economist overstated the size of the spending" ahead of the results, he said. "There's a lot of money out there that we can't account for, and the best guess is that it's going to be used for Christmas."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Buying a refrigerator, a typical durable good, is not a rash decision. (Photo by Associated Press)

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL/2004 Rolls-Royce Phantom; 
Keeping Up With the Maybachs

BYLINE:  By KEITH MARTIN

 BODY:
COMMONERS can become instant lords and ladies in Britain, simply by buying a title. Automakers, too, can gain nobility with a check, and the Germans have been on a snob-appeal shopping spree.
 In a flurry of acquisitions in recent years, Volkswagen bought Bentley, Bugatti and Lamborghini (and arranged an alliance with Maserati), and BMW acquired Rolls-Royce. Mercedes-Benz countered by creating a new ultraluxury brand (whose name, Maybach, revives a German marque that ceased to exist in 1941). 
 Why this rush to buy operations that in many cases have minuscule sales and produce profits that are, at best, limited? Perhaps it is as simple as keeping up with the Joneses (or the Schmidts). For Volkswagen, BMW and Mercedes, owning your own extraordinarily expensive nameplate makes you a serious player in the high end of the market. It also lends you cachet that may rub off on your more mundane cars, the ones that sell for $100,000 or $60,000. 
 VW picked up Bentley in 1998, along with all of the Rolls-Royce and Bentley manufacturing capabilities and a worldwide distribution network, for nearly $800 million. For $65 million, BMW got automotive rights to the Rolls name, but no factory or dealers. The first all-new BMW-designed Rolls, the Phantom, was unveiled early this year. The car is built at a new plant in Goodwood, England.
 Mercedes had already shown its Maybach, which went on sale at roughly the same time. Just as the Maybach relies heavily on the big Mercedes S-Class sedan for its mechanical components, the Rolls is primarily a custom frame and body, plus a bespoke interior, surrounding a slightly modified engine, transmission and suspension from the BMW parts bin.
 Both cars are wildly expensive, the Maybach 57 with a suggested list price of $308,000 and the Phantom starting at $324,000, including delivery. For better or worse, cars in this rarefied price range are judged by their own set of standards, which do not include fuel economy, ease of parking or towing capability.
 Those who can afford a Maybach or a Rolls are looking for a visual statement of wealth, truly elegant appointments and superior, if unobtrusive, performance. 
 I test-drove the Maybach earlier this year around Los Angeles, and then drove a Phantom through the tony Santa Barbara countryside. I took the Rolls on expressways, urban streets and challenging mountain roads. Judging by the reception the car received, the Phantom is the hands-down winner in the visual-impact category. Wherever we went, we were met with thumbs-up, rather than class resentment, from the common folk.
 And although the Rolls is surprisingly easy to maneuver in traffic, it is even better when enjoyed from the back seat, with a chauffeur in place. The rear quarter is designed so that when you sit back in your seat, your face is hidden. To see the proletariat, it is necessary to lean forward slightly. When you do, it seems appropriate to give a gracious royal wave.
 The Phantom is no shrinking violet. Not only is it large, at 19.1 feet in length (the hulking Cadillac Escalade ESV is 6 inches shorter), it is heavy at 5,577 pounds. And it is powerful, with 453 horsepower from its 6.75-liter V-12 engine.
 The upright front grille is, by far, the most debated part of the car. The Phantom's designer, Marek Djordjevic -- he was personally chosen by Chris Bangle, chief designer for BMW -- said in an interview that his goal was "to achieve the same type of assertiveness and presence that the Rolls of the 30's, 40's and 50's had." He added, "Rolls-Royces of recent years have been understated, almost as if they were ashamed of being Rolls."
 Oddly, the small rectangular lights high on the fenders, near the hood, are actually pairs of turn signals and driving lights. The actual headlamps are round, and they are mounted low, near the bumper, where you expect the turn signals to be. The mixture of round and angular lights is visually unsettling. 
 The grille is massive and imposing; if laid on its side over a flame, you could probably barbecue enough hamburgers on it to satisfy all the New York Jets at once.
 The styling of the rest of the car is more successful. The back half has cues from the R- and S-Type Bentleys of the 1950's and 60's. The rear window is small; the taillights seem tiny by today's standards. 
 To foil sticky-fingered miscreants, the famous Rolls mascot, the Flying Lady, cleverly disappears into the grille at the touch of a button. (She can also be programmed to go into hiding when the car is locked.) The liquid-filled hubcaps rotate independently of the wheels, and when the car is stopped, the RR logo in the center is always in an upright position. 
 The car rides on huge 31-inch-high Michelin tires of a run-flat design, so no spare is necessary. But because of the tires' stiff sidewalls, a surprising amount of road noise is transmitted into the car. By contrast, the Maybach is as hushed as an Egyptian tomb. 
 As you might expect from a car with 531 pounds-feet of torque, the Phantom proceeds effortlessly and, according to Automobile magazine, reaches 60 m.p.h. from a stop in 5.7 seconds. Surprisingly, the body leans noticeably on corners. A company spokesman said that this was intentional, that Rolls had decided not to employ adaptive suspension technology -- as used in some BMW's -- to keep the car flat in turns. Rather, they felt that some lean provided a more natural feeling to passengers.
 As a result, on the highway the Phantom is not as surefooted as you might expect. The Maybach, by comparison, seems much more secure at high speeds. Above 90 m.p.h., the front end of the Phantom felt as if it were getting lighter and was starting to "float." 
 Quick lane changes were not the car's forte, and it felt uncertain and overweight when pushed hard on a country road. Admittedly, few Rolls-Royce owners will ever drive their Phantoms in such a spirited fashion, but in an age when computer-controlled suspensions are increasingly the norm on high-end cars, more roll stability should have been built into this Rolls.
 The Phantom's strong point is a cabin that wouldn't look out of place in one of the world's finest yachts. The dash is an elegant mix of retro and modern elements. The gauges are analog -- the speedometer, a combined fuel and water temperature gauge, and, unique to Rolls-Royce, a gauge labeled "power reserve" that provides an estimate of how much power remains at any instant. Chauffeurs with a hot-rodding inclination will note that there is no tachometer to report the engine's speed.
 Cows and trees should be wary of this car; up to 16 hides swathe each interior, which is also trimmed with as many as 60 pieces of individually lacquered wood. The steering wheel is elegant, with a hard, thin, leather-wrapped rim that has raised grips at the 4 and 8 o'clock positions, rather than the customary 2 and 10. This is another clue that Rolls-Royce expects you to drive in a relaxed manner.
 The Phantom features a version of iDrive, the widely decried computerized control system used in big BMW's. Butin a telling concession, Rolls lets you essentially bypass iDrive: the stereo and air-conditioning systems have separate, intuitive controls that are almost as clear as those in a $25,000 Honda Accord, a first for a German-designed luxury car.
 Should you wish to use iDrive, a panel in the center of the dash -- it contains an analog clock -- rotates to reveal the iDrive screen.
 The center console must be opened to gain access to the seat-positioning controls, which means that neither you nor your passenger can have your arms resting on the armrest if the seats need adjusting.
 On the Interstate, aside from tire noise, the car offered an experience fit for a king. The rear seat sits higher than those in front, so rear passengers have a view of the road as commanding as the driver's. 
 The interior is acoustically engineered so that with four people in the car all voices are clear, crisp and easily heard.
 Rolls-Royce plans to build only 1,000 Phantoms a year, with just 400 or so for the United States, so you are unlikely to see yourself coming and going at the mall, even if your mall is a very exclusive one.
 Both the Maybach and the Phantom, when equipped with the optional rear buckets, are priced at about $80,000 a seat. With the Mercedes-derived car, the owner gets a big sedan with unremarkable styling but impressive performance, along with an interior festooned with the latest in electronic gadgets. 
 The Phantom takes the opposite approach. It is visually arresting, with an opulent interior in the traditional English luxury-car style. With its lack of high-tech distractions, it entreats you to sit back and enjoy the ride in regal style.
 The Maybach is the better car, but the Phantom is the more striking statement of success.

INSIDE TRACK: Majesty withoutsubtlety.

HEADLINE: Page Two: Oct. 26-Nov. 1; 
ECONOMIC NEWS FOR OPTIMISTS

BYLINE:  By David Leonhardt

 BODY:
Many economists greeted last week's rosy economic news with a chorus of "Yes, but . . . "
 Sure, they said, the economy grew at an annual rate of 7.2 percent during the three months ending on Sept. 30, more quickly than any quarter since 1984. 
But employment still declined during the quarter, leaving many Americans with little to show for the boom. 
 This criticism -- and the fact that the calendar is about to turn to an election year -- has increased the attention on the Labor Department's next jobs report, to be published on Friday. Most forecasters expect a gain of about 50,000 jobs in October, similar to the increase of 57,000 in September, the first rise since January.
That would be far short of the 150,000 or more new jobs needed each month to keep pace with population growth, but would still represent progress compared to most of this year.
In other words, an increase of that size would be just enough to keep the optimists optimistic and the pessimists pessimistic.
 David Leonhardt

SECTION: Section 2A; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk; Pg. 22

LENGTH: 2930 words

HEADLINE: HOLIDAY MOVIES; 
December

BYLINE:  By ANITA GATES; Compiled with the assistance of Suzanne O'Connor

 BODY:
 Dec. 5

FIVE SIDES OF A COIN -- A documentary about the power and culture of hip-hop, with Run DMC, Afrika Bambaataa, Grandmaster Flash, De La Soul and at least three dozen other artists. Paul Kell directed.

FORGET BAGHDAD -- A documentary about Jewish and Arab stereotypes, especially as seen in 100 years of film. Examples include Hollywood features, Israeli boureka comedies and Egyptian musical comedies. The film also focuses on the experience of Sephardic Jews, who may feel like foreigners in their own country. Directed by the Iraqi-born video artist Samir, whose family moved to Switzerland when he was a child.

FROM HERE TO ETERNITY -- The love scene on the beach (Deborah Kerr and Burt Lancaster clinched and drenched) is well known. Frank Sinatra's performance, as the scrappy Private Maggio, revived his stalled career and won him the Oscar for best supporting actor (one of eight Oscars the film received, including best picture). Montgomery Clift is Private Prewitt, the reluctant boxer, and Donna Reed is the ladylike hooker he falls for. The film, based on James Jones's novel about a military base in Hawaii just before Pearl Harbor, is exactly 50 years old. Fred Zinnemann, who did "High Noon" and went on to do "A Man for All Seasons," directed.

HONEY -- Jessica Alba (who made her name in the futuristic Fox series "Dark Angel") stars as an inner-city dancer who makes it big as a choreographer of music videos. Then she encounters sexual harassment. The cast also includes Lil' Romeo and Mekhi Phifer. Directed by Bille Woodruff.

THE LAST SAMURAI -- It's been a long time since Tom Cruise appeared on screen in period costume (and that was as a vampire). In this 19th-century epic, he's Nathan Algren, an alcoholic Civil War veteran who's been called to Japan to teach its army all about modern warfare. Which will mean the end of the samurai, and Algren becomes unsure that that's a good thing. Edward Zwick (whose film credits include "Glory") directed, and he wrote the screenplay with his former "thirtysomething" partner, Marshall Herskovitz, and John Logan. Tony Goldwyn, Billy Connolly and Ken Watanabe are Mr. Cruise's co-stars. A related article is on Page 6.

MONSIEUR IBRAHIM -- Omar Sharif plays a Muslim grocer who becomes good friends with an emotionally needy Jewish boy (Pierre Boulanger) in 1960's Paris. Mr. Sharif shared the best-actor audience award (with Benicio Del Toro for "21 Grams") for this role at the Venice International Film Festival. Francois Dupeyron directed.

PRISONER OF PARADISE -- In 1944, the Nazis decided to make a propaganda film about Theresienstadt, painting it as a utopian community rather than the death camp it was. To make the film, they chose Kurt Gerron, a German Jew who had been arrested in Amsterdam. Gerron was not just another prisoner. He had starred in "The Blue Angel" with Marlene Dietrich and had introduced the song "Mack the Knife" in the original Berlin production of "The Threepenny Opera." When the film, "The Fuhrer Gives a City to the Jews," was completed, Gerron was sent to Auschwitz and gassed. Malcolm Clarke (who did the Oscar-nominated short documentary "You Don't Have to Die") and Stuart Sender directed this film, which was nominated for best documentary feature of 2002 and is now being released commercially.

WHAT ALICE FOUND -- A drama about truck-stop prostitution. Emily Grace plays a young woman driving south to Florida. Bill Raymond and Judith Ivey are the seemingly nice couple who stop to help her when she has car trouble. They have some career ideas for her. A. Dean Bell wrote and directed.

Dec. 10

BIG FISH -- Tim Burton goes for heart-warming in this adventure drama about a dying father (Albert Finney) and his not-that-close son (Billy Crudup), who wants to know whether the tall tales that Dad told all those years were true. Really, where does a traveling salesman run into giants and witches? Jessica Lange is the dying man's wife, and Ewan McGregor and Alison Lohman play the couple's younger selves. The screenplay is by John August, who wrote "Go" (which everyone loved) and "Charlie's Angels: Full Throttle" (which they didn't).

POWER TRIP -- During the Soviet years, a lot of people in Georgia didn't pay their electricity bills and nothing happened. But when AES, an American company, bought the power plant in the capital city, Tblisi, and bills weren't being paid, the company did things the American way: they turned off the power. Paul Devlin's documentary is about the fiasco.

Dec. 12

GIRL WITH A PEARL EARRING -- Dad is suddenly unemployed after an accident at work. His 16-year-old daughter goes to work to help out the family. Then she falls in love with her married boss. In Peter Webber's film, this timeless story takes place in 17th-century Holland and the girl's employer is Johannes Vermeer, whose most famous paintings include a portrait of an unknown young woman, "Girl With a Pearl Earring." Colin Firth plays Vermeer and Scarlett Johansson, currently having her star-making moment in "Lost in Translation," plays Griet, the teenager turned housemaid. Based on the best-selling novel by Tracy Chevalier.

LOVE DON'T COST A THING -- We're remaking 1987 movies already? Sixteen years ago, "Can't Buy Me Love" starred Patrick Dempsey as a high school nerd who pays the prettiest girl in school to go out with him so people will think he's cool. This teenage romantic comedy stars Nick Cannon ("Drumline") as a high school nerd who pays the prettiest girl in school (Christina Milian) to date him for the same reason. Steve Harvey plays Mr. Cannon's father. Directed by Troy Beyer, who wrote and starred in "BAPS."

SOMETHING'S GOTTA GIVE -- We haven't seen Jack Nicholson and Diane Keaton together since his Eugene O'Neill seduced her Louise Bryant in "Reds." This time his middle-aged character is dating her character's daughter (sexy Amanda Peet), but after he has a heart attack he realizes it's the older woman he really loves. But a young doctor (Keanu Reeves) feels the same way about her. Nancy Meyers, who wrote and directed, also wrote "Private Benjamin" and "Baby Boom" (starring Ms. Keaton) and directed "What Women Want."

THE STATEMENT -- For a man who turned 70 this year, Michael Caine is awfully busy. In this political thriller from Norman Jewison (whose last feature film was "The Hurricane"), Mr. Caine plays a former Nazi executioner who has led an undisturbed postwar life in France until he is suddenly on everyone's hit list. The cast also includes Tilda Swinton, Charlotte Rampling, Alan Bates, Jeremy Northam and Ciaran Hinds.

STUCK ON YOU -- The Farrelly brothers, Bobby and Peter, have given moviegoers comedy about multiple personalities, morbid obesity, dogs in body casts and wayward ejaculate. Now they turn to the world of conjoined twins. Bob (Greg Kinnear) and Walt (Matt Damon) share a liver, get along beautifully and make a great hockey player in their hometown. But now Bob wants to go to California to pursue his dream of becoming an actor, and Walt says he won't hold him back. In their new life, they come into contact with Cher, Meryl Streep, Jack Nicholson, Jay Leno and Luke Wilson, who play themselves.

Dec. 17

THE LORD OF THE RINGS: THE RETURN OF THE KING -- The end has come for Peter Jackson's film trilogy, based on J. R. R. Tolkien's fantasy novels. Since all three films were shot at the same time, this one is likely to be as spectacular as the first two. When last we saw Tolkien's characters, Frodo (Elijah Wood) was getting a much-needed pep talk, Aragorn (Viggo Mortensen) was looking kingly and Gandalf the Gray (Ian McKellen) was looking grand on a white horse. Now the battle for Middle Earth begins, and someone has got to get that ring to Mount Doom and throw it into the fires. Other returning cast members include Sean Astin, Orlando Bloom, Cate Blanchett, Ian Holm, Liv Tyler, Hugo Weaving and Christopher Lee. Gollum (Andy Serkis, plus computer generation), who won best virtual performance at the MTV Movie Awards, is back, too. A related article is on Page 6.

Dec. 19

THE BUTTERFLY -- An 8-year-old girl bonds with the elderly entomologist next door. A family drama starring Michel Serrault and Claire Bouanich. Directed by Philippe Muyl.

CALENDAR GIRLS -- In Britain, apparently, if you are desperate for funds, the thing to do is take off your clothes. It worked for the unemployed men in "The Full Monty." And it worked for the ladies of the Rylstone Women's Institute in Yorkshire. To raise money for leukemia research, they decided to pose for the group's annual calendar wearing pretty much nothing but pearls. The models were all in their 40's, 50's and 60's. Helen Mirren and Julie Walters star in the film version of this true story. Nigel Cole, who did "Saving Grace," directed.

THE FOG OF WAR -- "This is a movie filled with existential dread," says Errol Morris, the director. "There's this surreal sense that nothing has changed." The documentary in question is about Robert S. McNamara, secretary of defense during the Kennedy and Johnson administrations. The film focuses on McNamara's involvement in the Vietnam War, the Cuban missile crisis and the World War II fire-bombing of Japan. When it was shown at the New York Film Festival last month, Stephen Holden, writing in The New York Times, called the film a "sober, beautifully edited documentary portrait."

THE HEBREW HAMMER -- Finally, a Jewish action hero. Jonathan Kesselman, the young writer and director of this satire, enjoys playing with stereotypes. The title character, whose real name is Mordechai Jefferson Carver (Adam Goldberg), is a Brooklyn private eye who, in his spare time, saves the world of Jewish culture and tradition. But, as the filmmakers point out, his mother still wishes he'd done more with his life. The Hammer is battling Santa Claus's son Damian (Andy Dick), who is out to eliminate Hanukkah. Mario Van Peebles plays the head of the Kwanzaa Liberation Front. Peter Coyote plays Bloomenbergansteinthal, head of the Jewish Justice League, which includes members of the Worldwide Jewish Media Conspiracy.

MONA LISA SMILE -- Here's Julia Roberts, barely 36 and already playing the older woman. In this drama from Mike Newell, whose films include "Enchanted April," "Four Weddings and a Funeral" and "Donnie Brasco," Ms. Roberts plays an open-minded Berkeley graduate who takes a job teaching art history at Wellesley in 1953. She has wonderful students but is horrified to realize that they have no interest in using their minds beyond whatever it takes to land a husband. And so she questions their values and tries to shake things up. Kirsten Dunst, Julia Stiles and Maggie Gyllenhaal play students.

Dec. 24

CHILDREN OF LOVE -- ("Les Enfants de l'Amour") From Belgium, one weekend in the life of a family separated by divorce, focusing on the three children. Geoffrey Enthoven, the writer and director, began doing research for a documentary but turned it into a docudrama instead. The cast includes Nathalie Stas, Winnie Vigilante, Michael Philpot and Olivier Ythier.

MONSTER -- Newspapers called Aileen Wuornos the first female serial killer. She was a highway prostitute and drifter who killed at least six men and was executed last year in Florida. Wuornos has been the subject of a television movie, a feature documentary, an opera and an Off Off Broadway play. In the latest film version, written and directed by Patty Jenkins, Charlize Theron takes the role, playing way against type, and Christina Ricci portrays her young lover.

Dec. 25

CHEAPER BY THE DOZEN -- Steve Martin and Bonnie Hunt seem made for each other as a pair of busy professionals with 12 children. This isn't exactly a remake of the 1950 film starring Clifton Webb as an efficiency expert who liked to test his theories on his own huge family: Mr. Martin plays a football coach who gets a new, time-consuming city job and Ms. Hunt is an author on a book tour, and both could use some time-management guidance. Their children include Piper Perabo, Tom Welling (the young Clark Kent on "Smallville") and Hilary Duff. Ashton Kutcher plays a boyfriend that Dad doesn't like. Mr. Martin has plenty of opportunities for physical comedy, including swinging from a chandelier. Shawn Levy ("Big Fat Liar") directed.

COLD MOUNTAIN -- Anthony Minghella's last two films, "The English Patient" and "The Talented Mr. Ripley," were major winners. Now he's written and directed this Civil War drama, based on Charles Frazier's novel of the same name. Jude Law plays a badly wounded Confederate soldier who leaves the hospital and begins a long walk home to North Carolina and the woman he loves (Nicole Kidman). She, meanwhile, is trying to manage her dead father's farm. Luckily a helpful drifter (Renee Zellweger -- an American!) turns up and stays. North Carolina's film industry may be thriving, but this film was shot in South Carolina, Virginia and Romania. A related article is on Page 1.

THE COMPANY -- It's going to be hard for Robert Altman to top his last film, "Gosford Park," but he's giving it a go with this backstage story of the ballet world. He says he hopes to capture "the work itself in all its demanding beauty." Barbara Turner (a co-writer of "Petulia," Richard Chamberlain's best movie, and the glorious "Pollock") did the screenplay, based on a story she wrote with Neve Campbell. Ms. Campbell ("Party of Five") is the central character, a young ballerina on the brink. The cast also includes James Franco, who gave an uncanny performance in TNT's "James Dean"; Malcolm McDowell; and members of the Joffrey Ballet.

PAYCHECK -- Michael Jennings (Ben Affleck), a computer engineer, has two big problems in this sci-fi thriller: his $4.4 billion paycheck has been canceled and his memories of the last two years have been erased. (That's the way he manages to work on top-secret projects without confidentiality dangers.) In trying to figure out what happened, he's aided by the woman he both works with and loves (Uma Thurman). Aaron Eckhart is back in bad-guy mode as Jennings's boss. John Woo directed, and Dean Georgaris wrote the screenplay, based on a short story by Philip K. Dick, whose stories and novels have been turned into films including "Blade Runner," "Total Recall" and "Minority Report." Related articles are on Pages 9 and 28.

PETER PAN -- After Mary Martin, Sandy Duncan, Cathy Rigby and Mia Farrow comes a Peter Pan actually played by a 14-year-old boy (Jeremy Sumpter). P. J. Hogan, who did "My Best Friend's Wedding," directed, and Michael Goldenberg ("Contact") wrote the screenplay, based on J. M. Barrie's classic, and frequently filmed, British play. The cast also includes Jason Isaacs (Lucius Malfoy in the second Harry Potter movie) as Captain Hook, Rachel Hurd-Wood as Wendy and Ludivine Sagnier (the sexy teenager in "Swimming Pool") as Tinker Bell.

YOUNG BLACK STALLION -- A prequel to the 1979 film "The Black Stallion," based on the Walter Farley novel. Seems that before the mysterious Arabian horse met
his best human friend at sea and bonded with him during a shipwreck, he had a significant emotional relationship with a little girl who had been separated from her father. The cast includes Biana Tamimi, Richard Romanus and Patrick Elyas. Simon Wincer ("Free Willy" but also "Crocodile Dundee in Los Angeles") directed. Jeanne Rosenberg, who was one of three co-writers on the first "Black Stallion" movie (which was directed by Carroll Ballard), did the screenplay. This is Disney's first dramatic feature made for Imax and other large-screen formats.

Dec. 26

HOUSE OF SAND AND FOG -- Sometimes the American dream doesn't come easy. Ben Kingsley plays an Iranian immigrant, a former member of the Shah's inner circle now reduced to doing menial jobs. He jumps at the chance to buy a house for back taxes, but it turns out that the house was seized erroneously and the evicted owner (Jennifer Connelly) has troubles of her own. Ron Eldard, who impressed New York theatergoers in "Death of a Salesman" and "Bash," is a deputy sheriff who gets far more involved than he should. Vadim Perelman, a Russian-born newcomer, wrote and directed. Based on the 1999 novel by Andre Dubus III.

MODERN TIMES -- Charlie Chaplin's last silent film and one of his comic masterpieces. Chaplin, who wrote and directed, stars as a factory employee -- his classic character the Little Tramp -- who has a nervous breakdown shortly after a test of an automated "feeding machine" (created so workers won't have to take breaks while eating lunch). He ends up in jail (he loves it there), goes back to a factory (where some large wheels eat his tool box and a co-worker), gets a job as a department store night watchman, becomes a hero while under the accidental influence of cocaine and ends up as a singing-dancing waiter with Paulette Goddard, his favorite waif. The film was originally released in 1936.

Dec. 31

JAPANESE STORY -- Which, of course, takes place in Australia. Toni Collette stars as a geologist stuck with baby-sitting a prospective client (Gotaro Tsunashima) who won't be satisfied with the usual city tour. She dislikes him on sight and he doesn't seem to care for her either, but at his request she takes him into the outback, where they eventually face a life or death situation. It's a love story, an adventure, a culture clash and an odd-couple comedy all in one, directed by Sue Brooks and written by Alison Tilson. This is Ms. Collette's return to her home country's film industry after appearing in a number of American and British movies ("The Sixth Sense," "About a Boy," "Far From Heaven").
