HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey; 
Schwab Thinking Small in Subleasing in Jersey City

BYLINE:  By ANTOINETTE MARTIN

 BODY:
CHARLES SCHWAB & COMPANY made the decision before the gleaming glass 19-story, 577,000-square-foot office tower built to its specifications on Jersey City's waterfront was even complete: go to Plan B.
 It was not that the building itself, Plaza 10 at Harborside Financial Center, had somehow fallen short. It was that the San Francisco-based brokerage house's need for it shrank in the economic downturns of late 2000 and 2001, as the structure was going up. Schwab had signed a 15-year lease for the entire structure, built and owned -- until recently -- by the Mack-Cali Realty Corporation. It put the entire building up for sublease in late 2001. 
 After the Sept. 11 attack on the financial district in New York, two large financial service companies moved in: Mizuho Bank, a Japanese bank taking 107,000 square feet, and Instinet, an electronic brokerage service arm of Reuters, taking 144,000 square feet. The rest of Plaza 10 -- 326,000 square feet -- remained vacant, though, as the economic slump went on, new buildings continued to rise on the Hudson riverfront, and more and more sublease space was thrown onto the commercial office market. 
Last spring, Schwab and its brokers -- Cushman & Wakefield and Handler Real Estate Services -- decided it was time for Plan C: break up the floors of the building, if necessary, and recruit smaller tenants aggressively -- offering them all the amenities Schwab had built into Plaza 10, as well as architects and builders to customize a tenant's space and a big break on the rent. Schwab's long-term lease is for $34 per square foot annually, but sublease deals of about $25-a-square-foot are being offered, for terms as short as five years or less. 
Schwab's real estate director, Paul J. McDevitt, said Cushman's broker-analysts came up with the approach. "Cushman recommended that this low-hanging fruit was being ignored by others," Mr. McDevitt said. "We thought we would take the opportunity to go after it."
Jersey City has traditionally been sought after as a site for large administrative and back-office operations for Manhattan financial services firms and other corporations. But the market for such big-fish tenants has slowed drastically in the last several years. 
"UBS Paine Webber, over at the Newport Office Center VII, a stone's throw away, is in virtually the same situation as Schwab," said Richard Donahue, a Cushman broker, referring to the fact that that company has had a half-million square feet of space available for sublease for almost two years.
He also mentioned a Goldman Sachs building nearing completion at the harborfront. Goldman Sachs has said it will occupy all of its own building, but brokers expect it will occupy only a fraction of it. Also, Lehman Brothers has 375,000 square feet on the market for sublease in Jersey City, he said. 
When these mammoth firms, and others, came to Jersey City in the 90's, "the market was hot as a pistol, with virtually no vacancy," Mr. Donahue said. "But financial service firms are not in an aggressive growth mode any longer -- is that an understatement, or what?"
Last summer, Schwab and Cushman held a large reception for real estate brokers to begin the new pitch to smaller users. "Mr. McDevitt made it irresistible for brokers to bring deals," said a Jersey City realtor, Skip Dolan, who heads Dolan Realty, which deals primarily with small-office tenants. "He said: 'We will not be undersold.' "
"I didn't let any grass grow under my feet," Mr. Dolan said. "I brought over eight tenants, and there are six transactions pending."
Mr. Donahue, who is handling the Schwab subleasing for Cushman, said deals with five new tenants had closed in the last six weeks, and two more were on the brink.
The seven deals will fill only 13 percent of the available space. "But we have momentum," Mr. Donahue said. "Obviously, it takes more time and work to fill a large office space with smaller tenants, but we are discovering there is a real market in it."
THE new tenants at Plaza 10 include Park Avenue Capital, which will relocate from Park Avenue at 57th Street in Manhattan, taking 3,500 square feet; Unigestion Ltd., a Swiss financial firm opening its first United States office, taking 4,521 square feet; and Perr & Knight, an insurance company based in Pacific Palisades, Calif., opening its first East Coast location and taking 4,181 square feet.
Two other tenants are relocating from within Jersey City: Arlington Hill Investment Management, taking 5,120 square feet, and Welgrow International, a shipping company, taking 3,972 square feet.
Lease terms on the five new deals range from five to 15 years.
One factor making the deals easier, Mr. Donahue said, is that Mack-Cali no longer owns the building, although it continues to manage it. Mack-Cali owns five other office buildings totaling more than three million square feet of Class A office space at Harborside Financial Center. Its agreement with brokers had been that any potential tenant shown space at Plaza 10 also had to be shown available space in the other buildings as well.
Plaza 10 was sold on Sept. 29 to a Manhattan-based investor, IStar Financial, for $194 million. Real estate executives believe that is the highest price ever paid for a building in the area but noted it is still a bargain by Manhattan standards. The purchase price came to $336 per square foot. Last year, 399 Park Avenue, a trophy property in Manhattan, sold for more than $600 a square foot. The landmark G.M. Building recently sold for more than $800 a square foot.
"When Mack-Cali sold," Mr. Donahue said, " the benefit for us was that it became wonderfully easy to go after tenants our own way. The complications with Mack-Cali disappeared." Mr. Dolan said he now told potential tenants for the Schwab building that "all tenants are being treated like 100,000-square-foot tenants."
"Smaller companies needing space don't have the people in house to do a build-out when they sign the lease," Mr. Dolan said. "They don't have time to hire a contractor, an architect, etc. But Schwab is providing those things. If a tenant needs X number of private offices, a server room, a pantry and a certain size bullpen for its employees, they make their reqests -- and within a few days' time, they get a set of plans."
Paul Spiegel of Handler, the brokers working with Cushman, said the Schwab property raises the bar as to what is available to smaller tenants in the New York metropolitan area. The building offers space with substantial glass, partitioning and tenant-controlled air-conditioning, since the systems were installed floor by floor.
If all that were to be available to a small tenant in Manhattan, it would almost certainly cost more than what Schwab is charging now, Mr. Spiegel said.
In addition, he said, the Jersey City building has an added amenity: the view. "The best views of Manhattan, the Empire State Building and the George Washington Bridge are from the Jersey side of the Hudson," Mr. Spiegel said. "Everybody knows that."
Mr. Donahue said he could not speculate on how long it might take to fill up the building, small tenant by small tenant. "All I know," he said, "is that this is working, after a long period of things that weren't working, so we're going with it."

HEADLINE: Did the Tax Cut Help the Economy? 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "Spotted: Evidence That Tax Cut Worked" (Economic View, Oct. 19): 
 Critics of President Bush's tax plan do not address the short-term, and possibly short-lived, economic gains of the tax cut. 
Instead they are worried about the effects on long-term growth, and their criticisms are still very valid.
 The Bush tax cut, combined with increased government spending, is creating huge projected deficits. These deficits are even more alarming if we take account of needed Social Security reform. 
 Other, less regressive tax cuts would have resulted in a bigger stimulus in the short run, making the bitter pill of large deficits a little easier to swallow. Low income people do spend a larger percentage of their income, thus suggesting that less regressive cuts would have resulted in a larger stimulus.

Ann Owen
Clinton, N.Y., Oct. 21

The writer, an economics professor at Hamilton College, previously was an economist for the Federal Reserve Board.

HEADLINE: The Nation: Help!; 
Disaster Aid: The Mix Of Mercy and Politics

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
PRESIDENT BUSH'S declaration last week that the wildfires in Southern California were a "major disaster" was the 50th such declaration he has issued this year.
 That is more than one disaster a week, double the average annual figure in the 1980's. At the rate he is going, Mr. Bush's total for the year could approach the record of 75 disasters declared by President Clinton in 1996, his re-election year. 
 When a president declares a region a disaster zone, like the four counties in California hit by fires, millions, even in a few cases billions, of federal dollars become available overnight. The residents can be eligible for assistance ranging from unemployment benefits to temporary housing to low-interest loans, and the communities receive grants to cover expenses like debris removal, repairs to damaged buildings and emergency public services. 
No one seriously believes there are more floods, fires and pestilence than there used to be. What has happened, in the view of students of the subject, is that presidents have discovered the political utility of the Federal Emergency Management Agency's disaster program.
Without question, the fires last week left a terrible trail of devastation, destroying more than 3,100 houses and other structures. But in a comprehensive analysis of disaster declarations over the years, two economists, Thomas A. Garrett of the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis and Russell S. Sobel of West Virginia University, found this year that "nearly half of all disaster relief is motivated politically rather than by need."
They used as the takeoff point for their paper this quotation from Congressional testimony in 1996 by James Lee Witt, then the director of the emergency management agency: "Disasters are very political events."
Mr. Witt declined to be interviewed for this article. Several other politicians and officials said they agreed with Mr. Witt's description, but they said it only after being promised their names would not be used.
"It's so awkward to talk about," said Representative Earl Blumenauer, Democrat of Oregon. "You don't want to appear mean-spirited."
The reluctance of politicians to speak out leaves criticism of the disaster programs primarily to an odd alliance of free-market conservative economists and avid environmentalists.
Even the most ardent libertarians do not hold that the federal government should offer no help when communities are devastated -- by a big earthquake, say, or a powerful storm. 
"There are national emergencies in which there is clearly a legitimate role for the government," said John Frydenlund, a senior fellow at Citizens Against Government Waste, a conservative research and lobbying organization. "But what's happening in agriculture, for instance, is that some part of the country has a little too much or too little rain, and there is pressure to declare a disaster area."
When assistance is too freely available, Mr. Frydenlund and some other economists say, it can result in more harm than good.
They hold that private disaster insurance is more expensive and less widely available than it should be because federal relief programs reduce the demand for private coverage. They also argue that the programs induce risky behavior, allowing Californians whose homes are destroyed by fire, for instance, to rebuild on fire-prone hillsides.
Other economists are more concerned about what they see as the inequity in requiring struggling taxpayers in, say, North Dakota, to pay taxes to cover the expenses every time a hurricane strikes affluent taxpayers in South Florida. In many parts of the country, statistics show, the farther people live from the coastline, where the property is most vulnerable to storms and flooding, the less well off the people are likely to be.
The case against the relief programs that environmentalists make is that natural disasters are part of the normal ecological cycle.
Federal flood insurance, to take one example, has often resulted in people building or rebuilding on high-risk flood plains that are "some of the richest and most important ecological areas in the country," said David Conrad, a water resources specialist at the National Wildlife Federation.
But these arguments carry little weight with the politicians. Rarely does any lawmaker take issue with offering money to regions where disasters have occurred. One reason, some suggest, is that the day may come when their states or districts will be seeking relief.
The disaster relief law is vague on how it should be applied, so presidents have great latitude. The General Accounting Office, the auditing arm of Congress, has recommended more specific guidelines and standards for years, but Congress has never seen fit to enact them.
Mr. Clinton was a master at showing compassion and spreading the wealth. Time and again at countless fires, floods and blizzards, he showed up to hug victims and offer the government's largess. The television correspondent Brit Hume once called him "almost the national chaplain to those in distress."
Mr. Bush has picked up where his predecessor left off. People are likely to remember the California fires and Hurricane Isabel for years to come. But how many remember even now the ice storm that struck South Carolina last January, the winter storm in upstate New York in April or the heavy rains in New Hampshire and Vermont in July, all belonging to the president's list of 50?
Still, even the president's staunchest political opponents in Congress are not complaining. To the bill providing $87 billion for military operations and reconstruction in Iraq, Congressional negotiators last week added $500 million for "disaster relief activities associated with recently declared disasters, such as Hurricane Isabel and the California wildfires."
The words "such as" were added at the end of the negotiations to appease lawmakers whose states and districts were not affected by the fires or the storm, but perhaps had some other emergency.

HEADLINE: Half a Step on Iraqi Security 

 BODY:
The Bush administration made a smart decision last week to speed the training of an Iraqi civil defense militia to help patrol the seething Sunni Arab area around Baghdad. Yet not even tens of thousands of new civil defense officers can relieve America of its larger military responsibilities in Iraq. Until there is a sovereign Iraqi government with a rebuilt national army, purged of top Baathists and carefully balanced among Sunnis, Shiites and Kurds, substantial international military forces will be needed. And until the United States occupation gives way to an international administration, most of those troops will have to be American. 
 With White House political strategists eager to see American troops headed home before next year's election and Pentagon planners scrambling to keep weary Army and Reserve units in the field, the administration should be eager to transfer sovereignty and internationalize the occupation. Yet despite cosmetic concessions in the latest Security Council resolution, Washington clings to its unrealistic insistence on unilateral occupation. Iraqis and Americans are paying the consequences. 
 It isn't surprising that President Bush now calls for training thousands of Iraqi militiamen. Violence is spiraling, American troops are stretched to their limits and no significant foreign military contributions are in sight. Even if more American troops were available, having them patrol cities and towns is a bad idea. 
Using heavily armed American troops for policing risks fanning resentment and plays into the hands of the Saddam Hussein loyalists, religious fanatics and extreme Sunni nationalists believed to be behind recent terrorist attacks. Along with relief organizations and Iraqis working with Washington, American soldiers have become regular targets. Over the past month, the number of attacks directed against the 130,000 United States troops in Iraq has grown to nearly three dozen a day. 
Some 90,000 Iraqis now work for American occupation authorities, including police, border patrol officers and guards protecting vital infrastructure. About 5,000 have been given civil defense training, with another 10,000 scheduled for training. The White House wants to quicken that schedule so that tens of thousands of Iraqi militiamen can be sent into the region around Baghdad. 
The training should not be abbreviated too drastically. Some of the trainees are men in their late teens, others could be former Iraqi Army members. Care must be taken to vet those joining the new militia force so that it is not infiltrated by hard-core Baathists or other extremists. If these precautions are observed, accelerated recruitment and training is a good idea. Not only can it ease tensions between Iraqis and American troops, it can also free more Americans to hunt Saddam Hussein and his inner circle and to hold mutually suspicious regions together while a constitution is drafted, elections held and the economy rebuilt.
Those tasks will very likely require 100,000 or more foreign troops for many months to come. That will strain American military capacities unless significant help is provided by countries like France, Russia and India. None seem eager to offer troops. But they will be more likely to do so if the request comes from a real Iraqi government.
Lack of security in Iraq is holding up relief work, economic revival and constitutional progress. Washington says that transferring more power to Iraqis and the international community must wait until there is more stability. Achieving that stability will require substantial Iraqi and international help, some of which will be available only when Washington loosens its grip on power in Baghdad.

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY 

 BODY:
 INTERNATIONAL 3-16

U.S. Considers New Force With Old Iraqi Army Units
Some American military officers in Iraq are pressing to reconstitute entire units of the former Iraqi Army to help stabilize the nation. That would require careful screening to weed out Saddam Hussein loyalists. 1

Twenty-two American soldiers have given their lives to the occupation of Iraq in the last two weeks, a platoon of 21 men and 1 woman cut down in accidents and the rising insurgency. 1

After one of the worst weeks of violence in Iraq in months, L. Paul Bremer III, the American administrator for Iraq, said the American strategy for quelling the attacks was to "encourage Iraqis to play a central role" in securing the nation. 13

In Court Over Mine Ownership
Descendants of the nomadic Nama tribe have laid claim to land in South Africa occupied by a large diamond mine and the minerals in it, charging that the former apartheid government drove their ancestors off it. 3

Fighting in Afghanistan
Bouts of factional fighting erupted across Afghanistan, and a Turkish road engineer was reported kidnapped by suspected Taliban fighters, officials said. 16

Sri Lanka Power Sharing Plan
The rebel Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam released a proposal for an interim authority for the territory they control in Sri Lanka. 11

Democratic presidential candidates are being forced to recalibrate their attack on President Bush's economic record because of an economic surge. They now say that one quarter of growth does not erase three years of sluggishness. 1

The growing success of albums by older artists offers some hope for a slumping record industry. 1

A Primer on Fire Safety
A planned community at the edge of the Santa Susana Mountains largely escaped damage during the Southern California wildfires and is seen as a model in fire survival. 24

Enola Gay Exhibit Is Faulted
The Smithsonian is facing criticism of an exhibit of the World War II bomber Enola Gay that makes no mention of Hiroshima. 18

Taking Sides in Feeding Case
Friends have come to the defense of Michael Schiavo, who wants to remove the feeding tube from his wife, who has been in a vegetative state for 13 years. 18

NEW YORK/REGION 31-39

Trash Heap on Long Island Spurs Lawsuit Over Compliance
The New York State attorney general's office is suing a recycling company to remove a trash heap that sits on a waterfront industrial peninsula on Long Island, on charges that the company flouted permits and state regulations for years in running the solid waste dump. 38

Evolving Pictureof a Family
A more nuanced picture of the New Jersey couple accused of starving four of their adopted children is coming to light as neighbors try to reconcile the accusations against the couple with the close-knit family they thought they knew. 31

High Lead Levels Persist
Thousands of children still have high lead levels, in part because of lead in the soil, on the streets and underneath elevated subway lines. 31

52 of 732 DOCUMENTS

 The New York Times

PUB-DATE: November 2, 2003
 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section 2A; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk; Pg. 17

LENGTH: 3488 words

HEADLINE: HOLIDAY MOVIES; 
Goodbye, Neo. Hello, Captain Crowe.

BYLINE:  By ANITA GATES; Compiled with the assistance of Suzanne O'Connor

 BODY:
 November
All dates subject to change.

Wednesday

THE MATRIX REVOLUTIONS -- As the trailer says, "Everything that has a beginning has an end." And this is it for Andy and Larry Wachowski's trilogy about a world in which everything humans think they know is just a computer simulation. Keanu Reeves carries on as Neo, who may or may not be the One to save humanity. Alien ships invade Zion, the city where the last free humans live. There's something about a train and rogue programs, and if you don't know who the Sentinels are, you could be lost. Laurence Fishburne returns as Morpheus, Hugo Weaving as Agent Smith and Carrie-Anne Moss as Trinity. Mary Alice plays the Oracle, replacing Gloria Foster, who died two years ago of complications from diabetes.

THE REVOLUTION WILL NOT BE TELEVISED -- (a k a "Chavez: Inside the Coup") California hasn't been the only place dealing with a recall referendum. Hugo Chavez, the president of Venezuela since 1998, has faced a general strike, the near collapse of his country's economy and a coup (in April 2002) that ousted him from office for a weekend. He now faces a recall movement, with the possibility of a vote early next year. Kim Bartley and Donnacha O'Briain, documentary filmmakers from Ireland, were in the right places at the right times.

Friday

ANYTHING BUT LOVE -- If "Far From Heaven" was a tribute to 1950's melodramas and "Down With Love" a fond remembrance of the Doris Day and Rock Hudson comedies around the same time, this film, directed by Robert Cary, is a tribute to the Technicolor musicals of that era. But this one is set in the present. Isabel Rose, who wrote the film with Mr. Cary, stars as Billie Golden, a 21st-century woman obsessed with 1940's and 50's glamour. She's also torn between two men: the boy she adored in high school and a jaded pianist. Which one will make her feel more like Rita Hayworth?

BILLABONG ODYSSEY -- A docudrama about some of the world's best surfers, and you can probably guess what they're doing. Yes, searching for the biggest wave on the planet. Locations include California, Mexico, Hawaii, Australia and Tahiti. Surfers include Mike Parsons, Ken Bradshaw, Layne Beachley and Brad Gerlach. Philip Boston is the first-time director.

ELF -- Will Ferrell, whose last notable film was "Old School," plays a human brought up among elves at the North Pole. Having always felt different, he travels south to find his biological father (James Caan) and learns that New Yorkers have forgotten the true meaning of Christmas (a problem they've had at least since "Miracle on 34th Street," in 1947). Ed Asner plays Santa Claus. Directed by Jon Favreau, who's gone in unexpected directions since "Swingers."

GLOOMY SUNDAY -- ("Ein Lied von Liebe und Tod") A restaurateur, a pianist, a waitress, a Nazi and a very depressing song in 1930's Budapest. The song is "Gloomy Sunday" ("Angels have no thoughts/ Of ever returning you/ Would they be angry/ If I thought of joining you?"), written by Rezso Seress and later given English lyrics by Sam M. Lewis. And it's true that the song became notorious for supposedly driving people to suicide when they heard it. Erika Maroszan, Joachim Krol, Stefano Dionisi and Ben Becker star in this romantic-triangle drama about moral choices and betrayal. Rolf Schubel directed.

HIDDEN IN PLAIN SIGHT -- Ever wonder where the Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega went to school? The same place as Roberto D'Aubuisson of El Salvador. It's the Western Hemisphere Institute of Security Cooperation (formerly the School of the Americas), a military training facility for Latin American soldiers and police officers. The odd thing is that it's in Fort Benning, Ga. And some people are unhappy about that, including John H. Smihula, the director of this documentary.

IN MY SKIN -- A French drama about self-mutilation. Marina de Van, who was Francois Ozon's co-writer on "Eight Women" and "Under the Sand," wrote, directed and stars. She plays a woman who has an accident and becomes so fascinated by her wounds that she starts inflicting new ones on herself. Her boyfriend (Laurent Lucas) doesn't quite know what to do. Lots of graphic gore.

JUST AN AMERICAN BOY -- What kind of American artist would write a song about John Walker Lindh, the American who joined forces with the Taliban? That would be Steve Earle, a longtime singer, songwriter and political activist, who told Jason Zengerle in The New York Times Magazine last year, "I felt like no one was trying to even consider for one second how he got to where he got." This combination concert film (shot during a 2002 tour) and documentary was directed by Amos Poe, who did "Alphabet City" in 1984.

LOVE ACTUALLY -- Things have worked out well before when Hugh Grant and the screenwriter Richard Curtis worked together ("Four Weddings and a Funeral," "Notting Hill," "Bridget Jones's Diary"). In Mr. Curtis's first film as a director, an ensemble romantic comedy set mostly in London, Mr. Grant plays a bachelor prime minister who falls in love with the young woman (Martine McCutcheon) whose job is to bring him tea. Emma Thompson, Alan Rickman, Liam Neeson, Colin Firth and Laura Linney (token American?) are among his co-stars, involved in relationships of their own. Billy Bob Thornton plays the president of the United States, which no longer seems strange at all. A related article is on Page 3.

LOVE FORBIDDEN -- ("Defense D'aimer") If you're going to question your sexual orientation, what better place than in an Italian villa? In this psychological drama from France, a young student, Bruce (Rodolphe Marconi, who also wrote and directed), has a chance to live and study in Rome. He leaves his girlfriend behind in Paris and soon meets a villa employee, Matteo (Andrea Necci), who seems both interesting and interested. But both men are absolutely sure they're straight.

MARTIN AND ORLOFF -- A black comedy about a failed suicide attempt. Matt Walsh and Ian Roberts of the improvisational group the Upright Citizens Brigade star. The troupe's other members, Amy Poehler and Matt Besser, make appearances, as do Janeane Garofalo, Andy Richter, Tina Fey and David Cross. Mr. Roberts is the suicidal patient, a mascot-costume designer traumatized because of the drowning death of a man in an egg-roll costume. Seems Mr. Roberts's character forgot to include eye holes. Mr. Walsh plays his psychotherapist, who turns their sessions into odd field trips. Lawrence Blume is the first-time director.

Nov. 12

MY ARCHITECT -- Louis Kahn designed, among other things, the Kimbell Art Museum in Fort Worth, Tex., and the Salk Institute in La Jolla, Calif., but it's his unorthodox private life that gets people's attention. He had three "wives" at once and a child by each. A son, Nathaniel Kahn, wrote and directed this documentary about Kahn, who in 1974 was found dead in a Penn Station men's room. When the film was shown at the New Directors/New Films festival in March, Stephen Holden, writing in The New York Times, called it "a meticulously structured portrait of a complicated man" with an "extra twinge" of poignancy.

Nov. 14

THE GOSPEL OF JOHN -- Not to be confused with Mel Gibson's film "The Passion." The life of Jesus, with Henry Ian Cusick, a Royal Shakespeare Company actor, as Jesus. Christopher Plummer is the narrator. Philip Saville, who has done mostly television work here and in Britain, directed. The screenplay is by John Goldsmith, using word-for-word dialogue from the American Bible Society's Good News Bible, in which John 3:16 becomes "God loved the people of this world so much that he gave his only son so that everyone who has faith in him will have eternal life and never really die." Nobody said it was pithy.

A HOUSE ON A HILL -- This one rings some "Life as a House" bells. Philip Baker Hall plays an elderly architect turned teacher who has pretty much given up on life and on the hillside, ocean-view house he began building decades ago. When a young couple want to buy it and have him finish it, everyone starts evolving emotionally. With Laura San Giacomo and Shirley Knight. From Chuck Workman, best known for his documentaries ("100 Years at the Movies," "Superstar: The Life and Times of Andy Warhol") and an Oscar winner for his short film "Precious Images."

LOONEY TUNES: BACK IN ACTION -- And so they are. Daffy Duck, fed up with Hollywood, teams up with a stunt man (Brendan Fraser -- all of him, not just his voice) to search for a missing diamond. Jenna Elfman, Joan Cusack, Steve Martin, Timothy Dalton and Heather Locklear (whose character's name is Dusty Tails) also star, in live action, alongside animated favorites including Porky Pig, Tweety Pie, Sylvester and Yosemite Sam. Directed by Joe Dante, whose credits include "Gremlins" and "Innerspace." A related article is on Page 3.

MASTER AND COMMANDER: THE FAR SIDE OF THE WORLD -- Peter Weir directs his countryman Russell Crowe, who is in period costume again. This time Mr. Crowe is Jack Aubrey, the early-19th-century sea captain of Patrick O'Brian's seafaring novels. Paul Bettany plays Aubrey's best friend, the ship's doctor. And if the water looks familiar, that's because it's in the same gigantic tank the makers of "Titanic" used. Mr. Weir rarely misses (from "Picnic at Hanging Rock" to "Witness" to "The Truman Show"), but can Mr. Crowe live up to Johnny Depp's new reputation as sexiest movie swashbuckler?

THE SINGING FOREST -- Reincarnation can be so inconvenient. Two gay lovers who died in the Holocaust come back, meet and fall in love all over again. The only problem is that one of them is the fiance of the other man's daughter. Written and directed by Jorge Ameer, whose past films have included "Strippers" and "My Straight Boyfriend." With Craig Pinkston, Erik Morris and Shelley Price.

TUPAC: RESURRECTION -- The rap star Tupac Shakur was only 25 when he died in September 1996 (from wounds inflicted in a drive-by shooting), but he was already a famous and controversial figure. Lauren Lazin's documentary about him appeared at the Sundance Film Festival in January; Elvis Mitchell of The New York Times wrote that it lacked a "clarifying vision," but the film was still a work in progress at the time.

I VITELLONI -- ("The Loafers") Federico Fellini's third film and one of his best, released in Italy in 1953 and in the United States three years later. It's the story of five young men in the provinces, wasting their lives and concerned about turning 30. (Fellini was 33 when the film was first released.)

Nov. 19

THE MISSING -- Ron Howard goes western. (His last film, "A Beautiful Mind," was a northeastern.) Tommy Lee Jones and Cate Blanchett star as an estranged New Mexico father and daughter who are forced together when the daughter's own daughter is kidnapped. With Evan Rachel Wood, Jenna Boyd and Aaron Eckhart. Ken Kaufman ("Space Cowboys") wrote the screenplay, based on Thomas Eidson's novel "The Last Ride."

TICKET TO JERUSALEM -- A drama about a Palestinian projectionist who travels from place to place showing movies to schoolchildren. One day a teacher asks him to bring his show to some students in Jerusalem, which presents a challenge. With Gassan Abbas, Areen Omari and George Ibrahim. Rashid Masharawi wrote and directed.

Nov. 21

THE BARBARIAN INVASIONS -- ("Les Invasions Barbares") Denys Arcand's group of oversexed Montreal dinner-party intellectuals (friends, lovers, exes) from "The Decline of the American Empire" is back. This time Remy (Remy Girard) is on his deathbed and determined to reconcile with everyone, although he's divorced from Louise (Dorothee Berryman) and not really speaking to his son (Stephane Rousseau), who's living in London. The first film was witty and delightfully talky, and the Cannes Film Festival judges seemed to like the second one. They gave awards to Mr. Arcand's screenplay and to Marie-Josee Croze, who plays a drug addict, as best actress.

BLUE GATE CROSSING -- From Taiwan, a high school romantic triangle with extra complications. Girl A acts as go-between for her best friend, Girl B, and Boy A. But Boy A likes Girl A better, and as if that weren't enough, Girl A really wants Girl B. Written and directed by Chin-yen Yee. With Bo-lin Chen, Lun-mei Guey and Shu-hui Liang.

DR. SEUSS' THE CAT IN THE HAT -- Theodor Geisel's large, mischievous kitty was a flop on Broadway as narrator of "Seussical!," but then the show didn't have Mike Myers. Mr. Myers plays the title role (it had to be he or Jim Carrey), who really messes up the house one day. It all starts with eating cake in the bathtub. The cast also includes Dakota Fanning (cute little girl of the year), Spencer Breslin, Kelly Preston, Alec Baldwin and Sean Hayes (as the voice of the Fish). Directed by Bo Welch, who has stuck mostly to production design ("Men in Black," "Primary Colors," "Edward Scissorhands") until now.

DUCK, YOU SUCKER -- ("Giu la Testa") It was Sergio Leone's penultimate credited film, released here in 1972, and many people consider it his most underrated. James Coburn plays an I.R.A. soldier far from home at the turn of the last century, and Rod Steiger is a Mexican bandit getting involved with his country's revolution. They team up and learn how different their values are. The film was also known in English as "A Fistful of Dynamite."

GOTHIKA -- Halle Berry, Robert Downey Jr. and a vengeful spirit? Good start. In this horror thriller from Mathieu Kassovitz ("La Haine"), Ms. Berry plays a psychologist who wakes up one day to find herself a patient in the mental institution where she works. And she finds herself accused of the murder of her husband (Charles S. Dutton), head of a prison psychiatric ward. Ms. Berry's character begins behaving strangely, but the cause may be something spookier than mere insanity. Mr. Downey plays a colleague and Penelope Cruz a disturbed patient. The screenplay is by Sebastian Gutierrez. Related articles are on Pages 9 and 28.

EL LEYTON -- From Chile, a romantic triangle that turns into a thriller. Two fishermen, longtime friends, are set against each other when one man has an affair with the other man's wife. Gonzalo Justiniano directed.

MAIL ORDER BRIDE -- If you're a Russian mail-order bride and you want to scam some lonely American man, don't pick a guy connected to the Mafia. When Nina (Ivana Milicevic) makes this mistake, an American mob boss (Danny Aiello) sends his nephew Anthony (Robert Capelli Jr.) to Moscow to retrieve her and the money. Sadly, Anthony isn't all that bright and neither is the Moscow mob boss's son (Slava Schoot) assigned as his partner. It's an action comedy directed by Mr. Capelli and Jeffrey Wolf. And my, how Moscow has changed!

THE TRIPLETS OF BELLEVILLE -- ("Les Triplettes de Belleville") Animated comedy written and directed by Sylvain Chomet, whose 1998 "Vieille Dame et les Pigeons" was nominated for the Oscar for best animated short. A related article is on Page 1.

21 GRAMS -- So far this drama from the team that did "Amores Perros" -- Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu, the director, and Guillermo Arriaga, the writer -- is talked about mostly for the meaning of its title. Seems that right after death, the human body weighs 21 grams less than before, and some like to say that's the
weight of the soul. But this is quite a cast, including Sean Penn, Naomi Watts and Benicio Del Toro, in a drama about a college professor, an ex-con and a formerly reckless wife-and-mom whose families are thrown together after a tragic accident. Last month, when it was the closing night selection at the New York Film Festival, Elvis Mitchell wrote in The New York Times that the film was "an extraordinarily satisfying vision" that "may well be the crowning work of this year."

Nov. 26

BAD SANTA -- John Ritter's next to last film ("Manhood," the last, hasn't been released yet) is a crime comedy. Mr. Ritter, who died in September, plays a shopping mall manager who is understandably upset when two con men (Billy Bob Thornton and Tony Cox) pose as Santa Claus and his right-hand elf and do some store-to-store shoplifting. But you can be sure someone will teach them the real meaning of Christmas before it's over. The cast also includes Bernie Mac and Lauren Graham. Terry Zwigoff, whose last two films were "Ghost World" and "Crumb," both a little off-center, directed.

EL BONAERENSE -- A touch of "The Big Easy," a touch of "Cops," a lot of Argentina. Jorge Roman stars as a locksmith who gets into trouble in his provincial hometown and has to be sent to the big city. He becomes a member of the Buenos Aires police force and quickly learns that corruption is all around him. With Dario Levy and Mimi Ardu. Written and directed by Pablo Trapero.

THE COOLER -- Bernie Lootz (William H. Macy) is the unluckiest man in Las Vegas, and his bad luck is contagious. Which makes for an odd career opportunity: a casino owner (Alec Baldwin) employs him to hang around and jinx customers who are winning too much. But when Bernie falls in love with a cocktail waitress (Maria Bello), his luck changes. And that's not good for the casino. Wayne Kramer directed.

THE HAUNTED MANSION -- Basing a movie on a theme-park ride seemed like a stupid idea a year ago, but that was before "Pirates of the Caribbean" earned $46 million on its opening weekend. This time we have a family horror comedy about a workaholic dad (Eddie Murphy), a real estate broker charged with selling a house that has a history. There are zombies, there are dark spirits and there's a friendly ghost (Martin Klebba), who may teach Mr. Murphy's character something Disneyesque about making time for family. Directed by Rob Minkoff, who did both "Stuart Little" movies. Written by David Berenbaum, a newcomer who also wrote "Elf."

IN AMERICA -- Jim Sheridan tells his own story or at least a variation on it. After "My Left Foot," "In the Name of the Father" and "The Boxer," all set in his native Ireland, Mr. Sheridan sets this family drama in the United States. It's about a young Irish immigrant couple (Paddy Considine and Samantha Morton) who move to New York with their two daughters, no money, a dream of a new life and overwhelming grief for their dead child.

TIMELINE -- Things are going smoothly for a group of student archaeologists working on a medieval dig in France, until their professor (Billy Connolly) disappears. He's traveled back to the 14th century and now they have to follow him there and keep him alive or there will be dire consequences. At least that's the way it worked in Michael Crichton's novel. Richard Donner ("Lethal Weapon," "Superman") directed. With Paul Walker ("The Fast and the Furious"), Frances O'Connor (the mom in "A.I."), David Thewlis ("Naked") and Anna Friel ("The Land Girls").

Nov. 28

HUKKLE -- ("Hiccup") When this film was shown at the New Directors/New Films series this year, Stephen Holden, writing in The New York Times, called it a "luminous directorial debut" for Gyorgy Palfi. And although it's mostly a beautifully photographed nature film ("a pastoral symphony"), there is also a plot: a murder case in a rural Hungarian village. With Ferenc Bandi, Jozsefne Racz and Jozsef Forkas.

INDEPENDENT SPIRITS: FAITH HUBLEY/JOHN HUBLEY -- The Hubleys, a mom-and-pop operation that made it big in American animation many decades ago, won three Oscars -- for "Moonbird," "The Hole" and "Herb Alpert and the Tijuana Brass Double Feature" -- plus the jury prize (shared with Garry Trudeau) at the Cannes Film Festival for "The Doonesbury Special." Their story is about more than awards, though. This documentary, directed by Sybil DelGaudio, also covers John's involvement with the 1941 Disney strike, his blacklisting in the 1950's and Faith's struggle for recognition in a male-dominated field. A related article is on Page 11.

THE LEGEND OF LEIGH BOWERY -- Bowery, one of the central figures in Boy George's new musical, "Taboo," was a costume designer, a performance artist, a musician, a club kid and a gay icon. This documentary reflects on his life and on London in the 1980's. Interview subjects include Boy George, Damien Hirst and Michael Clark. Charles Atlas, who also did "Merce Cunningham: A Lifetime of Dance," directed.

MY FLESH AND BLOOD -- Mia Farrow has nothing on Susan Tom. Ms. Tom is a divorced California mother in her 50's who has taken in and is bringing up 11 "special needs" children.That isn't always easy, especially when one of the children, a mentally unstable teenage boy, is threatening to kill one of his siblings. Jonathan Karsh, the director, brought in the cameras during the worst year of their lives, but Ms. Tom wouldn't have had it any other way. It was "like a free year of therapy," she said.

VALLEY OF TEARS -- All these decades after Edward R. Murrow's "Harvest of Shame" comes another documentary about the plight of migrant farm workers. This one, focusing on a 1979 Mexican-American onion workers' strike in Texas, at least has a hopeful ending. Hart Perry directed.

HEADLINE: Shall We Dance? 

BYLINE:  By William Norwich

 BODY:
The best things in life may be free, but current economic indicators suggest that demand now exceeds supply. 
 Job losses continue, the gap between the rich and the poor widens, the poverty rate is up, and new books have titles like "The Two-Income Trap: Why Middle-Class Mothers and Fathers Are Going Broke." Suffice it to say, we are not pushing caviar in this issue, nor, on the other hand, are we advocating hair shirts and crackers on Saturday nights. 
 After all, you have to dream to survive, just as Narciso Rodriguez Sr., the father of the fashion designer Narciso Rodriguez, did when he left Cuba for the United States in the mid-1950's. If we can't dream, then God help us all. Fortunately, these days, there is reverie aplenty. Have you noticed, for example, how much dancing -- the choreography of dreams -- has returned to the cultural imagination?
No fewer than two major discos have opened in New York this fall, Deep and Avalon, which also has established a West Coast version in Hollywood. Hugh Jackman is hoofing it up on Broadway in "The Boy From Oz." The high-heeled Beyonce is doing the work of what seems to be four sets of hips gyrating as one, and just about everyone under the age of 30 worth her (and in some cases his) low-slung blue jeans has at the ready an imitation of her ecstatic swayings.
While clothes of the 20's and the 70's are inspiring the fashion crowd, we must also thank the iPod for getting people moving again. If I've seen it once, I've seen it a dozen times in recent weeks: a zillion songs are downloaded, a desktop speaker is attached and suddenly every space from cramped galley kitchen to stadium-size downtown loft becomes an instant disco, a rave.
Shall we dance? Yes! Figuratively, literally, politically, economically. Even if it is just in our dreams. When you consider the alternatives, why not? Might as well get up on the dance floor and "boogie oogie oogie till you just can't boogie no more." 

GRAPHIC: Photo (Photograph by Ben Watts for The New York Times; Styled by Mimi Lombardo)

PERSON: BEYONCE KNOWLES (50%) William Norwich

HEADLINE: 'I Did It Frank's Way' 

BYLINE:  By Alex Witchel; Alex Witchel is a style reporter for The New York Times.

 BODY:
If it's not exactly "Call Me Ishmael," it's a classic all the same:
 "Summer 1968. The only man in America who was less interested than me in sleeping with Mia Farrow was her husband and my boss, Frank Sinatra." 
 So begins "Mr. S: My Life with Frank Sinatra," by George Jacobs, Sinatra's valet from 1953 to 1968, and William Stadiem, a memoir devoted to deep dish on the life and times of the Chairman of the Board and those who loved him: Ava Gardner and her drinking; Marilyn Monroe and her personal hygiene, or lack thereof; Judy Garland and her desperate sexual advances -- not all of them spurned. Published by HarperEntertainment in June, the book is now in its sixth printing, and has gone from being one of this summer's guiltiest pleasures to one of this fall's. 
It was in 1968 that Jacobs, now 76, unwittingly made what turned out to be the worst decision of his life. On his way to meeting Gardner one night (at his boss's instruction), he stopped into the Candy Store, a Beverly Hills disco. Farrow came in soon after and asked him to dance. They did. But timing is everything, as they say. Though Sinatra and Farrow had been estranged for some time, their divorce was about to be finalized. When the gossip columnist Rona Barrett reported that Sinatra's much younger wife was doing the watusi with her husband's black valet, Jacobs found himself fired and, within 24 hours, shut out of the Sinatra homes in both Bel Air and Palm Springs, Calif.
After 15 years on the inside of paradise, Jacobs was banished with a wrath that was practically biblical, not to mention vintage Sinatra; the singer had similarly excised from his life Peter Lawford, Lauren Bacall and Hank Sanicola, his original manager. The only difference, Jacobs says, is that he never thought Sinatra would do it to him.
He still seems shocked. On a late summer afternoon in Palm Springs, when the desert was drenched by intermittent downpours and the temperature hovered near a soggy 108 degrees, Jacobs braved his painful sciatica and glaucoma to prepare a Sinatra-style lunch. "Everything I learned about cooking for him was from his mom and dad," Jacobs said, stirring the marinara sauce. Dressed in a white linen shirt that stayed remarkably clean, Jacobs moved slowly, clutching his back. He never used the glasses that hung on a black cord around his neck.
"I made this so many times I could make it in my sleep," he said. "His dad, Marty, was an even better cook than his mother." After tasting the Dolly Sinatra marinara sauce, you can take his word for it. The base of the sauce is three serving spoons full of olive oil, which produces heartburn, Hoboken style, almost instantaneously. Jacobs shrugged. "You can put some water in the tomato can, thin it out a little," he said, pouring himself a straight vodka. He ran a hand through his white hair. "My back is killing me, man," he said to no one in particular.
Stadiem, a writer based in Santa Monica, Calif., was introduced to Jacobs by a mutual friend, the lawyer Henry Bushkin, made famous by his former client Johnny Carson, who called him Bombastic Bushkin on the air.
"What the hell did I do with the cover?" Jacobs asked, searching the small kitchen for something to speed the pasta's cooking. The Chicken Vesuvius was ready, and Stadiem was starving, but Jacobs didn't like being rushed. "I want it al dente," he said, "but not too hard."
Jacobs was born in New Orleans and learned to cook from his mother. "She was half Jewish, half Creole,"' he said. "And my father had a Jewish grandfather. My mother cooked for rich families, and she taught me to cook. Then I was in the Navy and went to the Cooks and Bakers School in Bayonne, N.J."
Having given up on finding a cover, he stirred the pasta. "Since I cooked for Sinatra, it's been 35 years," he said, suddenly looking a little self-conscious. "Relax, sweetheart, look around." The walls of the apartment were covered with pictures of Sinatra and his parents, Dean Martin, Marilyn Monroe, the Rat Pack. And one very peculiar head shot near the dining room table: "To George, Wishing you the very best, Mia."
He keeps a picture of the woman who danced him into unemployment? He nodded. "I had no idea it was a sin what I did," he said, "but it became an embarrassment to Mr. S. that on the night of his divorce I was dancing with his ex-wife. Hell, she was like one of my children. I got shoes older than her."
Through her manager, Judy Hofflund, Farrow said: "I have only the best feelings about George Jacobs. He is a wonderful man. George was dismissed after Frank and I broke up, and his dismissal had nothing to do with me."
Stadiem agreed. "Frank flew into one of his rages, and that was it," he said. "It certainly wasn't her fault."
With the pasta finally cooked, Jacobs settled at the square dining-room table he had bought at Goodwill. It was neatly set, with a green salad, grated cheese and a bottle of Kraft Zesty Italian dressing. There was also a bowl of one of Sinatra's favorite dishes: canned spinach tossed with olive oil, topped with chopped raw onions. "He likes it cold like that," Jacobs said. As people tend to do with their better days behind them, he loses track of his tenses. "The oil helped his throat," he went on. "He liked thin steaks, thin sandwiches. He ate very small portions. An egg for breakfast, lightly turned over with soft bacon."
Sinatra proved to be as provincial an eater as he was picky. When he traveled to Italy, he shunned restaurant cuisine, eating only the Italian food from New Jersey that Jacobs cooked in the hotel suite. And in Paris, when Sinatra went to the famed La Tour d'Argent, he had a steak and a cup of tea. He preferred Campbell's Pork & Beans straight from the can; Jacobs stocked up at Fauchon.
"He liked good food, not fancy," Jacobs said in his defense. "I miss him so much, man, it's frightening. I think about him all the time." Although both of his guests ate Jacobs's food hungrily (canned spinach excepted), he didn't eat a bite. He was clearly in pain, both from his back and his memories, and it took a few hours of talking and drinking for him to grow calm again.
One topic that can still amuse him is his employer before Sinatra, the agent Irving (Swifty) Lazar. As Jacobs tells the story, Lazar was fond of caviar, if not its price tag, and he had no interest in cultivating Jacobs's taste for it. "Blacks can't digest caviar," Lazar told him. "It gives them gout." Jacobs, who could digest caviar just fine, got in the practice of carrying a spoon with him to Nate 'n Al, the Beverly Hills deli where Lazar bought his supply. "I would eat some, and when he asked what happened, I told him they must have done it at the store," Jacobs recalled, laughing.
Jacobs is a good storyteller, and a few times a month, he appears at Sinatra's original Palm Springs house on Alejo Road to talk to tour groups about his former life. (The house's owner has an arrangement with a local events company.)
"I say, 'Ask any questions you want,"' Jacobs said, though discretion does not always seem the better part of his valor. He could barely conceal his contempt for Frank Sinatra Jr., who, in a recent interview about Jacobs's book and its gossipy contents with the Palm Springs newspaper The Desert Sun, said, "I haven't seen him in 40 years," adding, "I hope it's another 40 years before I see him."
Jacobs snorted. "That kid had nothing to do with me, and I had nothing to do with him," he said. "He thinks he's a singer. He thought he could be his father, and he wasn't."
Referring to the separate living arrangements that Sinatra maintained with his ex-wife Nancy and their three children, Nancy Jr., Frank Jr. and Tina, Jacobs said: "You had to be in his house to know what was going on. I had nothing to do with any of them kids. They only called when they needed me to help serve dinner or do the dishes, anything they didn't want to do. And that Tina was so snappy. She must have been 14, and I was driving her to school, in my white jacket, dressed like a servant, and the police stopped me. She said real loud, 'Tell him who you work for, George.' After that I said, 'Mr. S., I don't want to pick Tina up anymore."'
In his book, Jacobs writes about Sinatra's penchant for pulling practical jokes: on tour in Israel, Jacobs woke up one morning to find his employer and the rest of his entourage gone, leaving him with no money or plane ticket home.
That's funny?
Jacobs shrugged. "It didn't bother me," he said. "He always pulled those kinds of jokes if he'd been drinking or something. I admired this man, I had a good job, and I was well paid. And after I was fired, you can't believe the people who turned on me."
It would be 10 years before Jacobs saw Sinatra again, at Don the Beachcomber, a Palm Springs restaurant. "It's hard to talk about it," he said, choking up. As he wrote: "I took one look at him and broke down into tears. I couldn't stop crying. Mr. S put his arm around me. 'Forget about it, kid,' he said. 'It isn't so bad."' Although Jacobs kept crying, Sinatra left.
"My heart hurt," Jacobs said now, wiping his eyes with a paper napkin. "It was such a shock, it tore me apart. You have to understand, I spent 24 hours a day with him. I washed his underwear by hand on the road, I carried everything to take care of him, and it ended in such a miserable way. The way it was supposed to be, I guess. That was his way." He shook his head. "I danced with Ava and Marilyn and Rosalind Russell, too. I always wore a suit and tie, I wasn't a bum off the street." His tone was still baffled.
Stadiem, who has heard some version of this story possibly 1,000 times, nodded with the automatic yet genuine sympathy of a veteran bartender. "Any other day, George," he said gently, "you could have danced with Mia, and it wouldn't have mattered. Any other day." That might not be true at all -- Sinatra never mentioned Jacobs in any interviews -- though hearing it said seemed to placate him. He nodded. "I lived over it. I'm still here. Two wives divorced me for all the time I spent with him. But that was my life." 
After Sinatra fired him, Jacobs worked for Steve McQueen, George Hamilton and Bill Cosby, though he never lived in with anyone again. "They all thought I had Sinatra's phone book, it drove me crazy," he said. "I took off to Europe, disappeared for about three years."
When he returned, he took a stab at show business, appearing on "The Dating Game" and singing on "The Gong Show." Eventually, he moved to Van Nuys, Calif., and became a carpenter. He married a third time (and was divorced a third time) and had two daughters, now teenagers, with whom he remains close. Of his six other children, one son died of a heart attack, a daughter was murdered, and another son committed suicide.
Sinatra died in 1998, and Jacobs said that Barbara Marx, the final Mrs. Sinatra, cut him from the funeral's guest list. Though the two didn't marry until 1976, Sinatra had known her for years. Jacobs remembered asking him what he saw in her. "Grace Kelly with my eyes closed," was his answer.
Jacobs takes solace in believing that Dolly Sinatra, who continued to see him in spite of her son's banishment, hated Sinatra's last wife as much as he does. "She would tell me, 'He was better off with you than her,"' Jacobs recalled. He said that Dolly disliked her daughter-in-law so much that in January 1977, she demanded that a separate plane take her to Sinatra's Caesars Palace concert in Las Vegas. It crashed on takeoff and killed her.
"All things considered, I got away clear," Jacobs said, draining his drink. "I enjoyed my stay. I had more fun on the game than I did off." His smile ran deep with satisfaction. "And they were the best years of his life, too." 

Chicken Vesuvius
Sinatra Style
13 1/2-pound chicken, cut into eighths
4 or 5 small red potatoes (about 3 ounces each)
1 small red bell pepper
1 small red onion
1 small white onion
1 teaspoon crushed red pepper flakes
Salt and pepper to taste
Minced fresh parsley for garnish.
1. Preheat the oven to 425 degrees. Place the chicken into a 13-by-9-inch baking dish. 
2. Quarter the potatoes. Seed the bell pepper and cut it into 8 pieces. Quarter the onions through the root ends. 
3. Add the vegetables to the chicken and sprinkle with pepper flakes, salt and pepper, and toss to coat. Smooth out the vegetables, and make sure the chicken pieces are skin side up. Bake until the chicken is browned and the skin is crisp, about 40 minutes. Poke holes in the chicken skin so the juices flow. Stir so the vegetables are glazed. Continue baking until the vegetables are tender and the chicken is cooked through, about 20 minutes longer. 
4. Arrange on a serving platter and spoon the juices on top. Sprinkle with parsley.
Yield: 4 to 6 servings.

Sinatra's Spinach
Sinatra loved this dish because it isn't fattening and he believed the olive oil was good for his voice.

1 (1-pound) can whole-leaf spinach
3 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil
1/4 cup finely chopped red onion or other mild onion.
1. Drain the spinach and place in a serving dish. Drizzle with the oil and toss to coat. Sprinkle with the onion.
Yield: 4 servings.

Dolly Sinatra's
Marinara Sauce
This amount is for 1 pound of pasta.

1/2 cup olive oil
1 small onion, finely chopped
3 garlic cloves, finely chopped
1 (28-ounce) can crushed tomatoes with puree
1 sprig fresh oregano, finely chopped
1 teaspoon dried basil, crumbled
1 teaspoon Italian seasoning, crumbled
Salt and pepper to taste.
1. Heat the oil in a large saucepan over medium-high heat. Add the onion and cook, stirring, until tender, about 5 minutes. Add the garlic and cook, stirring, until the oil is fragrant and is seasoned, about 2 minutes. Stir in the tomatoes, and puree. Heat to simmering, and cook on low heat until the sauce thickens, about 20 minutes.
2. Add the oregano, basil and Italian seasoning, and mix well. Season with salt and pepper. Cook on low heat for another 15 minutes or so as it thickens.
Yield: 4 servings. 
Note: Jacobs served these dishes with a green salad topped with sliced tomatoes, a bottle of Kraft Zesty Italian dressing and sliced Italian bread.

HEADLINE: THEATER; 
Julia Jordan Beats the Odds, Then Beats Them Again

BYLINE:  By JASON ZINOMAN

 BODY:
THE Knicks winning the N.B.A. title. Halley's comet shooting through the sky. An unknown female playwright receiving four New York productions in one year. Some things just don't happen very often, and when they do they can provoke a certain surprise.
 The playwright Julia Jordan understands this better than most. She knows that getting produced once, or even twice, means you have beaten the odds. And if it happens three or, as is the case with Ms. Jordan, four times, jealous peers will suspect you sold your soul to the Devil. 
 "Tatjana in Color," which opened last Thursday at the Culture Project in the East Village, is the third of Ms. Jordan's plays to open in five months. The first two were over the summer: "St. Scarlet," about a dysfunctional family, at the Ontological Theater at St. Marks Church and "The Summer of the Swans," an adaptation of a young-adult novel by Betsy Byars and Ms. Jordan's second Theaterworks/USA production. (She also wrote the book to the 2002 musical "Sarah, Plain and Tall.") In April, Ms. Jordan will make it a quartet when Primary Stages presents "Boy."
"I suppose that some playwrights must hate me," Ms. Jordan said recently, looking melancholy in the SoHo restaurant Lucky Strike, where she once worked as a manager to make ends meet. "It's weird. I feel a little guilty."
In a telephone interview, David Auburn, the author of the play "Proof" and a friend of Ms. Jordan's, said: "I think that's crazy. She's paid her dues like nobody's business."
Indeed, before she started getting her telephone calls returned by producers, Ms. Jordan, who is in her 30's ("that's all I'll say"), struggled through an awkward series of post-college careers. After graduating from Barnard, she worked as an actor ("didn't have the talent for it"), a painter ("mediocre") and a copywriter for CNN ("I was good . . . I hated it"). "I was unemployable except as a waitress or a manager," Ms. Jordan said. 
Eventually, she decided to take her mother's advice and become a writer. She wrote her first play to complete an application for the Juilliard playwriting program in 1995. The play is about two girls hanging out under a railroad bridge and flirting with an older man. It never made it to the stage but it did get her into school, and she returned to this romantic dynamic again.
At Juilliard, Ms. Jordan made invaluable connections. Christopher Durang and Marsha Norman were her teachers, and Ms. Jordan's precocious class included Stephen Belber ("Tape") and Mr. Auburn. All four playwrights have been influences, and they formed the beginnings of Ms. Jordan's vast artistic social circle.
"Julia is one of those people who knows everyone in the scene," Mr. Auburn said. "She is the connective tissue for many theater artists." While Ms. Jordan is far too self-conscious to be a name-dropper, she counts Jesse Peretz, a musician and film director, and the playwrights Stephen Adly Guirgis and Lucy Thurber among her good friends.
Once she graduated, Ms. Jordan was chosen for a yearlong residency at the Manhattan Theater Club and saw her second play, "Tatjana in Color," anthologized in "Women Playwrights: The Best Plays of 1997." Still, the offers to produce her plays did not roll in.
This was a difficult period for Ms. Jordan. She was often broke, and endured a three-year writer's block. "I doubted myself and thought I wasn't good enough to be a writer," she said.
No producer would touch "Tatjana in Color." The problem, Ms. Jordan assumed, was its sexual subject matter. Set in 1912, the play is loosely based on the real-life relationship between the Austrian Expressionist painter Egon Schiele and a 12-year-old named Tatjana. When her father discovered that his daughter had been the subject of nude portraits, Schiele was accused of statutory rape.
"There are a lot of stories about an artist who bends the rules sexually and artistically," Ms. Jordan said. "In this story, what caught my eye was that she testified, but not against him. That takes guts. Tatjana is not a victim. If she was, the play would have had a message and it probably would have had an easier time getting produced."
For her next play, Ms. Jordan set out to write something commercial. ("What's the point of writing shows if they don't get produced?" she asks.) This new work would have one set, a naturalistic living room and kitchen, and, she emphasized, "no naked girls." The result was "St. Scarlet," her breakout drama. 
Set in Minnesota, where Ms. Jordan was brought up, the play follows three quarreling sisters on an extraordinary snowbound day. In The New York Times, Bruce Weber wrote an encouraging review: "Ms. Jordan understands how much it takes to fill a stage with a play's worth of material, and that her 'wrighting' skills are ahead of her life experiences. She's a storyteller; wait'll she grows her own stories." 
While Ms. Jordan has shown an impressive ability to work in different genres, she has consistently returned to the same theme: the awakening sexuality of a young girl. 
Asked about this preoccupation of Ms. Jordan's, Mr. Belber replied in an e-mail message: "At the risk of sounding foolishly analytical, Julia's incredibly well suited to take on the tricky task of young girls exploring sexuality. She came to New York right out of high school with classic, Midwestern values hitched to the desire to push a couple envelopes and see where it all led."
The need to push envelopes began earlier. When she was 15, she scared her parents by pursuing a 25-year-old man. "I'd be out all night and my mom and dad wouldn't get much sleep," she said. "It was all very glamorous." Did she finally get him? "No comment."
In "Boy," however, Ms. Jordan departs for the first time from that subject matter. She described the new play as "about people trying to write happy endings to the stories they live and tell."
With positive reviews for "St. Scarlet" and "The Summer of the Swans," Ms. Jordan has started thinking about her future. Asked whose theatrical career she would most like to have, she laughed and said, "Tennessee Williams without the alcoholism."

HEADLINE: HOLIDAY MOVIES; 
A Mom-and-Pop Shop for Animation That Married Art and Life

BYLINE:  By STUART KLAWANS; Stuart Klawans is the film critic for The Nation.

 BODY:
LIKE elves puttering in a cottage in some latter-day fairy tale, John and Faith Hubley made films by hand, then carted their wares to market -- and won Oscars for them. 
 Seven times, from 1960 through 1978, animated films by the Hubleys received Academy Award nominations. Three times the Hubleys won, gaining fame as the first successful mom-and-pop operation in an otherwise industrial field. 
 As John knew from his years at the Walt Disney studio, many hours of assembly-line labor are normally required to create a few seconds of animated magic. The Hubleys' films were labor-intensive, too, but the work was never regimented. 
Sybil DelGaudio's admiring, hourlong documentary "Independent Spirits: Faith Hubley/John Hubley" reminds us of how abnormal those methods were. And four short films by the Hubleys that are being screened with the documentary provide an introduction to their inimitable artisanal messiness -- which looks as startlingly free today, in our era of computer-generated imagery, as it did back when "Lady and the Tramp" was the norm. This small Hubley sampler, opening on Nov. 28, also helps to suggest why their blots and smears of color, their pulsing lines and infinitely pliable shapes, were precisely right for the subjects at hand.
Their very first joint production, "Adventures of an *" (1957), celebrates their own escape from regimentation, embodying the postwar decade's worst fears about itself in the figure of an office worker who spends his days pulling papers from an overflowing file cabinet and stamping them robotically. To some viewers, this satire of social conformity may seem to choose an easy target -- but the Hubleys had earned the right to aim at it.
John Hubley, a draftsman of wizardlike facility, had lost his job at the Walt Disney studio in the bitter strike of 1941. Following his wartime service, he got back into the animation business by helping to found United Productions of America (UPA), a distinctly non-Disney outfit where the boldly simplified drawings were all loops and the content all crotchety angles. UPA got off to a strong start -- especially with the figure of Mr. Magoo, whom Hubley helped to develop -- but soon ran into trouble from the House Committee on Un-American Activities. When it was Hubley's turn to testify, he refused to name names; and so, like many other filmmakers of the period, he became independent by becoming unemployable, with the assistance of the committee.
Faith Elliott Hubley needed no such help. A child of Hell's Kitchen who had dropped out of high school, she learned about life on the streets, at the New York Public Library and in the galleries of the Museum of Modern Art. Her love of movies eventually took her to Los Angeles, where she found work at Columbia and Republic and was trained as an editor, over the initial objections of their all-male staffs.
Los Angeles gave Faith not only a trade but also a lifelong companion. She met John Hubley on Hollywood Boulevard, toward the end of World War II. With an artist's eye for the characteristic feature and a rebel's robust self-esteem, she recalled seeing his face as one big toothy smile, while thinking, "Hey, somebody who looks like me." The friendship was immediate; the decision to marry took 10 years. Why the delay? Perhaps a part of the answer may be found in the Hubleys' 1958 film "The Tender Game," with its portrait of two shy and gawky people courting in a park.
With the arrival of their children, the Hubleys got another topic for film and eventually their first Academy Award as well. They recorded the kids talking, then used the ramblings as a soundtrack for their illustrations -- in the 1959 "Moonbird" (their original Oscar winner) and subsequently in "Windy Day" (1968) and "Cockaboody" (1974). People from outside the family were also welcome to contribute an improvised soundtrack, provided they were vivid enough, like Dizzy Gillespie. The Hubleys worked with Gillespie several times, using him both for his music and for his multidirectional talk -- the best of which may be heard in the Oscar-winning "The Hole" (1962), a two-character film about construction workers pondering the likelihood of nuclear war.
Militarism, feminism, overpopulation, urban blight: these were just a few of the topics that the Hubleys made fanciful, entertaining and eye-catching. "They could take on anything as subject matter," notes the film historian John Canemaker in "Independent Spirits." "They seemed to be limitless in terms of their daring." Given the back-and-forth nature of their partnership, it's not surprising that the Hubleys conceived many of these films as dialogues. You're always listening in on a conversation -- between Father Time and Mother Earth, Life and Death, little Emily Hubley and Georgia Hubley and, ultimately, between John and Faith themselves.
That last, long-running conversation came to an end with John's death in 1977. From then until her own death in 2001, Faith made films on her own, in a style that combined her old Museum of Modern Art favorites, Paul Klee and Joan Miro, with influences from tribal traditions throughout the world. If her solo films lacked some of the fluidity of her pictures with John, as well as the saving whimsy, they fulfilled her ambition of working simply and solely as an artist. The reason she disliked the term "animation," she said, was that it referred not to the film itself but to a craft that went into its making. During her last decades she consistently looked beyond that craft to draw and paint films about whatever was important to her.
This conviction, that a tool is just a tool, may be an especially valuable legacy of the Hubleys, now that so many people are dazzled by the possibilities of computer animation. Digital tools can be used to produce the immaculately rendered, highly modeled images that audiences now associate with animation. (Some of the results, as in "Finding Nemo," are very good, and others not so terrific.) But the computer is also useful for other, more artisanal-looking work -- the blobby yellow "Simpsons," for example, or the paper-doll figures of "South Park."
Maybe these later cartoons lack the painterly sophistication of "Tender Game" or "The Hole" -- but they are animated, in the true sense, by something like the Hubleys' cheerfully renegade spirit.

HEADLINE: PRELUDES; 
Reality Television Vs. Real Careers

BYLINE:  By ABBY ELLIN; Abby Ellin is a Manhattan writer. E-mail: preludes@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
IT'S a shame that reality television as we know it didn't exist when I was getting my start as a journalist in the early 1990's.
 I might have sent a tape of myself to a show like "Extreme Makeover," "Jackass" or "Road Rules," or maybe even allowed a Webcamto follow me around in my apartment while I vacuumed or put on my makeup. 
 Granted, many competitors on these shows seem to view themselves as just one break away from megastardom. But a few young people are using reality television and advertising to prod their careers along in this sluggish economy. 
 Cary Williams-Nunez, 29, the owner of Prime Time Boxing, a fitness gym in Sacramento, says business has been up by about 40 percent since she appeared as a contestant on "Fear Factor" this year. Never mind that she had to devour a bull's snout, spinal cord and spleen on national television as part of the competition. The attention she received made it worthwhile. 
 "My whole purpose was to get publicity to promote the business," Ms. Williams-Nunez said, adding that she didn't train at all for her culinary experience. "As soon as I knew it would air, I was in all the local media and I got inundated with calls." She has done so well that she is releasing a boxing DVD; she has even hired a publicist. 
 Some reality shows appear to be trying to capitalize on the difficult economy and job market. Consider, for example, "The Million Dollar Idea," now in its second season on KSTC, an independent television station in Minneapolis. The premise is this: Inventors, mostly in their late 20's and early 30's, compete for $50,000 worth of advertising, marketing and design services (in addition to the invaluable television exposure). Viewers choose the winner.
 "In a time of downsizing, people are becoming very entrepreneurial," said Todd Walker, who created the show with his best friend from high school, Jean Golden. "We wondered: What form could we give them to present their product to the marketplace, and to offer them a prize package that would then allow them to turn their dream into a reality?" 
 Then there is "The Apprentice," scheduled to be broadcast next year on NBC. The show was created by Mark Burnett, who also invented "Survivor." But instead of competing in the wilds of the Amazon, contestants struggle in the business jungle. The grand prize is a one-year position as a president or co-president of a division of the Trump Organization. Donald Trump, the company's president and chairman, is the host of the show. 
 Not everyone who auditioned for it had visions of owning skyscrapers and hotels. "My primary motivation was the thought that if I were to make it to the show, it would benefit me in terms of name recognition," said Eric P. Strauss, 31, a founder of City Date Connection, a dating service in Minneapolis, who made it to the second round of tryouts. "Reality TV is really changing how people are able to promote themselves and their businesses."
 Roz Dunn, a real estate broker and bartender in Manhattan, said she feels the same way. Ms. Dunn, 24, competed in the Miss Rheingold contest sponsored by the Rheingold Brewing Company. Nearly 300 women applied for the chance to win $10,000 and have their picture plastered on billboards. Ms. Dunn said she used the contest "as a trampoline to get to the next level." She said she eventually wants to run her own music club.
 ANTHONY MORA, a Los Angeles publicist and author of "Spin to Win" (Hawk Publishing), is a bit more pessimistic about the effects of reality TV in general on careers. The chances of being discovered through the shows, he says, are slim.
 "The chances are much greater that they'll be humiliated" by a show's outlandish requirements, said Mr. Mora, whose clients include Ms. Williams-Nunez. She was unique, he said, because she wanted only to promote her business. In most cases, he added, "Putting the camera on you and turning it on isn't going to change your life." 
 He may be right, but that won't stop people from trying. I am thinking about creating and, of course, competing in a show for writers, called "The Scoop." Eight fledgling reporters will vie to unearth a big story, then report it on live television. The winner gets a chance to write an article about himself or herself in a national magazine. 
 If that doesn't push my career into high gear, nothing will.
