HEADLINE: Executive Life; 
Fear of Technology, Quietly Conquered

BYLINE:  By CHRISTOPHER S. STEWART

 BODY:
THEY meet in crowded bookstores or public libraries, where anonymity is guaranteed. For sessions at work, they settle in behind closed doors, typically early in the morning or after hours.
 Yes, when an executive finally learns how to work a computer, secrecy can be crucial. 
 Over the years, many of these executives managed to put off computer training. But they have reconsidered as computers have become an unavoidable part of the business world. Rather than face derision from colleagues -- or worse, appear obsolete -- some are seeking out teachers and coaches who can educate them on the sly. 
 "It's a lot like those people who were illiterate in the work force years ago and talked very secretly about learning to read," said John A. Challenger, chief executive of Challenger, Gray & Christmas, the outplacement firm. "In the past, it was a point of pride to say you didn't buy into technology. But now it's our life, and the late adopters really feel guilty about it."
 One trainer of executives, Jennifer Shaheen, says that many of them ask her to tutor them clandestinely. "I call myself a 'tech therapist' because so many business people want to be taught in confidence," said Ms. Shaheen, who charges $300 a session, which generally last an hour. "What I do is a lot like therapy -- the getting over the fear of technology and being embarrassed."
 More than half of Ms. Shaheen's 20 executive-level clients (she will not offer many names) request some degree of confidentiality. She describes the training sessions -- covering fundamentals like setting up a computer and sending e-mail messages, as well as more advanced software issues like putting together a PowerPoint presentation -- as resembling some sort of cloak-and-dagger enterprise. Usually she contacts her clients by cellphone or on private lines and meets them before work or at night or at their homes over the weekends.
 One executive at a national transportation company asked her to work with him at a Barnes & Noble bookstore in New Jersey until they decided there were too many people around and moved to a private room at a nearby public library. "He showed up with a laptop that he'd just gotten and said, 'What do I do?"' Ms. Shaheen recalled. Another man, who "didn't know what the right mouse button did," instructed her that if anyone asked about her visits to help him, she should say she was "just a consultant for the company."
 While statistics are hard to come by for how many executives are untrained in using computers, Andrew Sherwood, chairman and chief executive of Goodrich & Sherwood, an outplacement firm in New York City, said he thought the number was substantial.
 "You'd be surprised how many don't knowanything," said Mr. Sherwood, who estimated that more than 75 percent of his clients lacked basic computer skills. "A lot of these executives work 16-plus hours a day and they've never had time to get into computers or had very skilled administrators working for them. They tend to fudge their computer skills, and just smile." 
 Among those caught in the learning gap are executives who previously had two or more assistants managing all their computer work, from sending and receiving e-mail messages to typing proposals and correspondence. As companies started cutting the size of their work forces in a sluggish economy, some executives were left stranded without such help. 
 Ann Rose, the president of Montville Carpet and Flooring in Montville, N.J., said that until a few months ago, she had relied on others to do her computer work. But she decided that she was in danger of becoming outdated and chose private tutoring at the Career Center, a career and management firm in Manhattan that specializes in technology-related work. "I didn't want anyone to know at first," said Ms. Rose, who is 54. "The fact that I missed the boat on computers, it's embarrassing. Particularly when the young ones come in and know everything. It's a way of life with them."
 The difficult job market has made more executives aware of their tech shortcomings. But a fear of being discovered, and stigmatized, is driving many executives underground for help, said Debbie Ringler, a founder and vice president of the Career Center. "Many of them are scared of being exposed," she said. "Some of their staff is leaving, and they don't have the skills to pick up the slack. Or they're looking for a new job and don't have the most fundamental computer skills to make the leap."
 MS. RINGLER recalled one executive who was sent to her by his company to learn a specific program. In fact, the executive knew nothing about computers, so instead of studying the program, he used the time to learn skills like word processing, spreadsheets and navigating the Internet. He made her promise not to give up their secret, she said.
 Dan Kenyon, corporate sales manager at ExecuTrain, an international training firm, said it did very little teaching that was truly secretive.
 Still, he said, "most of the executives that come in prefer privacy." Mr. Kenyon's company has tutored about 100 executives in the New York metropolitan area this year, a slight increase from previous years. "It's not a surprise," he said of the abundance of executives who need to be taught the basics. "It's more of a giggle."
 Some relatively self-reliant -- and guarded -- executives are turning to tutoring programs that run on a computer. One is the Video Professor, a suite of computer CD's that allow users to learn everything from Windows to Lotus 1-2-3 to PhotoShop at their own desks, by themselves.
 Still, secrecy can be hard to maintain. Michael Gallin, vice president of one of the oldest building contractors in New York, John Gallin & Sons, brought Ms. Shaheen to the office for secret instruction on using e-mail and mobile technology, like a personal digital assistant.
 "We started out with her as a regular visitor," said Mr. Gallin, who is 46. "She didn't make any noise."
 But eventually, he said, "people started to ask questions and the cat was out of the bag."
 "So I told them, 'She's here teaching me the computer and she's great,"' he added. "'You should all try her out."'

HEADLINE: New Malaysian Leader's Style Stirs Optimism 

BYLINE:  By JANE PERLEZ

DATELINE: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Nov. 1 

 BODY:
The new prime minister of Malaysia, Abdullah Badawi, a consummate diplomat abroad and well connected to the Islamic community at home, cuts an entirely different image from his volatile predecessor, Mahathir Mohamad. Mr. Abdullah is popularly known here as "Mr. Nice Guy," an endearment that could hardly be conferred on Dr. Mahathir. 
 But the new leader's basic policies are likely to provide a continuum for a prosperous nation that survived the Asian economic crisis better than most and is headed for nearly 5 percent growth this year, analysts said. 
 Mr. Abdullah, 63, comes from a patrician family on Penang, the island that is the base for the technology firms, including Dell and Intel, that provided the exports for Malaysia's economic success in the 1990's. One of his main challenges will be how to keep Malaysia competitive as China becomes the fulcrum for low-cost manufacturing in the region, and India becomes a base for cheap back-office services.
A former foreign minister and defense minister, Mr. Abdullah wasted no time in sizing up the competition from China. In preparation for taking power, and in recognition of the fact that China has become Malaysia's fastest growing trading partner, he visited Beijing several months ago. 
At the same time, he is well regarded by American officials, who say he is unlikely to repeat the anti-Western and anti-Semitic remarks of Dr. Mahathir.
"The different style of leadership provides a firm foundation for turning a new page in U.S.-Malaysia relations," said Ernest Z. Bower, the president of the U.S.-Asean Business Council, a group of major American companies with investments in Southeast Asia. "There are clear signals from both the administration in Washington and the American private sector on the value of not prejudicing America's future relations with Malaysia and the new prime minister based on the past." 
One of Mr. Abdullah's strengths appears to be the way he combines the traditional values of Islam with a modern outlook. His father and grandfather were religious leaders, and Mr. Abdullah graduated from the University of Malaya with a degree in Islamic studies. 
"The religious leaders had a loathing for Mahathir -- he was too secular for them," said Karim Raslan, a Malaysian writer and lawyer. "But they can't write Badawi off." 
For that reason, leaders of the governing party, the United Malays National Organization, believe that Mr. Abdullah will be able to retrieve some of the ground the party lost in the last election in 1999 to the conservative Islamic party known as PAS. 
Some of the swing away from the governing party was attributed to Dr. Mahathir's prosecution and jailing of his former deputy, Anwar Ibrahim, and to allegations of cronyism within the party. Mr. Abdullah has made clear his distaste for some of the mega-infrastructure projects of the Mahathir era, including the extravagant new political capital, Purajaya. His reputation for clean government and his interest in rural development could help bring back some voters who fled to the Islamic party, the analysts said. 
But Mr. Abdullah will not be making crass appeals to the conservative Islamic forces, they said. His wife, Endon Mahmood, projects herself as a modern Muslim woman who appears in public without covering her head. Ms. Endon started a campaign, "Sisters in Islam," that encourages monogamy as an ideal for religious Muslims. 
On his first day in office, the new prime minister ignored the ultra-modern capital here and traveled to his home village, Kepala Batas, to see his mother and to break the Ramadan fast with his family. Festive signs along the homecoming route greeted him as Pak Lah, an affectionate diminutive of Abdullah, meaning "Uncle Lah," a far cry from the correct titles given to his predecessor.

HEADLINE: Ex-Guatemalan Rebel Tries Her Hand at Democracy 

BYLINE:  By DAVID GONZALEZ

DATELINE: ESCUINTLA, Guatemala 

 BODY:
Makrina Gudiel gave up her identity to survive. 
 As a teenager who accepted neither a woman's place in this macho society nor Guatemala's military government, she grabbed a rifle, embraced the nom de guerre Ana and joined the guerrillas. 
 Worn down by combat, she spent five years in exile in the United States, protected by the so-called sanctuary movement organized by Americans protesting United States policy in Central America during the civil wars of the 1980's. 
But she is hiding no more. Now she is a congressional candidate of the Guatemalan National Revolutionary Unity in elections being held on Nov. 9. The rebels founded the party after peace accords in 1996 ended the country's 36-year civil war. 
Ms. Gudiel welcomes campaigning openly in a land no longer at war. But it is far from peace: poverty is rampant, society is polarized and men with guns linger at the fringes of her campaign stops. Like a flashback, even Gen. Efrain Rios Montt, who presided over the counterinsurgency when Ms. Gudiel was with the rebels, is running for president. 
"The conditions that brought us to war are still present," she said. "Those who massacred us are still there. Friends and family tell me to be careful. Don't say much. Guard your life." 
She was born 40 years ago in a society that was highly protective of women. But despite her father's teachings that spouses were equal and indigenous people deserved respect, local life showed otherwise. Men staggered home drunk and beat their wives, and Mayan girls in their long woven skirts were shunned in public. By her teenage years, she knew something had to change.
"I did not like the life that women had," she said. "It was grow up, get married and have children. I wanted more."
Not long after her brother, Jose Miguel, announced that he was joining the rebels in the mountains, she followed, spending a year with the guerrillas and taking part in raids. The time with the guerrillas was not easy, she said, and it rattled her nerves so badly that she was sent into exile with another rebel who would father their three children. 
Contacts in Mexico put her in touch with the sanctuary movement in Arizona, which smuggled her into the United States. Still calling herself Ana and hiding behind a kerchief, she and her family wound up living in the tower of Riverside Church in Manhattan, one floor below the huge bells. 
The sanctuary movement had established itself among liberal religious groups opposed to the American government's aid to Central American armies that committed numerous human rights abuses while combating leftist rebels. The American government said the asylum seekers were economic refugees, at best.
For the next year or so, Ms. Gudiel and her companion, who had taken the name Federico, gave talks about the war and helped arrange for others to come to the United States to give testimony at the United Nations. While her audiences were sympathetic to her stories of military oppression, she did not touch on her own time fighting in the mountains. 
"My North American brothers did not look well on the decision the people of Guatemala took in rising up when there was no rule of law," she said. "For North Americans, a guerrilla war is incomprehensible unless they have lived through it." 
Such an admission might have complicated the often romantic view held by some people that Ms. Gudiel and her family were innocents caught between armies. 
"They simply didn't tell us very much and we didn't want to know," said Mary Ann Lundy, who helped her. "We were much more concerned about people not being sent back. I don't apologize for not knowing." 
Ms. Gudiel's time in the United States -- about five years until 1989 when she returned to refugee camps in Mexico rather than flee farther north to Canada -- changed her. 
"To get to the United States was to breathe, to havehope," she said. "There I learned the responsibilities of civilians, that it was not enough to just go vote every four years. I learned you have rights, to study, to have a roof. To feel protected. I also learned to value what I had in Guatemala." 
Those lessons filter through her campaign. She is considered to have a shot at winning. She talks about how people have a right to know government budgets and a say in how the money is spent. When she talks about health care or school, it is not an abstraction: she is now a single mother raising three boys while keeping up a breakneck pace dashing to campaign stops in a pickup truck. 
At campaign rallies, grandmothers and teenage girls alike surround her. "She shows us we can get ahead," said Alejandra Ramirez, 56. "The government had for so long only used the hard hand against the people, so people got used to the harshness of guns and the military. Now it is changing a bit. Now women can protest this situation." 
Just not too much. Campaign consultants to Ms. Gudiel have suggested that she not speak about the war. 
"People in Guatemala do not believe in political parties, they only see people," she said. "And people do not want to hear anything about the war. I do not reject my past, but for the electoral struggle we do not need to mention it." 
The signs of her past were evident as she rode in a campaign caravan. Another candidate wore a bulletproof vest. On the street, wiry men with steely gazes, some with missing fingers, nodded at her like the former comrades in arms they once were. 
She would do it again, she said, even the hardship, the exile, the loss of friends and family.
"I could have been like a Guatemalan, get educated and do nothing," she said. "It is easy to ignore reality when you are ignorant. But when you know, then you have a commitment."

HEADLINE: The Neediest Cases; 
For Homeless, the Gift of Hope

BYLINE:  By ARTHUR BOVINO

 BODY:
Gloria Hernandez tries to be strong for her five children, but strength, like privacy or full stomachs, does not come easily when you and your family live in a shelter for the homeless. 
 "The children say, 'Mommy, when are we going to get out of here?' " Ms. Hernandez, 40, said softly, her eyes downcast. "You see it in their faces: they don't speak, but they show it. They say it's your fault." 
 For 10 years, Ms. Hernandez and her children lived in the same apartment in Corona, Queens. But what appeared stable was anything but. Ms. Hernandez said a new landlord wanted the apartment for himself. There were other units, she said, but her landlord said her family had "too many people." 
After more than two years of legal wrangling, Ms. Hernandez agreed last November to leave if her landlord gave her until the end of April to find a home.
"Every time I called to ask about apartments the answer was always 'No, no, no,' " said Ms. Hernandez. " 'We don't want no children. We don't want no programs from the city.' " 
So Ms. Hernandez and her family became a few more among New York City's more than 38,000 homeless. She learned about the crowding and unpleasantness of shelter life, along with the hardships of a hand-to-mouth existence.
But unlike so many others on the streets, she was fortunate to learn about something else: the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. 
The fund, whose annual campaign starts today and runs through Jan. 31, has been aiding and comforting New Yorkers in distress since 1912. The homeless, the gravely ill and the down and out: these are the people who have been aided by the fund, and by the seven New York charities it supports. 
For Ms. Hernandez, the fund gave her and her family a bit of needed stability, and hope.
Ms. Hernandez, a widow for 11 years, used to clean homes but lost her job when her employers moved. Now she stretches $231 in public assistance every two weeks and $350 in food stamps each month to raise her family. Without money to store their belongings, Ms. Hernandez faced losing everything. A friend suggested she call Catholic Charities, Diocese of Brooklyn and Queens, one of the fund's seven beneficiary agencies. There, her caseworker, Patricia Cadavid, secured $462 from the fund so the family could store their living room furniture and irreplaceable albums of baby pictures.
Ms. Hernandez and her children stayed with friends until it became too crowded in July, then went to the city's Emergency Assistance Unit in the Bronx. They spent four days at a Bronx shelter, in a small room that her youngest child, 9-year-old Jeffrey, still recalls. "The hotel was dirty and it had flies all over," he said. "There are nice places and bad places. The place we went to that night had big old rats."
Eventually, they were placed in a room at a shelter in an industrial part of the East New York section of Brooklyn. But the family is together, the children are in school. And in five months, they hope to be in a new apartment.
The small amount of money from the fund, along with the continuing support of Catholic Charities, gave them what many homeless people do not have: breathing room to sort out options and try to get back on their feet.
Today, more and more people are without that breathing room. According to the city's Department of Homeless Services, homelessness has climbed to record levels in New York this year. The peak was in May, when 38,660 people were homeless. On Thursday, 38,357 homeless men, women and children were sleeping in the shelter system. The Coalition for the Homeless, a court-appointed monitor of the city's shelters, said that figure was almost double the number five years ago. 
Many of the people behind those statistics have fallen victim to the same things: unemployment, an overloaded shelter system and a lack of affordable housing. "We have these two New Yorks," said Dr. John Ruskay, executive vice president and chief executive of the UJA-Federation of New York, another beneficiary of the fund. "One which is reasonably O.K., even in bad times, and looking forward to renewed prosperity. And we have another group of elderly and immigrants and large families who increasingly find themselves on the cusp of not being able to make it."
Though some people believe the economy shows signs of renewal, the homeless are not feeling a rush of optimism just yet. According to the coalition, the number of homeless single adults has increased by 33 percent since 1994, to 8,100 per night from 6,100.
The recent increase in overall numbers of sheltered homeless -- 38,463 in January 2002, up from 31,064 a year earlier, was the largest one-year increase since the Depression, the coalition said. And, earlier this year, Homeless Services counted another 1,780 people sleeping in streets and subway stations.
But if the situation appears dire to many, some have found help and hope through the fund. 
The fund serves people in all manner of distress. And, over the years, it has helped pay for all manner of needs -- from food and rent to furniture and health care. Last year, it raised over $8.8 million in donations, the second-highest amount in its nine-decade history.
Among the recipients -- those facing grave illness, sudden calamity, unanticipated loss -- the homeless occupy a special place, for it was a story of homelessness that inspired the fund's creation.
It happened on Christmas Day in 1911, when Adolph S. Ochs, the publisher of The New York Times, chanced upon a shabbily dressed beggar. The experience inspired Mr. Ochs to use his newspaper to help the poor.
He decided to publish their stories, hoping readers would feel compassion for fellow New Yorkers. 
In 1912, the fund's first year, there were 117 contributions, totaling $3,630.88. In its 92 years, it has raised over $136 million. This is in addition to the $62 million raised by a related fund for those affected by the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attack. The Times pays the fund's expenses, so all contributions go directly to the charities, which use them to provide services and cash assistance.
This year, the campaign has special significance as the fund has passed a milestone: Total donations since its inception have exceeded $200 million. Helping to open the campaign is an event tomorrow called Children at Risk: Protecting New York City's Youths, 1653-2003, at the New-York Historical Society.
Mr. Ochs's great-grandson, Arthur Sulzberger Jr., the current publisher of The Times, said that even as the newspaper has reached out to a broader national audience, the fund has remained important.
"We still have the 'New York' in our name," he said. "It speaks to the constancy of purpose -- we're in here for the long haul. This has been a part of us for a very long time. There are some things that you stay with year after year because they just work. And my goodness, does this work."
While the fund's mission has remained constant, the problems it has addressed have not.
Unemployment is way up, with 240,000 jobs lost in the city in the last three years alone, according to the Fiscal Policy Institute, a research group. Some 1.4 million New Yorkers are living below the federal poverty level.
And a recent study by the United Way shows another disturbing trend. Families with children are the largest and fastest-growing segment of the homeless. As of January 2002, 42 percent of people in shelters were children. According to the Coalition for the Homeless, the average length of time families spend in the shelter system is now 11 months, more than double the 1990 average.
Linda Gibbs, commissioner of homeless services, says that in the battle against homelessness, "It's not ultimately going to be about building more shelters. Our focus has to be much more on engaging communities in preventing people from becoming homeless."
A 110 percent increase in rental assistance resources has begun to help relocate homeless families, but Ms. Gibbs said that demand has continued to rise. She said there are two fundamental needs that need to be addressed. The first, she said, is "Whether there are resources for people to stay in housing if a family is in danger. And the second is, do we know who they are and where they are and how to help them before they become homeless."
With national welfare reform, public assistance caseloads have dropped sharply in New York. But people continue to live on the brink.
"In a good economy you can assume they got jobs," said Lilliam Barrios-Paoli, senior vice president and chief executive for agency services of the United Way in New York. "Things happen, you get ill, you have to go into the hospital and that wipes you out."
Aside from unemployment, there is also a shortage of new and affordable housing. According to the United Way, occupancy at the city's public housing developments exceeded 99 percent last year.
And then there are those who are on the brink of joining the city's homeless, as Latwanda Manson was last spring. Without the help she received from the fund, she said, she might have been in a shelter.
Ms. Manson, 34, a secretary for the State Health Department, lives in the same apartment building in the Bronx with her two children, Timara Manson, 13, and Taia Bell, 5, that she grew up in. 
Like Ms. Hernandez, Ms. Manson said she ran into trouble after a change of landlords. In February 2002, the new landlord began renovating the building. The family was relocated for four months. When they returned, they were told they were going to have to start paying for electricity. A few months later, Ms. Manson got the first bill: $649.
She juggled resources until she could not stretch her pay, $760 every two weeks, any further. Ms. Manson's salary is $30,000 a year, of which almost $7,000 goes to her $581.56 monthly rent. 
"You borrow from Peter to pay Paul and you hope you can pay Peter back," she said. 
In November, she was behind on her bills. In January, the landlord told her to pay the balance of over two months' rent or leave. The case was tied up in court for two months.
"The judge, the social workers try to give you resources, but when you go to those, the resources are at its limit," she said. "Many days I would come out of that courthouse with tears. I didn't want to go into the system or lose my home or lose the stability for my kids. I was scared." 
Ms. Manson was denied public assistance in February, but was given until June to pay the back rent. In May, she could not pay for Taia's child care and needed Timara to pick her up from school. Timara attends an after-school pregnancy prevention program at Intermediate School 90, run by the Children's Aid Society, another beneficiary of the fund. The staff members noticed that Timara was acting out and leaving early. Simone Oliver, a caseworker, called Ms. Manson to see if everything was O.K.
"When I first met Ms. Manson, her heart was heavy," said Ms. Oliver. "When I told her that I was going to be able to help her, she was a little skeptical." 
A week later, Ms. Oliver secured $1,297.34 from the fund for the rent, and the family averted disaster. 
"The hardest thing now is to keep food in the house," said Ms. Manson. "Because you don't want to fall behind on the rent." 
The fund was also there for Mary Strong, 55, a mother of three. She became homeless in October 2002 when her landlord had to sell the building she lived in in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn.
Ms. Strong stayed with friends and relatives for a month. A cousin took her daughters, Christen, 20, and Avis, 14, but there was not enough room for her.
"My son took me to the shelter. He has his own family so I couldn't stay with him," she said. "I was going through a lot; I was depressed and I ended up in the hospital." 
From 1978 to 1993, Ms. Strong had worked as an administrative assistant at the Legal Aid Society, where she made $34,000 a year. She liked her job and the salary was good. But she was laid off when the office was modernized with computers.
"Even though I was there for a long time, I was at the bottom of the list," she said. She looked for a comparable job and worked for temporary-work agencies. But there are unfortunate truths about temping: "The only thing about that is they don't last long." 
So she took whatever work she could find, cleaning houses and working as a bus matron for public schools in the Bronx. By the time she lost her home, things seemed hopeless, she said.
Now at the Transitional Living Community, a program run by the Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service at the Brooklyn Women's Shelter in East New York, Ms. Strong has a cot in a room with nine other women. She gets counseling at least once a week, one of the services provided by the bureau, another fund beneficiary. Ms. Strong receives $22.50 from public assistance every two weeks. It is barely enough to cover car fare to visit Avis; Christen, who works at Toys "R" Us to put herself through Berkeley College; or Ms. Strong's son, Willis Killebrew, 32.
Maritza Santos, Ms. Strong's caseworker, secured $800 from the fund, which Ms. Strong used to buy warm winter clothes for her and her daughters. Ms. Santos has also helped Ms. Strong apply for a housing subsidy and is helping to find her a permanent place to live.
In the meantime, Ms. Strong continues counseling and enjoys working in the shelter's garden, tending vegetables and flowers. She looks forward to more planting in the spring, though she would be happier to leave the shelter before then.
Though Ms. Strong's future remains uncertain, she, like Ms. Hernandez and Ms. Manson, is grateful for the boost -- financial and emotional -- that the fund provided. They, like so many past recipients, appreciate the compassion of those who are more fortunate, and fear where they might now be without it.
"Every day there are more people coming," Ms. Hernandez said of the Emergency Assistance Unit. "And it's a big place and it's a lot of people and they start fighting. I'm just hoping to have a place to stay, to be normal."

HEADLINE: AROUND THE MAJORS; 
Showalter Only Looks As Free Agency Nears

BYLINE:  By Jack Curry

 BODY:
Texas Manager Buck Showalter flipped through a list of free agents while sitting at his desk last week, reviewing dozens of players and circling those he thought the Rangers should try to sign. Reluctantly, but not surprisingly, Showalter breezed by the marquee players because their potential price tags would make them difficult fits for a team slashing its payroll.
 "I'm probably not highlighting the ones fans would be interested in," Showalter said. 
 So Showalter did not mark outfielders Vladimir Guerrero and Gary Sheffield or shortstop Miguel Tejada; he moved past the starting pitchers Bartolo Colon, Kevin Millwood and Andy Pettitte, who has not officially filed for free agency; and he avoided scribbling the names of relievers Ugueth Urbina, Keith Foulke and LaTroy Hawkins. 
They are all superb choices and Showalter would love to have several of them in a Rangers uniform next season.
But like numerous teams that have seen the Anaheim Angels and the Florida Marlins win the last two World Series championships on modest payrolls, the Rangers are thinking austerity and are trying to devise a winning plan thatis, most importantly, economically feasible.
The Rangers are listening to offers for Alex Rodriguez, who still has $179 million left on his $252 million contract, and the Boston Red Sox put Manny Ramirez on irrevocable waivers Wednesday in hopes that some team would claim him and the $104 million remaining on his $160 million deal.
Obviously, those teams feel constrained by the contracts and would rather have the surplus of $20 million a year to add several critical pieces, not lavish it on one player.
"I think the very long-term contracts have proven to be very, very risky and we'd be concerned about very long contracts," said Fred Wilpon, the Mets' owner, essentially telling fans not to expect Guerrero in right field at Shea Stadium next season.
When the free-agent auction starts in nine days, most teams, one baseball executive said, will not be as eager to "be the first to strike" on players anymore and will want to be "cautious and not outbid themselves." Mets General Manager Jim Duquette said he expected the process to be slow-moving while teams judged how the market was developing and what they could afford.
Still, Billy Beane, the general manager of the Oakland Athletics, said everything he had seen, heard and read convinced him that there would be "a flurry of activity on the great players." Beane said he would be only an onlooker, because his goal is to try to retain Tejada and Foulke; realistically, he thinks the A's will end up with only one of them.
The Yankees will probably pursue Guerrero or Sheffield, the Red Sox may chase Colon or Millwood, and the Dodgers, the Braves and the Orioles will also be aggressive, but Showalter said some teams would be able to sign only more reasonably priced, second-tier free agents. Although Showalter would not reveal who appealed to the Rangers, figure that they are interested in Sterling Hitchcock, Kenny Rogers, Pat Hentgen, Jason Grimsley, Scott Spiezio and J. T. Snow.
"I know teams were cutting back last year," Showalter said. "I think there's going to be even more cutting back this year."
The Yankees have typically been aggressive in singling out a splashy player on the first day a team can make an offer, a strategy that helped the Philadelphia Phillies sign Jim Thome last season. But Duquette, who utters "nontender" as often as he utters "hello," said patience was necessary for a slew of teams because a second wave of players who are not tendered contracts would become available next month.

Texas: Big and Bigger
How big is everything in Texas? Big. How big is Roger Clemens in Texas? Real big. How big of a lure would it be for Clemens to eschew retirement and pitch one final season for the Texas Rangers? The Rangers hope the chances of that happening are big, too.
While Showalter merely said he wondered if the 41-year-old Clemens would really retire, one American League official who has spoken with the Rangers said the team was hopeful of offering Clemens a one-year deal and persuading him to follow Nolan Ryan by finishing his Hall of Fame career in his home state. Those close to Clemens did not think he would be swayed.
"When I asked him if he was really retired, he said, 'This is it, boss,' " Randy Hendricks, one of Clemens's agents, said in an e-mail message.
If anything, the Yankees believe Clemens would return to them late next year as a possible pitching mercenary. Clemens is keenly aware of his place in baseball history and probably wants to be remembered for finishing his career as a Yankee.

Support for Little
As much as the Boston Red Sox insisted that Manager Grady Little was not dismissed because he left Pedro Martinez in to pitch against the Yankees in the eighth inning of Game 7 of the American League Championship Series, it is hard to believe them. Little was on shaky ground and the decision to listen to Martinez, who blew a 5-2 lead, surely cost him any chance of keeping his job. To one former Yankee, that criticism was unfair.
"I think you have to leave Pedro in that game," Joe Girardi, who could be on Joe Torre's staff next season, said. "I don't care what the other guys in their bullpen had done. They're not Pedro Martinez."

Trade Soriano?
Alfonso Soriano had a dreadful postseason, setting a record with 26 strikeouts and being benched for one game in the World Series. The dismal performance raised speculation that the Yankees should shift him to the outfield or trade him.
Because the 25-year-old Soriano is the team's youngest starter and its most talented, although flawed, player, trading him would be dubious. The Yankees should instruct Luis Sojo, who is likely to be added to the coaching staff, and Willie Randolph that their mission is to teach Soriano better footwork, smarter positioning and improved throwing technique at second base.
"Teams are saying this is a good time to pop George on Soriano," one decision-maker from a major league team said, referring to George Steinbrenner. "They just might be haphazard and go and get rid of Soriano."

Hip-Hop on First!
OutKast, the hip-hop group featuring Big Boi and Andre 3000, includes a musical interlude on its double compact disc that parodies Abbott and Costello's "Who's on First?" routine.
The interlude, called "Good Day, Good Sir," focuses on a character named Bentley Farnsworth. As a second character tries to confirm Farnsworth's identity, other characters -- Fantasticly Well, Spectacular, Fine and Exactly -- are introduced. Those character names, some of which are also feelings, create the same type of confusion as having Who on first, What on second and I Don't Know on third.

HEADLINE: In Race for Mayor of Yonkers, Its Experience vs. Experience 

BYLINE:  By LYDIA POLGREEN

DATELINE: YONKERS, N.Y., Oct. 30 

 BODY:
Voters will decide between the current deputy mayor and a former chief of the city's troubled school system when they go to the polls on Tuesday to choose a new mayor.
 The deputy mayor, Phil Amicone, a Republican, seeks to replace his political mentor, Mayor John Spencer, who is barred by term limits from seeking re-election. Joe L. Farmer, a Democrat and a career school administrator who was schools superintendent for three years, seeks to become the city's first black mayor. 
 In a city where Democrats outnumber Republicans almost two to one but Republicans have dominated City Hall for the past decade, the outcome is anything but certain. Gov. George E. Pataki came to Yonkers to endorse Mr. Amicone, and a steady stream of state and local Democrats have campaigned heavily for Mr. Farmer.
Mr. Amicone has campaigned on a promise to continue the course set by Mr. Spencer, emphasizing economic development and the overhaul of city schools.
"In spite of an economic recession around the country and state, Yonkers has continued to move forward and progress with our leadership," Mr. Amicone said.
Mr. Farmer said that his experience in the schools and as a special deputy in charge of creating moderately priced housing made him best able to tackle the city's biggest problems.
"I have the experience in the critical areas," Mr. Farmer said.
The race follows a hard-fought primary, in which Mr. Amicone faced Assemblyman Michael J. Spano, a longtime rival of Mr. Spencer. But rather than throw his support to Mr. Amicone after losing the messy fight over the nomination, Mr. Spano stayed in the race, seeking victory on the Conservative and Independent Party lines.
Mr. Spano's decision forced Mr. Amicone to wage a two-front campaign. Mr. Spano said in an interview after the primary that he had chosen to stay in the race because he felt that Mr. Amicone, a self-described social conservative, was too conservative for the city's heavily Democratic electorate. 
But Mr. Spano later reversed course, pulling out the race and throwing his support to Mr. Amicone. When he went to Yonkers on Wednesday to announce his endorsement of Mr. Amicone, Governor Pataki singled out Mr. Spano and his brother, Nick, who is a state senator from Yonkers, for applause. (The Spanos are not related to Andrew Spano, the Westchester County executive, a Democrat.)
Mr. Farmer worked in the school system as an administrator for three decades and had a tumultuous tenure as superintendent. He has staked his candidacy on his education experience, saying that only he can right the city's school system, which has been torn apart for decades over an ugly battle to end racial segregation. Mr. Farmer also worked in Mr. Spencer's administration, as an administrator in charge of developing more moderately priced housing.
Despite a numerical advantage in enrolled voters, Democrats have seen Republican mayors dominate city politics in recent years. Some saw the September primary as an opportunity to buck that trend, but Mr. Spano's withdrawal turned what had been an unpredictable three-way race into a more conventional campaign. Both Mr. Amicone and Mr. Farmer claimed Mr. Spano's withdrawal would help their campaigns.

HEADLINE: MARATHON; 
Lovely Day To Watch (Maybe Not Race)

BYLINE:  By FRANK LITSKY

 BODY:
The weather forecast for today says temperatures should be in the 60's, an idyllic day for a Sunday stroll or an autumn picnic or watching the 34th annual New York City Marathon. Whether it will be a day of dreams for the 34,000 or so serious and recreational runners who will try to cover the 26 miles 385 yards through all five boroughs remains to be seen.
 The race organizers have taken extra steps to assure that 31,000 to 32,000 starters will finish. As usual, the race will start at the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge and end in Central Park, but everything will be an hour earlier. That should help many back-of-the-pack runners finish in daylight and avoid the evening chill. Disabled runners will start at 8 a.m., wheelchairs at 9:05, elite women at 9:35 and elite men and the rest of the men and women at 10:10. 
 Even with frequent water stations along the way, marathon runners tend to dehydrate during a race. The relatively warm weather is somewhat dangerous for recreational runners, who are not as finely trained as the professionals and are on the course longer. For the pros, warm weather is generally no more than an inconvenience.
"I'm not at all worried about it," said Catherine Ndereba, the women's favorite.
And Rodgers Rop, the men's defender, said, "It's my best weather because I've been training in hot weather."
Ndereba and Rop are Kenyans and accustomed to training in heat. One runner who doesn't like it is Marla Runyan of Eugene, Ore., who finished fourth among the women last year in her marathon debut and figures to do well again.
"I'd like colder weather," she said. "The temperature is more significant for me than the hills."
Any distractions, like too-warm weather, will not be welcomed by the American women who are seeking a qualifying time for the United States Olympic trials April 4 in St. Louis. Any who break 2 hours 40 minutes will get full expenses paid for the trials. Others who better 2:48 will qualify, but must pay their own way.
There are dollar rewards, too. ING, the Dutch financial services company, has become the race's first title sponsor. With its help, the prize money has been raised to $532,000 plus potential time bonuses. The leading man and woman will each collect at least $100,000 plus a European car, a Smart coupe.
As usual, Kenyan runners are expected to dominate. Last year, Kenyan men finished first, second and third and Kenyan women first, third, fifth and seventh.
Rop, 27, won the men's race last year and then won the Boston Marathon in April.
"My preparation for New York has been good," he said. "I think everything will be going smoothly."
Will he win again?
"I think so," he said. "Every time I run, I think I'm going to win, but I'm more sure now."
One interesting challenger is Laban Kipkemboi, only 25. Last year, in his marathon debut, he finished third here. Three weeks ago, Evans Rutto of Kenya won the Chicago Marathon in 2:05:50, the fastest marathon debut ever, and Dieter Hogen, who coaches Rutto and Kipkemboi in Boulder, Colo., has said Kipkemboi is better.
Kipkemboi understands the economics of the sport.
"If you win a marathon like New York," he said, "you will be very well known in the world and you will be invited to races. You can make a living."
Another potential winner is Julio Rey, a 31-year-old Spaniard who was the runner-up two months ago in the world championships. Before he began running at age 8, he watched his father run marathons for enjoyment and followed his father on a bike.
"I haven't seen the course here," Rey said. "But I was told 'piano, piano.' That's Italian for take it easy at the beginning. If I do, I think I can run 2:08."
A time of 2:08 would have won every marathon here except the one in 2001, when Tesfaye Jifar of Ethiopia set the course record of 2:07:43. The same year, Margaret Okayo of Kenya set the women's course record of 2:24:21.
Okayo, 27, is small (5 feet, 95 pounds), but she is a dangerous contender in the strong women's field. She started too fast in the Boston Marathon this year and faded to fourth in 2:27:39. She showed her speed three weeks ago when she ran a half-marathon in 1:07.
"I don't think New York is fast enough for a woman to run 2:20," she said. "But Idon't care. I don't think I have any competition."
She may face plenty of competition from other native Kenyans. Joyce Chepchemba, 32, the defending champion, has won marathons in New York, Chicago and London. Lornah Kiplagat, 29, who is a new Dutch citizen, won the New York Mini-Marathon in June, and if she wins today she will collect a $100,000 bonus. Two years ago, Ndereba, now 31, ran the Chicago Marathon in 2:18:47, a world record at the time.
Ndereba won the world championship two months ago, and as she recalled that day she sounded like a winner here as well as there.
"I wasn't tired, and I wasn't sore," she said, "not at all. I was extremely happy."

HEADLINE: Fishing and Bickering 

BYLINE:  By LAURIE NADEL

 BODY:
"YOU'VE heard of off the beaten track? Well, this is the beaten track," John Skinner said as his red Jeep Cherokee slid through a mile-long serpentine trough of sand called Burma Road. It spit the Jeep onto Great Gun Beach near Moriches Inlet, five miles east of the entrance to Smith Point County Park. Mr. Skinner, 42, of Wading River, stopped his vehicle to survey conditions on the beach one recent Saturday morning before sunrise. A southeast wind was whipping the gray sea into uninviting, churning waves.
 "That's good, nasty side chop," he said. An outgoing tide, overcast skies, cool weather and rough, clean surf presented good conditions for catching Atlantic striped bass. 
 Mr. Skinner, a recreational fisherman, was not the only one who was betting that the bass would bite. Six others were already surfcasting. One man, wrapped in a sleeping bag, sprawled next to a driftwood fire near his camper van. 
 "Anyone who will get up at 1 a.m. to try to outsmart a lower life form by waving a stick is crazy," Mr. Skinner said with a twinkle in his eye. He was attempting the same dubious feat, but had stayed in bed till 5. 
 As the first rays of sun poked through the clouds, he removed his old Lamiglass rod with its heavy-duty Penn spinning reel and 30-pound-test line from the vehicle's roof and tied on a Superstrike popper lure. Encased in a waterproof closed-cell neoprene suit and hip waders, Mr. Skinner walked into the wash and commenced whipping casts into the breakers. 
 Nearby, Bill Jentz, 48, of Bohemia, reeled in a 15-pound bluefish, a brute for its species but something of a consolation prize for the crowd that frequents Long Island beaches these days, looking for a striped bass that would double, triple -- they dared to hope for a trophy four times the weight of that bluefish.
 It was not to be. Chris Marino, 45, of Shirley, who had started fishing at 5:30 that morning, was calling it quits. "No runs, no hits, no errors," Mr. Marino said. "You might as well play Lotto." But like many lottery players, he said he intended to try again the next day. 
 Mr. Skinner cast different lures into the froth for three hours. It was hard work muscling casts into a cold wind while the surf tried to snatch his feet out from under him. But for his effort Mr. Skinner reeled in one undersized bass, which he released. 
 "Bass fishermen tend to be obsessive," he said by way of explanation.
 Forget golf or lacrosse -- striped bass fishing is the signifying sport on Long Island, like surfing is in Southern California. Hungry, night-feeding bass cruise the shoreline on their autumn migration from New England to warmer waters farther south, and the beaches from Cape Cod to New Jersey are the best spots to intercept them. The South Shore is in the middle of this zone. So every fall, thousands of Long Islanders forsake their warm beds to stand on the sand or a rocky jetty with a long rod and cast into the surf or the gnarly rips and inlets in pursuit of the striper. 
 The height of the season is right about now. In fact, as any fisherman will tell you, the biggest bite of the year was yesterday.
 "Bass bring out something in people," said George Scocca, publisher of Nor'east Saltwater, a magazine published in Commack. "The mystique has to do with its size, beauty, and grace. You can hold it and look at it. It has no teeth. When you release it, you nurse it back in the water. There's something sensual about it. It's the only fish that will make a man say, 'She was so beautiful, I had to let her go."'
 In addition to turning rugged outdoorsy types into misty-eyed poets, stripers taste great, and have long supported a commercial fishery. Last year New York commercial fishermen sold more than half a million pounds of striped bass, according to Ken Gall, seafood specialist with the New York Sea Grant Project, a public research group..
 But in the same year the state's recreational fishermen landed more than four million pounds of stripers, a disparity that is one of several issues in a long-running skirmish between commercial and sport anglers.
 The minimum length for a keeper striped bass in New York State is 28 inches, with recreational anglers, unlicensed and using a rod and reel, limited to one per day, two per day if landed on a charter boat. Commercial fishermen, who must be licensed and mostly use nets, have the same size limit and an allotment of 151 fish per fisherman per season, an increase of 42 percent over previous years.
 The increased commercial catch was approved in February by the 15-state Atlantic Marine Fisheries Commission. Lower commercial limits had been in effect since 1990, and for seven years before that it was illegal for any angler in New York to keep a striped bass.
 The increase in commercial limits reflects the judgment by the Marine Fisheries Commission that the bass population, which crashed in the 1980's because of overfishing, can withstand more pressure without being depleted. But the recreational limits were not changed, fanning sport anglers' resentments.
 "I'm disappointed in the commercial quota increase," Mr. Skinner said, summing up the general opinion at a recent seminar in Lynbrook attended by more than 300 recreational fishermen. 
 But the commercials say they're still being denied a fair slice of the pie. "I would have allowed the commercial fisheries to increase their landings," said Arnold Leo, 64, of East Hampton, who represents New York State's commercial fishery on the Atlantic Striped Bass Advisory Panel. "We were prevented from doing that by A.M.S.F.C. because of lobbying by the recreational fishery.
 "Whoever has the most political power gets most of the quota," Mr. Leo said. "Whoever tried to reduce the recreational quota would be shot at dawn."
 Brad Loewen has been a commercial trapper in Peconic Bay for the past 30 years. "I have to wait for them to come to me. That's like going out in your backyard and hoping you'll find gold," said Mr. Loewen, 54, of East Hampton. "The feds gave us more fish. If there's a good run in the fall, I'll be able to fill my tags this year." Even if he fills the quota, he estimated that if he caught 151 11-pounders, at $3.53 a pound, it would not be a significant part of his income. "We're still under such restrictions, you can't really make a living." 
 According to Mr. Leo, the disparity in sport and commercial anglers' bass catches is even greater than the statistics indicate because catch-and-release fishing, a common practice among sport anglers even when they catch a legal fish, kills more striped bass than this year's increase in the commercial limit.
 "He exhausts the fish by dragging them through surf and sand," Mr. Leo said of the recreational angler. "He cuts the gills and gullets with his hooks. He wounds them, then throws them back into the water."
 Sport fishermen contend that 1 out of every 9 or 10 fish die this way, but Mr. Leo estimates that the striped bass fatality rate from "catch and release" activity is closer to 1 out of every 4 or 5.
"Those guys are killing six million pounds of striped bass while the commercial guys now get around 800,000 pounds," he said. "There isn't any equity." 
 Sport anglers say the commercials have the same problem with undersized fish injured in their nets, not to mention the waste of bycatch, the unwanted species hauled aboard. The small bass and unwanted species -- "trash fish" to the commercials but just as much a part of the ecosystem -- often vastly outnumber the keeper bass in a net, and are thrown overboard, usually dead or dying.
 But according to Mr. Leo, commercial fishermen cause minimal damage to the environment. "It's the recreational fishermen who destroy wetlands with their marinas, pollute the water with their engines and destroy the dunes with their S.U.V.'s," he said.
 Recreational anglers put a different spin on the same facts, noting that the recreational fishery dwarfs the commercial one in terms of economic value. 
 Another point of contention is the protection of trophy-sized fish, all of which are females. A 50-pound cow is about 20 years old and could have another 10 years or more to live, and produces more eggs as she ages.
 "A 20-year-old female will produce several million more eggs than a younger fish," said Fred Schwab, 68, of Mattituck, who has represented New York State's recreational fishery on the Atlantic Striped Bass Advisory Panel since 1978. He argued that an increased commercial catch will take more large bass out of circulation, leading to less spawning for future generations.
 "In terms of numbers, the striped bass resource has recovered, but there are few large fish," he said. "We want to give the fish a chance to grow older."
 But the recreational anglers generally oppose any change in their catch limits, and few of them can bring themselves to give up their right to keep a trophy fish. On the other hand, many commercial fishermen favor a maximum length as well as a minimum, to protect large fish. 
 "We think you should be able to catch fish between 22 and 36 inches," Mr. Leo said. "That way you get small fillet fish and larger steak fish. Fish over 36 inches are clearly the strongest and the smartest. They should be protected for spawning."
 "Recreational fishermen are full of delusions about how things work," Mr. Leo said. "Their greed whoops their ability to think clearly. The recreational guys think that if you leave the small fish, eventually you will have more big fish to catch. Not exactly." 
 Mr. Skinner allowed that he "would have liked to see better protection of bigger fish in the recreational allotment." But that's as far as he would go in agreeing with Mr. Leo.
 So the standoff continues. Meanwhile, just off a beach somewhere along the South Shore, a five-foot torpedo with a mouth like a bucket cruises silently, waiting to make some angler's day.

J.P. Morgan Chase To Lay Off 1,000
 In the largest Long Island job layoff announced this year, J.P. Morgan Chase said Monday that it would cut about 1,000 back-office jobs in Hicksville by next May, moving most of the jobs to a new customer-service center in Vancouver, British Columbia. 
 The bank will move the remainder to other customer-service and collection centers in Houston; San Antonio, Tex.; Tampa, Fla.; and Tempe, Ariz., said Kirsten Batteria, a bank spokeswoman. About 500 jobs will remain in Hicksville. The shift will strengthen the bank's ability to provide customer service to the West Coast and will take advantage of lower operational costs, Ms. Batteria said. 
 Gary Huth, the Long Island labor market analyst for the State Department of Labor, said the layoffs were the largest by a single employer on the Island this year. "While the job losses will be individually very disruptive, I think a number of the people who are being laid off are well positioned to be reabsorbed into the local economy fairly quickly," Mr. Huth said.

Cablevision's New Venture
 Charles Dolan, the founder of the Cablevision Systems Corporation (NYSE: CVC) in Bethpage, said on Oct. 23 that he would step down as the company's chairman to run a satellite TV spinoff called Voom. James Dolan, his son and Cablevision's chief executive, will assume the chairman's post.
 Analysts generally reacted negatively to the venture, which several said exposed the company and its investors to a risky initiative. "The company is again straining credibility with investors," Ted Henderson, an analyst at Stifel Nicolaus, told CBS MarketWatch.

Acclaim Settles Lawsuit
 Acclaim Entertainment (Nasdaq: AKLM) of Glen Cove, the video game company, said Monday that it had resolved its dispute with Dave Mirra, a professional dirt-bike racer. Mr. Mirra, who licensed his name and likeness to Acclaim for a series of video games, filed a lawsuit in Federal District Court in New York in February seeking over $20 million in damages. The lawsuit contended that the game was pornographic and damaged Mr. Mirra's image.
 The lawsuit was settled without compensation, and Acclaim is moving forward with a new game based on Mr. Mirra's racing exploits, the company said. Compiled by Warren Strugatch

HEADLINE: L.I.@WORK; 
A Plan to Build the Best-Protected Bathroom Ever

BYLINE:  By WARREN STRUGATCH

 BODY:
TOURISM promoters believe they can overcome deeply rooted neighborhood objections and move forward with a plan to build what would be Long Island's first true visitors' center after at least three decades of trying.
 Each year, tourism accounts for about $1.6 billion on Long Island, according to a study completed last year by Global Insight, an economic consulting firm in Reston, Va. Pearl Kamer, the Long Island Association's economist, said that tourism accounted for 100,000 jobs last year, making it the No. 4 industry on the Island, after retailing, heath care and education. 
 But for all their spending, visitors don't exactly get red-carpet treatment. In fact, they don't even get a flush toilet. 
 Most tourism promotion agencies slap welcome centers on well-traveled roads, plying visitors with brochures, information and often complimentary snacks and beverages. And, of course, a bathroom. For many visitors, nothing may be as urgent.
 But that's not how things work on Long Island. The Long Island Convention & Visitors Bureau, which has a $2 million annual budget, mostly financed by hotel-room surcharges, operates four information centers. Two shut down every October: the chalet on Southern State Parkway in Valley Stream, and the converted and rather dilapidated Long Island Rail Road car on the eastbound Long Island Expressway near Exit 51. The bureau distributes information year round from an unstaffed kiosk at the Tanger Outlet Center in Riverhead and from a staffed booth at MacArthur Airport. 
 Only the rail car has a bathroom supplied by the tourist bureau: portable toilets that are available from April 1 through Columbus Day.
 Michael G. Hollander, the executive director of the tourism bureau, acknowledges that Long Island offers visitors a dubious welcome. "Hospitality means one of the things you provide visitors, along with information, is use of bathrooms," Mr. Hollander said. "Historically we haven't been able to do this very well."
 Mitchell Pally, the Long Island Association's government affairs specialist and Mr. Hollander's chief ally in the effort to provide modern visitors' centers, agreed. "Do we shoot ourselves in the foot?" he said. "Yes, we do." 
 The reason it has taken decades to let tourists use the bathroom is community opposition. Efforts by civic groups and vocal individuals have consistently derailed efforts to build full-service visitors' centers, out-muscling both the tourism board and the Long Island Association. Both organizations want to establish at least three year-round, full-service visitors' centers. The association, in fact, has made that one of its 2004 priorities.
 This quixotic campaign has been under way since the early 1970's. Last month, both organizations said they believed they had finally turned a corner. 
 Both of New York's senators have sent letters to the federal highway superintendent in Washington calling for a waiver on the ban that bars construction of office buildings on federal highways. If granted, the waiver would allow the tourism board to move forward with its newest plan, which is to move into a 19,000-square-foot state highway patrol building that would be built where the rail car now stands. The projected completion date is 2007.
 The state would pay the $35 million construction tab, and the bureau would maintain the building, which it would share with the state troopers. Visitors could pick up brochures promoting Long Island attractions and find someone to answer questions year round. And, at long last, visitors could use the bathroom, probably one of the safest roadside bathrooms anywhere.
 The effort to block the project has a long, boisterous pedigree. Over the years, civic groups have successfully opposed opening full-service centers by drawing lurid scenarios involving drug users, prostitutes, roving bands of teenagers and promiscuous gays.
 Daniel C. Brown, the chairman of a group called Citizens Against Rest Stops, said that his organization opposes the efforts to build the visitor center near Exit 51 because truck drivers allow their engines to idle at the existing rest area for hours, spewing exhaust. "There are facets to the new plan that are outscaled, in particular the size," he said. "They're now saying 19,000 square feet. Last May, they presented the plan to us as 9,000 square feet." 
 Mr. Pally of the Long Island Association contends that neighborhood advocates should take a broader view. "Local residents tend to look at regional issues from the perspective of how they affect their own immediate neighborhood," he said. "That's why it's often so difficult to succeed not only in tourism promotion, but also in moving forward with other projects. All kinds of worthwhile things have been delayed or defeated. Long Islanders need to understand that we are in this together."
 Neal Lewis, the executive director of the Neighborhood Network, an advocacy group claiming 30,000 members in Nassau and Suffolk, said that tourism promoters alienated residents with their heavy-handed style. "Community groups are told, in effect, you can support this plan or you can oppose it," he said. "So they oppose it."
 Michael Davidson, the executive director of the Glen Cove Chamber of Commerce and Mr. Hollander's immediate predecessor, said he made construction of a visitors' center a top priority during his tenure, from 1990 through 1997.
 Although the project went nowhere, Mr. Davidson denied that the effort was a failure. "I look at everything as a long-term process," he said. "You keep presenting ideas, and you keep trying."
 David J. Lee, a Sag Harbor retailer and the chairman of the convention and visitors bureau during the mid-70's, said that establishing a visitors' center had also been one of his priorities. 
 He said that the installation of the old rail car, which he helped to implement, was a step in the right direction. "The railroad car leaves a lot to be desired, but it's a heck of a lot better than nothing," he said. 
 Mr. Lee blamed bureaucratic turf-protecting and political inertia for the years of delay in establishing a modern visitors' center. "There is a D.O.T. building on the south service road by Route 110, and we wanted to get it turned over to us" for a visitors' center, Mr. Lee said, recalling an effort he led nearly 30 years ago. "It didn't happen. D.O.T. said they needed the building. They use it to store gravel and trucks. It was a real waste of valuable land."
 Mr. Lee expressed limited optimism for the current effort. "What happens is these things get bogged down in politics, in the unwillingness of bureaucrats to change and, especially, nimbyism," he said. 
 Speaking perhaps with tongue in cheek, Mr. Lee suggested that tourism promoters could make their case by arranging a nonstop tour for government officials from Manhattan to Montauk. "I say, fill 'em up with coffee, then don't let 'em out to use the bathroom until they get to Montauk," he said. "That ought to do it."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The old rail car that serves as a tourist information center on the eastbound Long Island Expressway shuts down in October. (Photo by John W. Wheeler for The New York Times)
