HEADLINE: As Population Grows Older, Upstate Towns Face a Crisis 

BYLINE:  By LYDIA POLGREEN

DATELINE: MAYVILLE, N.Y. 

 BODY:
In 1998, when Mark Thomas took office as county executive of Chautauqua County, the southwesternmost county in New York State, the county spent $13 million on health care for its poorest residents. Next year the bill is expected to reach $29 million, and the vast majority of that sum, which represents more than half the property taxes the county collects, will pay for medical care for Chautauqua's growing elderly population.
 Like much of rural America, upstate New York is aging rapidly, and that aging comes with its own economic and social problems. But the consequences have been particularly tough for upstate New York, because of the state's extensive programs under Medicaid and its unusual requirement that local governments pay a quarter of the cost of most of them. Medicaid, a federal and state program, helps pay for health care for poor, elderly, blind and disabled patients and for poor families with children. 
 People 65 and older make up an ever-larger portion of the population of upstate New York, according to an analysis of 2000 census data completed this fall by the Brookings Institution, a Washington research organization. It found that on average, 14 percent of people living in upstate counties were 65 or older, two percentage points higher than the national average. In western New York, in places like Chautauqua County, the figure rises to 16 percent, and in some counties, like Hamilton, with about 5,000 people in the Adirondack Forest Preserve, 20 percent of residents are 65 or older.
The bill for caring for the poorest of the state's elderly is strangling upstate communities, according to county officials statewide. County governments, the primary conduit for social services, must meet this expense despite an ever-shrinking tax base.
A report on the fiscal health of New York counties issued in September by Moody's Investors Service painted a grim portrait of counties across the state struggling with the ballooning cost of Medicaid, much of which goes for nursing home care and prescription drugs for the elderly. In 2000, the latest year for which specific data are available, New York spent nearly $3 billion on Medicaid for people 65 and older living outside New York City. More than two-thirds of that went for nursing home care. Counties pay 10 percent of the cost of institutional long-term care and 25 percent of the cost of other Medicaid services. Most states do not force local governments to pay anything, but of the 20 states that do, New York's local share is the highest.
Compounding this problem is New York State's extensive Medicaid package, including many optional programs like prescription drugs, home heath care aides and dental care. New York State spends $9,365 a year, on average, on its 3 million Medicaid beneficiaries. California, with twice as many recipients, spends $2,862 on average. Some of New York's spending goes toward covering poor children and families, but upstate, where the tax base is often smaller, the population older and the economy shriveled, the greatest burden is the elderly. In 2000, elderly Medicaid users cost $22,138 on average, more than anyone else in the program, including people with disabilities, according to a report issued in September by the Center for Government Research, a nonprofit, nonpartisan research institution in Rochester. Children covered under Medicaid cost only $2,142 a year, and healthy adults cost just $4,059, according to the report.
The problem will only worsen as the baby boom generation begins retiring, setting up a crisis that could bankrupt local governments statewide, according to officials at the New York State Association of Counties. Nowhere is this clearer than in places like Chautauqua County, 1,062 square miles of rolling farmland. The county's population in the 2000 census was about 140,000, including more than 22,000 people 65 or older.
"We are dealing with seniors burning through their financial resources and having to go on Medicaid," County Executive Thomas, a Democrat, said in an interview at his office in Mayville, the county seat. "And because of the way the system is financed in New York, their overwhelming health care needs become a burden to the rest of us. These expenses dwarf everything else and make it very difficult for us to provide the minimum of other services county governments perform."
Last year, facing a $12 million budget gap created in part by a $7.4 million increase in Medicaid costs, Chautauqua shed 80 jobsfrom the county payroll, consolidated departments and increased property taxes by more than 22 percent. This year Mr. Thomas has requested a 9 percent increase in taxes and more job cuts, which, along with last year's cuts, will pare about 20 percent of the county's work force.
"We try to make the cuts in places where residents won't feel them so much," Mr. Thomas said. "But you can only cut so much on the margin until there is no margin left anymore."
And so Katie Smith, the director of the county's Office for the Aging, said she tried to do more with less. Meeting with a group of lay ministers at the First Presbyterian Church in Jamestown, the county's only city, she explained why spending local tax dollars to help older people stay in their homes was important.
"We get state money to help people with housekeeping," Ms. Smith said. "At budget time the County Legislature gets tempted to cut the $95,000 it costs us to keep the program. But if having someone help a 90-year-old with her chores means that 90-year-old can stay in her house and keep paying property taxes rather than us spending $60,000 a year in taxpayers' money on long-term residential care, it is money well spent."
Helen Grover, 89, gets help with housekeeping and from Meals on Wheels, and hence is able to stay in her two-story blue wood-shingle house.
"They help me, and it is a blessing," she said as Barrie Yochim, the director of the local Meals on Wheels program, dropped off a shrink-wrapped luncheon tray of chicken cordon bleu, peas and whipped potatoes. She said county programs helped her stay independent.
But for local officials who approved a 22 percent tax increase last year, asking taxpayers to cough up an additional 9 percent in an election year is a tough sell, and the urge to cut programs is strong.
"We are a rural economy that depends heavily on a lot of farming, especially dairy and grapes," said Jim Caflisch, leader of the Republican minority in the County Legislature. "Those industries have been hit hard with price downturns, and weather this year has been so wet, so a lot of grape crop was lost. We can't place any more of a burden on those people who are paying."
He said that raising property taxes just added to the county's financial problems because high taxes made it harder to attract new businesses that could provide jobs and increase the tax base, and made it less likely that elderly people would be able to keep their houses. 
Still, cutting programs for the elderly can have unintended consequences that will simply cost the county more in the future, county officials said. Thousands of elderly people live in Chautauqua County, often left behind by younger relatives who have left the area in pursuit of better jobs. Their needs are often overwhelming: the county helps many people pay their heating bills, build wheelchair ramps outside houses, clean up after themselves, get to doctors' appointments and get food.
The county has a budget of about $3 million to pay for these things, the majority of which comes from the state and federal governments, but $600,000 of which comes from local taxes. And because the federal and state money is often contingent on local governments chipping in, reducing local spending can mean losing a program.
But pulling together the $600,000 that the local government must raise from property and sales taxes has been a yearly struggle for officials.
"Every year we fight for every penny, but it is always a fight," Ms. Smith said. The money her department receives has remained flat over the past few years, and she said she had managed to keep up with increasing demand by cutting administrative costs and had tried to avoid limiting services but had had to begin waiting lists for some services, like housekeeping.
Dorothy Akin, a 92-year-old widow, moved into a small subsidized apartment 12 years ago, after she realized that she could no longer maintain her mobile home. She gets about $600 a month in Social Security and depends on the county and state's help to survive, she said.
"I have a lady who comes to help me twice a week, which is a blessing," she said, leaning heavily on her cane. "And these folks come check on me every day, make sure I am breathing," she added, gesturing to Mr. Yochim, who dropped off her Meals on Wheels lunch and dinner.
"I can't pay for my prescriptions, so I get help with that too," she said. "They help me live. Without them, I don't know what I would do."

COMPANY: MOODY'S INVESTORS SERVICE LTD (65%)

PERSON: Lydia Polgreen

HEADLINE: Sales Fell in October for G.M. and Ford 

BYLINE:  By MICHELINE MAYNARD

DATELINE: DETROIT, Nov. 3 

 BODY:
Reporting one of the domestic automobile industry's toughest months yet this year, the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company said on Monday that sales fell in October from the month last year.
 G.M. said its sales dropped 7 percent in October, while Ford said sales fell 2 percent. Among the Big Three, only the Chrysler Corporation, a unit of DaimlerChrysler of Germany, reported a gain over last year, rising 11 percent to let it remain in third place ahead of the Toyota Motor Company of Japan, which said sales rose 11.7 percent in October. 
 The industry sold vehicles at an annual rate of 15.6 million last month, the slowest pace since February, according to Ward's Automotive Reports of Southfield, Mich. That is well behind the 16.1 million rate that analysts had expected for the month, and a steep drop from the 18.9 million pace in August, the year's best. In August, auto companies offered substantial incentives, including interest-free loans and rebates, to clear out 2003 model year cars and trucks before new models began arriving in September. 
 Total industry sales for the month were flat with last year, Ward's said. 
 Based on the October performance, Paul Ballew, chief sales analyst at G.M., said the industry would probably sell fewer than 17 million vehicles in 2003 for the first time in five years, although he said he expected the industry to achieve that figure next year.
 Carmakers are hoping that renewed consumer confidence and an improving business climate will lead to higher car sales through the end of this year and into 2004. "It is fair to say that the economy is starting to fire on all cylinders," said Jarlath Costello, an economist for Ford.
 But October remained a month to forget at G.M. and Ford, where officials said their sales were trampled somewhat by the wildfires in California, the nation's largest car market. Toyota, whose operations are based in California, said sales at its Lexus division climbed 40 percent last month and it did not cite any effect from the fires.
 Neither did Nissan Motor, whose sales climbed 18 percent in October from last year's level. It joined a flock of foreign-based companies in posting higher October sales, including BMW and Mercedes-Benz of Germany, and Hyundai of South Korea. Honda Motor surprised analysts by recording a 2.9 percent drop in October sales.
 In a conference call with analysts and journalists Monday, Mr. Ballew tried to damp expectations that G.M., which has posted small market share gains in each of the last two years, would be able to gain share for a third consecutive year.
 "We realize three-peating will be tough," Mr. Ballew said. "The important thing is that we'll end the year somewhere in the 28 percent range."
 So far this year, G.M. has 27.7 percent of the United States market, down 0.6 percentage point from last year, according to Autodata.
 Even as sales of Cadillac CTS sedans, Hummer S.U.V.'s and other previously popular G.M. models fell in October, G.M. raised its fourth-quarter production forecast by 10,000 vehicles over its previous estimates.
 Stephen Girsky, the auto analyst with Morgan Stanley, noted in a conference call that G.M. ended October with a 90-day inventory of unsold vehicles, well above the 65-day level that is normal for this time of year. Chrysler wound up the month with an 87-day supply; Ford did not disclose its inventory.
Mr. Girsky wondered why the company would increase production, given the industry's slower pace. Mr. Ballew said it was too soon to write off November and December. "I wouldn't accept our sales as weakening or the industry as weakening," Mr. Ballew said.
 Jesse Toprak, senior analyst with Edmunds.com in Santa Monica, Calif., said he believed that G.M. was building inventories to fuel a year-end sales push, like the one it introduced last year. "What are you going to do? " he said. "You can't have all those cars sitting on the lots."
 George Pipas, chief sales analyst at Ford, said he also expected incentives to climb in November and December, and signaled that Ford's F-150 pickup could be in store for more generous discounts. 
 Ford sold 18,000 of the new trucks in October, out of a total of about 68,000 F-series, but Ford eventually will have to sell more than 45,000 a month to meet its goal of selling 500,000 a year of the new model. The only discounts available thus far are to previous F-series owners.
 "If you had asked me, I would have said I didn't think we could do this well" with minimal incentives, Mr. Pipas said. "I can assure you this is one of the low months" for the new version of the F-series, he added.
 But October was just the opposite for the Dodge Ram pickup, whose 46 percent increase in sales startled some analysts, since the current version has been on the market for well over a year. Like each of the Big Three companies, Chrysler has blanketed the Detroit area with commercials promoting special deals for employees and family members, in hopes of spurring sales.
 Gary Dilts, a Chrysler vice president, acknowledged that Chrysler raised incentives slightly on the Ram in October, but maintained there were no out-of-the-ordinary discounts on the Ram last month. "The truck spoke for itself in the marketplace," Mr. Dilts said.
 But figures from Edmunds showed Chrysler had been the most aggressive among Big Three pickup makers in offering discounts, including rebates, lease deals and low-rate financing, off the sticker prices of its new trucks. 
 In September, the latest month for which statistics were available, Chrysler's average discount on the 2004 version of the Dodge Ram was $5,543. That compared with $4,803 on the Chevrolet Silverado, and just $2,771 on the Ford F-150. 
 "They're pushing out the Rams, and that paid off very well," Mr. Toprak said.

HEADLINE: October Manufacturing Activity At Highest in Nearly 4 Years 

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Manufacturing registered its highest level of activity in nearly four years in October, an industry report said yesterday, suggesting that the economic growth of the third quarter might be continuing this quarter.
 In another positive sign, construction spending in September posted its best month on record, with spending by private builders also reaching a new high, the Commerce Department said. 
 The industry group, the Institute for Supply Management, reported that its manufacturing index rose to 57 last month from 53.7 in September. It was the fourth consecutive monthly gain and pushed the index to its highest level since January 2000. The reading was well above the 55.5 that analysts had expected. 
 An index level above 50 indicates expansion; one below 50 indicates that manufacturing activity is contracting. From March through June, the index was below 50.
 "The U.S. economy has solid momentum," said Sherry Cooper, chief economist at BMO Nesbitt Burns.
 Mark Vitner, senior economist at Wachovia Securities in Charlotte, N.C., said the advance suggested that the economy would show sound growth this quarter after expanding at a 7.2 percent annual pace in the third quarter.
"This is the first hard evidence we have on the fourth quarter, " Mr. Vitner said, "and it suggests that a lot of the strength of the third quarter is carrying over." He predicted fourth-quarter growth in the range of 3.5 percent to 4 percent annually.
 The Commerce Department said the total value of building projects reached a seasonally adjusted annual pace of $910.6 billion in September, a 1.3 percent rise from August and a record monthly high. And the 1.3 percent increase exceeded analysts' expectations of an advance around 0.4 percent. Spending by private builders on housing projects rose 1.4 percent in September to a pace of $471.4 billion, also a monthly record.
 The housing market has been an important source of strength for the economy and is expected to remain so if interest rates remain low.
 Manufacturing employment continued to be weak, with an index below the point that would signify growth.

HEADLINE: South African Companies Fill a Void 

BYLINE:  By NICOLE ITANO

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, Nov. 3 

 BODY:
Africa largely missed out on the investment boom of the 1990's and still receives only a tiny portion of the world's foreign direct investment. But while the continent is receiving a shrinking share of global investment from traditional donors like the United States, Britain and France, investment from South Africa, the region's biggest economy, in the rest of the continent has surged. 
 "If you look over the last 10 years, South African businesses have discovered Africa," said Neuma Grobbelaar, head of the Business in Africa program at the South African Institute of International Affairs, a nongovernmental organization doing research on South African investment in the continent. "There's a realization that South Africa has a competitive edge on the African continent that it doesn't have in the more developed markets of Europe or the United States or Asia or Latin America." 
 In fact, experts say, in the last few years, South Africa has become one of the continent's biggest sources of foreign direct investment, and it has been greeted with mostly welcoming arms by businesses elsewhere on the continent. 
 Though South African companies initially invested in the country's small but stable neighbors, like Mozambique and Botswana, they increasingly are tackling some of the continent's most difficult markets, like Congo, Nigeria and Angola. And while some are still investing in traditional African sectors like oil and gas and minerals -- building diamond mines in Angola and copper mines in Congo, for instance -- others are now injecting capital into industries like telecommunications, banking and retailing, which development experts say contribute more to local economies.
 As these South African businesses, once pariahs, move rapidly north, they are bringing the rest of the world's least developed continent everything from fast food to cellphones, electricity to new roads. And some are making big profits in difficult markets that most other investors have shunned.
 Measuring foreign direct investment, particularly in Africa, is difficult, and the numbers can fluctuate widely year to year. But according to figures from the South African research foundation BusinessMap, during 2001 and 2002 South Africa was the largest single-nation source of such investment in the 14-country Southern African Development Community, which stretches as far north as Congo and Tanzania. In West and East Africa, which are new but expanding markets for South African businesses, South Africa is now the largest source of foreign direct investment outside the oil and gas industry, Ms. Grobbelaar said.
 In all, South African companies have invested an average of more than $1 billion a year in Africa since 1994, and last year they planned projects totaling an additional $6 billion.
 The boom in South African investment in Africa is largely a result of two developments. The end of sanctions against South Africa in the early 1990's, as apartheid was dismantled, radically changed the country's relationship to the rest of the continent, opening new markets but also increasing competition back home. And African countries began to overhaul their economies to meet conditions set down by international monetary organizations, making them better investment opportunities.
 Keith Campbell, managing director of Executive Research Associates, a risk management firm in Centurion, South Africa, for companies investing on the continent, said that 10 years ago, the rest of Africa was a place where the big mining companies struck raw materials. Now, said Mr. Campbell, who is also vice chairman of the six-month-old, 120-member South Africa-Angola Chamber of Commerce, "It's safer to go in, it's easier to get materials in and out, easier to repatriate your profits."
 "You're finding more and more success stories among the smaller guys," he said.
 Though many African countries have privatized state-owned enterprises, liberalized industries and rewritten laws to attract more foreign investment, investment on the continent is still difficult. And the South African companies often have to start from nothing, even building their own power sources and access roads, as they flood into other African countries.
 Still, though poor by global standards, these countries offer undeveloped markets the South Africans can enter and quickly dominate. Countries like Mozambique and Botswana are attractive because they are nearby and have many cultural similarities with South Africa, while places like Nigeria and Angola have oil wealth, and hence a moneyed class. Of least interest to South African companies are francophone West African nations like Senegal and Gabon, where French and Belgian companies already have a strong foothold. 
 And though African investments are risky in traditional terms, they have brought South African companies returns that are generally higher than those of their other foreign or domestic investments. Some industries, like cellular communications, have even brought returns as high as 40 percent.
 South African telecommunications companies have been among the most aggressive investors in the African market. Vodacom, one of South Africa's main providers of cellular service, recently spent $119 million on a cellular network in Congo, a country struggling to emerge from a five-year civil war. It also agreed to buy a controlling stake in Nigeria's second-largest network, Econet Wireless Nigeria, for an estimated $230 million, a deal that is being challenged in court by a stakeholder.
 Executives at the company, which is 50 percent owned by South Africa's fixed-line monopoly Telkom S.A. and 35 percent by the Vodafone Group of Britain, have said they are not commenting on the deal for now.
 If the purchase goes through, it will pit Vodacom against its main competitor in South Africa, the MTN Group, which spent nearly $900 million to build Nigeria's largest cellular network. "The Nigerian network was two and a half times more expensive than South Africa's," said Yvonne Muthien, MTN Group executive for corporate affairs. "There were no fixed lines, power was not stable. We had to build back up generators and a whole new transmission backbone that now connects 120 cities and towns."
 But, Dr. Muthien said, by 2005, the company expects revenue from the Nigerian operation, which signed up 1.2 million subscribers in its first 18 months, to surpass its revenue from South Africa, where it has more than 4 million subscribers. 
 Over all, she added MTN has invested 12 billion rand, or about $1.75 billion at current rates, in its five African operations outside South Africa and is looking for other opportunities on the continent. Those operations have a 40 percent profit margin, compared with MTN's 30 percent margin at home, and account for more than a third of the company's total revenue.
 Other South African companies expanding aggressively northward include Shoprite Holdings, a grocery chain, and the fast-food chain Steers Holdings. Eskom, South Africa's quasi-state electric utility, provides electricity around the continent and has ambitious expansion plans. JHI Real Estate Ltd. has built many of the continent's shopping malls. SABMiller, now based in England but born and bred in South Africa, is the continent's biggest beer maker and drink bottler, with 44 African breweries and 10 bottling plants, including one it just purchased in Angola.
 Some smaller companies that rely more on human than financial capital are also making inroads in businesses like advertising, information technology and consulting.
 Not every South African company has found gold north of the border, however. Inadequate financing and poor infrastructure continue to be major barriers. Political instability is also a big problem. The outbreak of civil war in Ivory Coast last year, for example, caused several new South African investors to withdraw.
 Even in stable countries, some companies have found the business climate too difficult. Pepkor Ltd., parent of the discount clothing retailer Pep Stores, decided this year to shut its Ghana operations, citing, in part, competition from smuggled and secondhand clothes.
 In some countries, too, South African companies have been met with apprehension by local businesses that fear dominance by more highly capitalized competitors. African business groups, however, generally herald the South African expansion as the beginning of a new era of intra-African trade.
 "We do believe that South African companies have an advantage over Nigerians in a number of ways, but being an African country, we can learn from them," said Olumide Adekunle, director general of the Nigerian Association of Chambers of Commerce, Industry, Mines and Agriculture, as he shouted over a crackling landline and joked that his cellphone was clearer. "Nigeria is a very large market and there are many opportunities. Development from the African continent is good."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TRAVEL: ON THE GROUND -- In Houston; 
Oil, Yes, but Also Culture and Fine Dining

BYLINE:  By MARK A. STEIN

 BODY:
FLAT on its back during the oil bust of the early 1980's, Houston diversified its economy as it rebounded in the 1990's. It is still the energy capital of the world, and the headquarters of ConocoPhillips, the El Paso Corporation, the Halliburton Company and other oil patch giants, but it is also emerging as a center for trade, transport and other industries. 
 In 1981, oil and gas production accounted for two-thirds of Houston's "base economic jobs," defined as those that export goods and service outside the metropolitan region. Today, that proportion has been halved as the city has benefited from the growth of nonenergy businesses like Sysco, the nation's biggest food services company; Waste Management, the nation's biggest trash hauler; and Continental Airlines.

AIRPORT
 Both of Houston's commercial airports, George Bush Intercontinental and Hobby, are being remodeled and expanded. Ernest DeSoto, a spokesman for the Houston Airport System, which runs both airports, said contractors were working at night and otherwise trying not to disrupt traffic. "It's like trying to change your underwear without taking your pants off," he said. 
 Intercontinental, which is 20 miles north of downtown, recently opened a consolidated rental car facility and is adding a fifth terminal and a fifth runway, to ease delays.
Seven of 20 gates in the new terminal, Terminal E, are open. Mr. DeSoto said the city wanted all of them operating by the time Houston plays host to the Super Bowl in January. Trains link all terminals.
 Hobby, seven miles south of downtown, has a new concourse to consolidate the operations of Southwest Airlines, which accounts for 80 percent of all flights. About one-third of the 24 gates are open; contractors are scheduled to finish construction next year.

HOTELS
 "Houston does not have an abundance of great hotels," said Randy Kabrich, a programming consultant to radio stations. "The only one that comes to mind is the Four Seasons downtown -- and right now downtown is an absolute nightmare with all the road work they are doing this year."
 The FOUR SEASONS (713-650-1300, $295 to $365) has multiple-line phones and high-speed Internet access in each room. Many business services are available 24 hours a day. Wireless Internet access is available in meeting rooms.
 Also downtown is the MAGNOLIA (713-221-0011, $149 to $329), a 300-room boutique hotel in what was originally the headquarters of the Post-Dispatch newspaper. Each room has two-line cordless phones and high-speed Internet access. There is a health club and a pool.
 North of downtown, near the Woodlands neighborhood, is the HOUSTONIAN HOTEL, CLUB AND SPA (713-680-2626, $295 to $365). Each of the 280 rooms comes with high-speed Internet access and cordless phone. The spa has 200 exercise machines, an indoor track, tennis and squash courts and a pool.

RESTAURANTS
 What Houston lacks in hotels it makes up in restaurants," Mr. Kabrich said. People in Houston spend more per capita on restaurants than residents of any other city.
 VIC AND ANTHONY'S STEAKHOUSE (713-228-1111, $110 for dinner for two, including wine and tip) is a downtown restaurant with a boardroom-style private dining room for meetings and a piano bar just off the main dining room. 
 In the River Oaks section, Tony Vallone, one of Houston's top chefs, runs LA GRIGLIA (713-526-4700, $75), a neighborhood restaurant in a shopping mall. "The place is a little loud, but it's my favorite place to dine when I'm in Houston," said Doris M. Koch, executive director of the Texas Association of Appraisal Districts, an industry group based in Austin. "Good wine list, consistently good contemporary Italian food."
 Near the Galleria, in an unimposing strip mall, SIMPOSIO (713-532-0550, $100) serves game, lamb, veal and pasta. "The food is good, consistent, and fresh," and the "service is wonderful," said Nancy Dellhommer, an engineer for Haverly Systems, a software company.

ENTERTAINMENT
 The SAMBUCA JAZZ CAFE (713-224-5299) in the Rice Hotel downtown has a full schedule of traditional, Latin and swing jazz. The animal prints on the wall may not be for everyone, but food is served and it has a cigar bar.
 The ALLEY THEATER (713-228-8421), a Tony Award-winning regional company, is currently presenting "Fully Committed," Becky Mode's 2000 comedy about an actor who takes reservations for a hot new Manhattan restaurant.

ON YOUR OWN
 The Level 9 Tour at SPACE CENTER HOUSTON (281-244-2100), the visitor center at the Johnson Space Center of NASA, is a behind-the-scenes look at Mission Control for manned space flights. Only 12 people a day can be accommodated. Tours begin promptly at noon. Reservations must be made at least one day in advance.
 A short drive east of downtown, in La Porte, is the SAN JACINTO BATTLEGROUND (281-479-2421), site of the battle in 1836 that won Texas its independence from Mexico.

BUSINESS LORE
 Two former top executives of Waste Management, Rodney Proto and Earl DeFrates, agreed last month to pay a total of $4.2 million to settle federal allegations of insider trading and making false or misleading public statements about the company. Mr. Proto will pay $3.7 million; Mr. DeFrates, $482,779. 
 The two men neither admitted to nor denied the allegations made by the Securities and Exchange Commission, which nonetheless banned them from acting as officers or directors of any publicly traded company for five years.

This feature about places to stay, eat and visit in leading business destinations appears every Tuesday.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS AND BONDS; 
Factory and Chip Reports Send Shares Broadly Higher

BYLINE:  By Reuters

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks rose yesterday, closing at their highest level in 17 months, after a surprisingly strong reading on manufacturing in October.
 Technology stocks, bolstered by sharply higher sales in September and expectations of a strong 2004, did still better, closing at a 21-month high. In all, 15 percent of the issues traded on the New York Stock Exchange and the Nasdaq market reached 52-week highs. 
 Stocks rose after an economic report showed that American manufacturers increased output in October to the best level in nearly four years. Separate data showed that construction spending surged in September to a record high. 
 "This is consistent with the idea that the economy is moving along quite nicely," said Steve Ricchiuto, chief economist at ABN Amro.
 The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 57.34 points, or 0.59 percent, at 9,858.46, and the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 8.31 points, or 0.79 percent, to 1,059.02 -- both closing levels not seen since May 31, 2002.
 The technology-focused Nasdaq composite index gained 35.49 points, or 1.84 percent, rising to 1,967.70, its highest close since Jan. 17, 2002.
 Yesterday's advance was the sixth consecutive one for the Dow industrials. The stock market, since touching 2003 lows in March, has risen over the last few months as data pointed to an improvement in the economy and companies were expected to post better quarterly earnings. When many of them did, investors funneled still more money into equities.
 "The economic news continues to be pretty good," said John Davidson, president of Partner Re Asset Management. But he warned that based on earnings now forecast, stocks appeared to be "pretty fully valued," suggesting more limited gains in the near future.
 Volume was moderate, with 1.36 billion shares traded on the New York Stock Exchange, down from 1.51 billion on Friday. Advancing issues outpaced decliners on the Big Board by about 7 to 3 and by about 2 to 1 on Nasdaq. Of the roughly 3,400 stocks traded on the New York exchange on Monday, 490 closed at 52-week highs.
 Computer-chip-related stocks were buoyed by a report from the Semiconductor Industry Association showing that worldwide chip sales in the third quarter rose 13.7 percent from the quarter before, driven by strong demand for PC's. The Philadelphia Semiconductor index rose to a 52-week high.
 Shares of Intel, the largest chip maker, led both the Dow and the Nasdaq composite indexes higher, rising $1.09, or 3.3 percent, to $34.04.
 Sun Microsystems, the most heavily traded Nasdaq stock, with volume of more than 122 million shares, rose 44 cents, or 11 percent, to $4.39. Its executive vice president for global sales said there were signs of a recovery in technology spending by financial services and telecommunications companies.
 Marsh & McLennan advanced $2.13, or nearly 5 percent, to $44.88, after an announcement that Lawrence J. Lasser would leave as chief executive of its Putnam Investments unit, less than a week after civil charges of securities fraud against Putnam by regulators.
 Shares of Kellogg, the large cereal producer, rose $1.77, or 5.3 percent, to $34.90. Its quarterly earnings rose sharply, surpassing Wall Street expectations.
 The stock of the energy company Dynegy rose 16 cents, or 4 percent, to $4.17, after it said it would sell Illinois Power to the Exelon Corporation.
 In bond trading, Treasury prices slid in reaction to the strong manufacturing report. By late in the day, the benchmark 10-year Treasury note declined 13/32, to 99 8/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, climbed to 4.34 percent from 4.29 percent on Friday. The 30-year Treasury bond dropped 16/32 to 103 3/32; its yield rose to 5.16 percent from 5.14 percent.

HEADLINE: Palestinians And Israelis Still Speaking, In a Whisper 

BYLINE:  By GREG MYRE 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Nov. 3 

 BODY:
More than two months after Israel broke off contacts with the Palestinians, senior leaders from the two sides have quietly resumed behind-the-scenes discussions in an effort to revive the stalled Middle East peace plan.
 But violence persists. Acting on a tip, Israeli troops raided Azun, in the West Bank, and a 16-year-old Palestinian bomber, Sabih Abu Saud, blew himself up as soldiers were closing in, the military said. One soldier was slightly wounded. 
 Palestinians traditionally praise family members who carry out attacks against Israel. But the bomber's father, Kamal Abu Saud, was critical of Al Aksa Martyrs Brigades, which recruited the youth. "He was just a little boy, and those who sent him should have left him alone," Mr. Saud was quoted as saying in a report by The Associated Press.
In another case, a Palestinian, Tariq Hussein, 25, who was wanted in the shooting death of an Israeli girl, turned himself in at a checkpoint in Qalqilya, on the West Bank, the military said. It was not immediately clear why the suspect turned himself in -- an extremely rare occurrence. But the military had recently searched his home, and family members may have pressured him.
Regarding peace talks, Shaul Mofaz, the defense minister, acknowledged that he had been meeting Palestinians. He declined to identify them, but Palestinian and Israeli officials identified Mr. Mofaz's negotiating partner as Salam Fayyad, the Palestinian finance minister.
In another development on Monday, the National Labor Court temporarily barred a nationwide strike called by the country's large labor federation, the Histadrut. The court permitted a four-hour labor protest, which was staged by some workers. But it also directed the Finance Ministry and the federation to resume talks and report back on Thursday.
The Histadrut, which represents hundreds of thousands of government and private-sector workers, called the strike to protest government plans to overhaul the pension system, which would raise the retirement age and reduce benefits.
Finance Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has been trying to reduce substantially the government's role in the economy, which has been in turmoil for the past three years. 
But Israeli labor groups have resisted the cutbacks, saying they fall disproportionately on poor and working-class Israelis.

Israeli Aid Adjustment Proposed
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (Reuters) -- The Bush administration will ask Congress to give Israel $2.22 billion in military assistance in fiscal year 2005, $60 million more than in 2004, the State Department announced Monday. The increase is in line with a 1990's agreement that reduces economic assistance to Israel by $120 million a year while adding $60 million a year to the military component of the package, the largest Washington gives to any country.

HEADLINE: Consumer Credit 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 "Buyer Beware" (editorial, Oct. 27) doesn't mention an important point about credit information sharing among business affiliates. 
Restricting information flow would obscure lenders' knowledge about customers and increase lending rates. This would reduce overall credit access, particularly for traditionally underserved populations. 
 You suggest that a patchwork of state laws, not uniform national standards, would better serve consumers. This balkanization of our credit reporting system, however, would slow economic growth and fail to help consumers needing assistance. Under this scenario, the only people to be extended credit would be those who have little problem obtaining it. 
You say that affiliate sharing can invite identity theft. In fact, these crimes are best fought when law enforcement and financial institutions can easily monitor accounts, detecting illegal activities. The Senate should pass the bipartisan National Consumer Credit Reporting System Improvement Act on behalf of consumers.

JOHN E. SUNUNU
U.S. Senator from New Hampshire
Washington, Oct. 31, 2003

HEADLINE: Make Baghdad Pay 

BYLINE:  By Mark Medish; Mark Medish, a lawyer, was deputy assistant secretary of the Treasury from 1997 to 2000.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
The economic consequences of regime change in Iraq could get worse if the United States, Great Britain and their coalition partners act on radical impulses to make grand gestures. A case in point is Iraq's sovereign debt.
 Iraq's debt includes $40 billion owed to Paris Club official creditors, most notably Japan, France, Germany and Russia; at least $30 billion to other official creditors; at least $3 billion to London Club commercial banks; and perhaps $10 billion owed to corporate creditors. 
 What is to be done? Already we hear calls from the right and the left to impose what might be called a "zero option"; that is, cancellation of Iraq's debt. From the right, Richard Perle and William F. Buckley Jr. have called for freeing Iraq of its "odious debt" on moral grounds. From the other end of the political spectrum, Oxfam and Jubilee Iraq have taken much the same position, while Joseph Stiglitz, the Nobelist, is advocating relief on more prudent grounds, citing the lessons of the 1919 Treaty of Versailles, which required Germany to pay heavy war reparations. 
These recommendations, though doubtless well intentioned, are misguided. A country like Iraq, with the world's second-largest proven oil reserves, should be expected to be able to pay its obligations. Furthermore, the moral charge that the debts are odious is simply too sweeping. Acting on it would be bad for Iraq and would set a damaging precedent for the international financial system.
For Iraq to normalize its external financial relations, it must respect one of the first principles of the rule of law: contracts should be honored. Without this presumption, markets cannot work. The threshold for overturning the presumption must be kept high to prevent chaos. In the case of Iraq, the threshold has not been met. 
Several myths have gained currency in the debt debate. The first is that Iraq's debts are invalid because they were accumulated under Saddam Hussein's regime. This is overbroad and misleading. First, much of the debt, including the bulk of what Iraq owes to banks and corporations, went to finance civilian construction -- roads, hospitals, apartments and utilities. By contrast, military-related debt can and should be separated out and perhaps even forgiven. 
It's worth remembering, too, that much of Iraq's debt was incurred in the 1970's and 1980's, before sanctions were imposed, when the United States was willingly doing business with the Hussein regime.
Another myth is that historical precedents dictate that zeroing out the debt would be prudent. Post-Versailles Germany is a frequently cited case. But there is an important difference between punitive reparations and commercial debt incurred by a country for civilian projects. Moreover, in the last decade countries like Poland, Egypt and Yugoslavia have escaped their heavy debts not because their debts were forgiven but because the financial community created reasonable long-term repayment plans.
Third is the myth that companies have already written off the Iraqi debts and no longer care about them. This is ridiculous. How companies account for bad debts on their books is irrelevant to the legal status of their claims. It would be a perverse result to extinguish debt simply because a debtor has not paid.
Iraq is entitled to have its special case heard. So far it has been granted an official moratorium through 2004. When the international community decides to begin tackling the wider debt problem, it should follow several simple maxims: avoid radicalism and bad precedents; promote an orderly, market-friendly debt repayment schedule based on financial analysis; and encourage creative solutions, including debt swaps.
Finally, for solutions to be meaningful, Iraq must negotiate with creditors on its own behalf. This, after all, is a major aspect of sovereignty. 
The Iraqis should also favor an orderly debt repayment process. The country has been a financial rogue state for the past 12 years. What the new Iraq needs is a reputation for honoring its word.

CORRECTION-DATE: November 6, 2003

 CORRECTION:
An Op-Ed article on Tuesday about Iraq's foreign debt should have more fully disclosed the background of its author, Mark Medish. Mr. Medish, an international lawyer and former Treasury official, represents corporations that are owed money by Iraq.

HEADLINE: THE STRUGGLE FOR IRAQ: BUSINESS AND FINANCE; 
Iraq's Economy Is Mostly Stagnant, Propped Up by U.S. Cash and by Hopes of Safer Days

BYLINE:  By ALEX BERENSON 

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 3 

 BODY:
The state-owned shoe factory here was once sophisticated enough to make shoes for Bally, the Swiss luxury goods company.
 But that was 20 years ago, before wars and sanctions, before Saddam Hussein's army became the factory's biggest customer. Now, with Mr. Hussein and most of his army gone, production has plunged to 1,800 pairs of shoes a day from 5,000 at the start of the year, according to Riadh Hassan Ali, the company's design manager. There are scarcely any customers. 
 Six months after President Bush declared major military operations in Iraq over, the economy here is largely in stasis, propped up by American cash but showing little progress. The privatization of Iraq's decrepit state-owned industries like the shoe factory, is on hold; foreign investors have stayed home. 
Many small and mid-size businesses have laid off workers, according to a new survey of 400 companies nationwide. Iraq's oil fields, a treasure trove second only to Saudi Arabia's, are finding that recovery from years of neglect and more recent looting is slow.
The reason for the stagnation is as plain as the concrete walls in front of the Oil Ministry or the thump of the mortar rounds here at night. Until the streets are safe, the economy here will grow weakly at best, senior Iraqi officials say.
"Without security, you can't make any growth, any progress," said Sami Matti, director general of Iraq's Planning Ministry. "No one will be encouraged to come."
The success of Iraq's economy is crucial to the American project here. It is meant to serve as a regional example, demonstrating that a free market works and provides opportunities -- especially to the young -- that curb the frustrations on which terrorist recruiters thrive.
In the long run, the United States hopes that Iraq will become an economic model for the Middle East, said George Wolfe, director of economic policy for the American-led occupation authority. 
If all goes well, Mr. Wolfe said, low tariffs and a strong financial system will attract foreign investment. Bloated state-owned industries will be privatized and made efficient. Iraq's oil wealth will provide a base, but the country will diversify its economy and avoid the "resource curse" that has plagued countries like Nigeria, where oil wealth has been squandered by corruption.
"I view our mission as working in support of Iraqis to help them build a platform from which their economy could grow," Mr. Wolfe said.
There are some signs of life. Iraq is short on capital, short on electricity and short on management expertise, but it does not lack economic enthusiasm. At the shoe plant and on the streets of its Karada neighborhood, Iraqis seem surprisingly, perhaps irrationally, hopeful about their prospects.
The same survey of small and mid-size companies that found widespread layoffs also found that 57 percent of the companies expected their prospects to improve over the next six months. Only 11 percent thought business would get worse. Almost 60 percent of the companies said they would hire new employees in the next six months.
"Despite everything, it's better than before," said Haidar Ghazy, who owns a clothing store in Karada. "Of course we're optimistic. We have a saying: 'If you are optimistic, you'll find good things.' "
Given the importance that confidence plays in the investment and spending that drive economic growth, that positive attitude is one of the biggest strengths Iraq's economy now has.
Another, of course, is oil, at least in theory. Iraq's state-owned oil fields are slowly increasing output. On good days, they produce as much as two million barrels, mostly from the south, said Shamkhi al-Faraj, chief of economic development for the Oil Ministry. That is nearly as much as Iraq averaged last year, according to a recent speech by Thamir Ghadhban, the industry's chief executive. 
But bigger decisions about oil, like who Iraq will hire to develop its fields, will wait until it has a stable government. Because that is not expected until at least next year, no development deals will by signed until late 2004 at the earliest, Mr. Faraj said.
If the Iraqi economy is to lift off, oil is the key, and the current confused politics and insecurity suggest that it will be a long time before the country's potential is fulfilled.
Other problems also loom. Even if the transition to democracy is swift, with early free elections, economic growth happens slowly under the best of circumstances, and Iraq is starting in a very deep hole.
After a generation of misrule under Mr. Hussein, who built a huge military infrastructure while neglecting civilian investment, and a dozen years of United Nations sanctions, Iraq's unemployment rate tops 50 percent. Its per-capita production of $2,400 ranked 162nd worldwide in 2002, trailing India, Indonesia and Syria, according to the Central Intelligence Agency's world fact book.
In the six months since Mr. Hussein's government fell, the economy has stagnated, and may have shrunk, though the Planning Ministry has been unable to assemble reliable data for this period.
Output at state-owned companies like the shoe factory has plunged. Electricity fails sporadically, a problem that may take years to overcome, and many major roads damaged in the war need repairs.
Such problems will not be solved quickly. But the occupying forces are trying to plant seeds for growth, especially in the financial system. The October introduction of the new Iraqi dinar, which replaced two older versions, has been largely successful, and the currency has strengthened in value against the dollar. The occupying authorities have also eliminated most tariffs, leading to a retail boomlet in Baghdad for luxury products like imported air conditioners. Some small companies have started up. 
Still, the road ahead looks arduous. For a developing country, average long-run growth of 5 percent a year per capita is excellent, and 7 percent is stellar. Even if Iraq managed to achieve the latter figure, an all-but-impossible task given its high birth rate, Iraq would need 15 years until it produced as much per capita as Thailand does today.
The shoe factory illustrates just how much ground the country must make up. The state-owned company that runs the factory employs 3,000 people around Iraq to make shoes, as well as a few other leather goods.
Plant No. 7, where the company makes men's dress shoes, is clean and cheery. Under high ceilings, men stamp out pieces from shiny leather hides, while women stitch together shoe tops at sewing machines. With the scattering of the army and the police, a search for new clients has begun.
With the collapse of Mr. Hussein's rule, Iraq no longer subsidizes imports of leather hides, a subsidy that the company passed along to its customers. "Because we bought it very cheap from the government, we sell it very cheap to the citizens," said Mr. Ali, the design manager. "The profit was controlled."
Now, however, the company must buy its hides on the open market, and pass those increased costs along to customers. So prices have risen, and sales have dropped, Mr. Ali said.
But the company has not had to fire anyone, because the United States does not want to put more unemployed Iraqis on the streets and risk worsening the security crisis. So the occupying authorities are paying the salaries of all 3,000 workers, even if they have nothing to do.
In this, the shoe company is no different from any of Iraq's 53 state-owned companies, whose workers are all still being paid by the occupation, at a cost of several million dollars each month. The cost is small compared with the others the occupation is incurring, but the payments show that for now, security considerations have topped the United States' hope of making the state-owned companies more efficient.
With wages subsidized but the shoe company forbidden to fire anyone, estimating profit or loss is impossible, much less planning long-term investments in new equipment, said Ali Hadi, a manager. "We can't calculate these things now," he said. "When next year comes, we will calculate next year."
Mr. Hadi is optimistic and believes that Iraq will be prosperous in three or four years. But as long as terrorist attacks continue, this manager is not counting on foreign investment.
"Capital is a coward," he said.

HEADLINE: BOLDFACE NAMES 

BYLINE:  By Joyce Wadler; with Campbell Robertson

 BODY:
Dog on a Hot Tenement Roof
Before the opening of "Cat on a Hot Tin Roof" at the Music Box Theater on Sunday night, MAYOR MICHAEL R. BLOOMBERG was talking about the importance of the theater to the New York City economy and joking that down at City Hall they sometimes called him BIG DADDY. 
 "We depend on tourists," the mayor said. "As they say in another TENNESSEE WILLIAMS play, we depend on the courtesy of strangers." 
 "It's kindness," several people in the audience shouted back.
Veteran politician that the mayor is, he ignored the hecklers. 
At intermission we saw PATRICK ("Star Trek") STEWART talking with KYLE ("Sex and the City") MacLACHLAN. Mr. Stewart's sentences were long dramatic affairs with acts and intermissions. He would say something, then pause theatrically while the reporter's pen hovered above the notebook -- then come down with the last few words like the denouement of a Greek tragedy. "I haven't seen any Williams . . ." he began. Then the pause. Men were born, aged and died. Redwoods grew. Mr. MacLachlan looked into his drink. 
". . . for decades," Mr. Stewart concluded. 
"Cat" stars NED BEATTY in the role of Big Daddy, JASON PATRIC as his apathetic and morose son, BRICK, and ASHLEY JUDD as MAGGIE, Brick's wife. 
At curtain, Mr. Patric might as well have still been in character: as members of the cast were taking their bows, he rolled his eyes. 
At the after-party at Tavern on the Green, Ms. Judd was in the press room talking with everyone, but Mr. Patric had come and gone. We caught up with him in another room, where he was sitting at a table with a plateful of food. His publicist was telling him that someone wanted a picture of the three stars.
"Do we have to do this now?" Mr. Patric asked, angrily. Told yes, he picked up his plate and walked into the press room, where he handed it to his publicist. She whispered something in his ear. Mr. Patric bared his teeth and the publicist did the spinach check. 
"You're fine," she said.
"Don't worry," Mr. Patric said, "I won't be smiling."
We were the last of Ms. Judd's 238 interviews about Tennessee Williams and the South, and when she reached us, she was weary. But when we turned the conversation to basketball at her alma mater, the University of Kentucky, and asked about TUBBY SMITH and RICK PITINO, she perked right up. 
"Tubby Smith is one of the finest human beings walking the face of this planet," Ms. Judd said. 
Asked if her family was there, she said no -- they had been to rehearsals and would come to the show again later. 
"Opening night is a little bit like a birthday party where you never get to eat the cake," Ms. Judd said. "You have this tremendous sense of anticipation and then you talk to the niece of the lawyer for the theater the whole night. She's a nice girl."
We're sure she's lovely.
"She's adorable," Ms. Judd said. "But family comes and thinks you're going to talk about this tremendously liminal rite of passage and extraordinary moment of fulmination on the stage and you just don't. You trade cold cream at the end of the night to take the makeup off."
She departed and Mr. Beatty came over. He was wearing his clan tartan -- from the MACBETH clan -- and he was a great talker. Sitting with him, one might have been sittin' on the porch glider with a couple of bourbons. Asked if he had based his interpretation of Big Daddy on someone specific, he recalled a man he had met in a restaurant bar during the filming of "Deliverance" in Georgia, years ago.
"A big, red-haired fella," he remembered. "Tall and big. Very red. And he grabs my hand and says, 'How ya doing there, boy?' He was frightening. There was a steak knife on the bar and I actually reached over and got my hand on the steak knife. He had ahold of my hand, you see." Later, after the red-haired man had gone off "to intimidate somebody else," Mr. Beatty was approached by a man whose job it was to watch over the big red-headed man because he got into so much trouble. 
"He said, 'Aw, don't worry about him. He's very wealthy and he drinks a lot,' " Mr. Beatty remembered. "But there was something about his roughness that I think about sometimes when I play the part. It's not who I think Big Daddy is, but I think he's capable of the same thing."

HEADLINE: In Resigning Oil Post, Jailed Russian Hints at Political Fight 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN LEE MYERS and SABRINA TAVERNISE 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Nov. 3 

 BODY:
Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky resigned as chief executive of Russia's richest company, Yukos Oil, on Monday even as he defiantly vowed to continue a public -- and possibly a political -- campaign "to build an open and truly democratic society in Russia."
 Mr. Khodorkovsky, imprisoned since Oct. 25 on charges of embezzlement, fraud and tax evasion, said in a statement that he was stepping aside to shield the company from what he and others have called a politically motivated prosecution. 
 But two people in a position to explain Mr. Khodorkovsky's thinking said his resignation cleared the way not only for his legal defense but also for a campaign for political office, possibly even a challenge to Vladimir V. Putin in presidential elections scheduled for next March. 
Jailhouse campaigns have a precedent in Russia's new and chaotic democracy, but a challenge to Mr. Putin, whose re-election next year has been considered a given, could send politics in Russia's new and chaotic democracy in unpredictable directions. It could also present Russians with a stark choice between two of the country's most influential men, one representing power, the other money.
"He is a man with vision who would not be excluding any options if circumstances were to force him into one corner or another," said one of the people close to Mr. Khodorkovsky. "He would respond to that."
Asked if that could include a presidential challenge, he added, "That is an option that he could not exclude."
The other person said, "I think the events are pushing him to getting involved in politics." 
Mr. Khodorkovsky's announcement severs his managerial role with Yukos, which is in the last stages of a merger with its smaller rival, Sibneft, to create the world's fifth largest private oil company. Mr. Khodorkovsky still has an enormous financial stake in the company, though prosecutors last week froze 40 percent of the company's shares, controlled by him and his partner, Platon Lebedev, who is also in jail.
A spokesman for Group Menatep, the financial company controlled by Mr. Khodorkovsky and Mr. Lebedev, said Mr. Khodorkovsky had transferred control of his stocks to another Yukos shareholder, Leonid B. Nevzlin, who is now in Israel. That leaves Mr. Nevzlin with the authority to vote on behalf of Mr. Khodorkovsky while he remains in prison.
Even before his arrest, Mr. Khodorkovsky distanced himself from the day-to-day operations, appointing an American, Steven M. Theede, as chief operating officer this summer. Mr. Theede took over as acting chief executive after his arrest.
An American citizen at the company's helm could significantly raise the stakes should prosecutors pursue further action -- trying, for example, to confiscate the frozen shares and turn them over to the state.
In his statement, Mr. Khodorkovsky defended the company's successes since its founding in 1996, saying Yukos had erased $3 billion in debt and, apparently in a response to prosecutors' charges of tax evasion, paid "in excess of $5 billion" in taxes this year. "I have to do all I can to pull our work force safely out from under the blows that are being directed at me and my partners," Mr. Khodorkovsky said of his resignation.
Although Yukos has its roots in the shady privatization of state assets in the 1990's, he said the company had become a model of efforts to adapt international standards of accounting and corporate government. 
Yukos stock soared in late trading on news of Mr. Khodorkovsky's resignation, rising 13 percent to $12.65 by the end of the day, though it has still fallen by 20 percent since his arrest.
"Mr. Khodorkovsky's resignation definitely makes the company harder to attack and puts distance between him and Yukos," said Alasdair P. M. Breach, chief economist at Brunswick UBS in Moscow. "Going forward, however, it's unclear to what extent is Putin prepared to let the company go."
There have been new signs of division -- and confusion -- within Mr. Putin's government over the matter.
In an interview published on Monday, Russia's finance minister, Aleksei L. Kudrin, dismissed the idea that the Yukos case would hurt the economy. His remarks came only a day after Mr. Putin's new chief of staff, Dmitri A. Medvedev, had said the opposite, warning prosecutors that their actions were potentially counterproductive. On Friday, Prime Minister Mikhail M. Kasyanov also raised concerns about the investigation's impact.
In an interview published in Kommersant, Mr. Kudrin said the investigation would have no impact on the economy, while the resignation of Mr. Medvedev's predecessor, Aleksandr S. Voloshin, would have a positive one.
He said the departure of Mr. Voloshin, who worked under President Boris N. Yeltsin and strongly defended the interests of business under Mr. Putin, represented a break from the "Yeltsin epoch."
"This marks the end of the Byzantine Empire!" the newspaper quoted him saying. "Will it change the situation for the better or for the worse? Everything will be different now. It is always this way when epochs change. I know that this will benefit the Russian economy."
Mr. Putin has sought to defuse concerns about the investigation, but faces questions at home and abroad. Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel, at a Kremlin meeting on Monday, deviated from a lengthy discussion on the Middle East to question the Russian president on the matter, one official familiar with the discussion said. "He expressed worry about the arrest," the official said, declining to characterize Mr. Putin's response.
European Union leaders are expected to raise the case when Mr. Putin meets them in Rome this week.
Many in Russia view the arrest of Mr. Khodorkovsky, 40, as a result of his clear political ambitions. In an interview in his office three weeks before his arrest, Mr. Khodorkovsky said he planned to end his business career when he turned 45 -- in 2008. "Afterward, in one form or another, I'm going to delve into public affairs," he said then.
In his statement on Monday, he said he would remain chairman of Open Russia, the philanthropic and political organization he created beginning in 2001. As improbable as a campaign from prison might seem, at least two other men awaiting trial, in St. Petersburg and the Siberian region of Krasnoyarsk, have won election to regional assemblies from jail.
Irina Y. Yasina, a spokeswoman with Open Russia, refused to discuss the possibility of a political campaign by Mr. Khodorkovsky.
"I cannot comment on this in any case because the person is in prison, and in our country, where the aggression of the authorities is not regulated, I can't put him under such risk," she said. "It's frightening. If we say something about politics, he will not get out of there."

HEADLINE: CAMPAIGN TACTICS BEING REVERSED AS EVENTS SHIFT 

BYLINE:  By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 

 BODY:
In Iowa on Monday, Howard Dean was talking not about the economy, but about the deadly turmoil in Iraq, and what it would mean for the presidential race.
 "It weakens the position of the president and my Democratic opponents," said Dr. Dean, a Democratic contender who, as one of the most vocal critics of the war, cited the attack on a Chinook helicopter that took the lives of 16 American soldiers on Sunday. "There are now almost 400 people dead who wouldn't be dead if that resolution hadn't been passed and we hadn't gone to war." 
 In Birmingham, Ala., in a speech to workers at a warehouse, President Bush talked less about the latest death toll and more about the report late last week of surging third quarter economic growth. 
"Our economy is gaining some momentum," he said, dismissing Democrats who had warned that his tax cuts would devastate the nation's economy. "We've got a consistent and effective strategy, and we're making progress."
The day was a snapshot of the presidential contest, as realities on the ground -- the upbeat economic growth figures and the deadly helicopter attack -- intruded on the best-laid plans of the candidates and this White House.
The Democrats want to blame Mr. Bush for a weak economy that may be finding its step just in time for next year's election, while Mr. Bush is confronting the possibility of campaigning against a backdrop of American casualties and chaos in the war he began.
So in the topsy-turvy world of presidential politics, Mr. Bush was talking up the economy -- the very issue that Democrats have long argued would make him a one-term president. And Democrats were hammering Mr. Bush on the very subject that many Republicans argued would guarantee his re-election: foreign policy.
This could very well prove to be a passing moment in the larger struggle of whether the course of this campaign will be determined more by foreign policy or by the economy. Still, over the last few days there has clearly been an across-the-board recalibration by Democrats and Mr. Bush as they try to keep up -- and capitalize on -- the changing landscape.
So in Alabama on Monday, Mr. Bush combined a somber declaration of perseverance in Iraq with a jaunty assessment of the economy. "Remember this last week, the surprising announcement -- at least, it confounded some of the experts -- that our third-quarter economic growth was vibrant, and that's good," he said. "Inflation is down, and that's good. After-tax incomes are up. People are keeping more of their own money, and that's really important for economic growth."
Several Democrats, meanwhile, moved to retool their message on the economy to account for the new economic figures. Senator John Edwards of North Carolina, who campaigned in Iowa on Monday, said in a telephone interview that the growth figures would mean little to Americans who remain worried about high unemployment.
"Out across the country, people are very worried about jobs, worried about their families, worried about the potential for a plant or facility closing," Mr. Edwards said. "There's no such thing as a jobless recovery."
Wesley K. Clark, a retired general, issued a written statement saying: "On May 1, the president declared 'Mission Accomplished' on Iraq. Yet we still have no plan to bring peace to Iraq and protect our soldiers. President Bush seems ready to declare 'Mission Accomplished' on our economy. I say: 'Not yet Mr. President -- we've lost too many jobs.' "
In Clinton, Iowa, Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts had just finished addressing a lunch when Highland Nichols, a retired construction worker and former chairman of the local county Democratic committee, expressed unvarnished concern to Mr. Kerry about what the economic figures would mean for Democratic hopes of retaking the White House.
"The administration had spokesmen out touting the rebound in the economy," he said, adding: "They were saying this is going to take away the Democratic platform."
Mr. Kerry responded: "I hope we have a good economy. It doesn't change anything that I'm saying or fighting about if we have a good economy. We still have a problem with health care for Americans, right?"
While the economic news may complicate the Democratic case against Mr. Bush, some Democrats are still struggling to define their positions on Iraq. Dr. Dean, for one, argues that his opponents who favored the war resolution were now in an even weaker political position given the events in Iraq.
"I think it was going to be a big issue anyway," Dr. Dean said in a telephone interview from Iowa. "But it certainly is going to be a more divisive issue among the Democrats, because things are clearly not going well. I think it works in favor of the Democrats -- if I become the nominee."
The candidates who voted for the resolution include Mr. Kerry, Mr. Edwards, Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri and Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut. General Clark, a retired general, has fiercely criticized Mr. Bush's Iraq policy, but last month in an interview described his position as the same as those members of Congress. He said he, too, probably would have voted for the resolution, but later retracted his statement.
Three other Democratic presidential candidates -- Representative Dennis J. Kucinich of Ohio, the Rev. Al Sharpton of New York and former Senator Carol Moseley Braun of Illinois -- have also been strong opponents of the war.
Those Democrats who voted for the resolution have been challenged on the votes almost wherever they go, from farms in Iowa to town hall meetings in New Hampshire to nearly every one of their televised debates. They are now struggling to defend the original votes, and move quickly to condemn Mr. Bush in an area where all the Democrats now view him as vulnerable.
"But what is truly infuriating is the fact that this administration, the Bush administration, conducted a foreign policy that so pushed our allies away," Mr. Lieberman told a women's missionary group at the Williams Chapel A.M.E. Church in Orangeburg, S.C., adding: "And then had no plans for what to do the day after Saddam fell that we're now in a situation which we ought not to be in, which is that American soldiers are almost totally alone in keeping the peace there. We saw the loss of 16 more yesterday."
Mr. Gephardt, who was one of the original sponsors of the Iraq resolution, said in Concord, N.H., that the nation could not step back now.
"We have to prevail," Mr. Gephardt told reporters. "We have to bring democracy to Iraq. We cannot fail. If you think Afghanistan was a terrorist training camp, you wait. If you leave Iraq, it will be a terrorist training camp the likes of which would make Afghanistan look simple. In our own deep self-interest, to prevent future acts of terrorism, we have to succeed."
He, too, proceeded to criticize Mr. Bush. "We need a president who can get the world to work together with us to solve this problem," Mr. Gephardt said.
Mr. Kerry struck a similar note in Iowa. "What the president is doing is in fact exposing the troops to greater danger than if he did the diplomacy correctly at bringing other countries into this effort," he said.
