HEADLINE: Footing the Bill For Computer Lab 

BYLINE:  By JEFFREY SELINGO

 BODY:
FOR Nancy Couto, the director of technology for the Armada school district in suburban Detroit, walking into a computer lab at the high school is like stepping back in time. There, beat-up machines still run Windows 95 and barely chug along on 120-megahertz processors and 16 megabytes of memory, a tiny fraction of what even the most basic new desktop comes with these days.
 It has been seven years since voters approved a bond issue that bought many of the 750 computers that sit in nine labs across the district today. With a bare-bones budget and school officials unwilling to ask voters to borrow money again, Ms. Couto has had to scavenge parts from dead computers to repair problems with the machines that are still hanging on. 
 "They're so old we can't even buy parts for them anymore," Ms. Couto said. "I tell teachers not to shut them down after class. It takes five minutes just to boot them back up, and when you're in class, you just don't have that kind of time." 
With states facing big budget deficits because of a long period of weak economic growth, public schools have been forced to tighten their spending, often choosing to pay only for basic services and not for what they see as luxury items, like new computers. One result is outmoded equipment that makes it hard for teachers to use technology in their lessons or to engage students who have become accustomed to faster computers at home.
Rather than wait for the budget situation to improve, some cash-strapped schools are asking for money from parents' groups -- including foundations established expressly to help pay for technology purchases -- to buy computers. Other districts are looking for donations of used equipment from local businesses and colleges.
"The bar is higher for technology in the schools," said Peter Grunwald, president of Grunwald Associates, a consulting firm in Burlingame, Calif., that focuses on school technology. "They are operating in an environment of expectations that is formed by students who get to play with everything in their own homes." 
The budget cuts, which have also reduced dollars for support staffs and teacher training, could not have come at a worse time, Mr. Grunwald said. "School districts were finally turning their attention to how to use all this stuff in the classroom."
Outdated computers are usually acceptable for the lower grades, where they can be used for basic tasks like word processing. But teaching advanced applications to older students with aging machines is nearly impossible. Thomas Watchorn, a computer teacher at the middle school in Ms. Couto's district, said he had given up on the desktop computers in his lab for video editing or Web design. On most days, he is happy if the machines simply function. "I never have 30 computers that exactly work the way they are supposed to," he said. Screen colors change unexpectedly, programs shut down without warning, and machines crash. 
One of the labs in Armada Middle School is so riddled with problems that the computers there are not used at all. Mr. Watchorn said he wondered how long it would be before his lab suffered the same fate. "If we're lucky, maybe two more years," he said.
Given the conditions under which school computers operate -- multiple users throughout the day, some of them less than gentle -- the machines never last as long as the average home or office desktop. Ideally, schools need to replace equipment at least every four to five years, school technology directors agree. But that schedule is usually only met with an infusion of cash, typically through a bond issue for technology or for a new school. 
Nearly half the 1,100 computers in the public schools in Fitchburg, Mass., are less than four years old, thanks to money furnished to build a new high school that opened there in 2000. But the warranty on the high school computers expires in June, and "then we'll be in real trouble," said Art Newcombe, the district's director of technology. 
Elsewhere in the district, most of the computers are five to seven years old. Mr. Newcombe's budget has been cut by $200,000, or 84 percent, over the last three years, and many of the technology grants he has received are for teacher training, not new equipment. 
Like technology directors in other districts, Mr. Newcombe is trying to get more out of what he has by relying on networked computers. Instead of buying new desktops, some schools have opted to buy servers, which cost about $5,000 each and provide the needed disk space for 40 or 50 outdated computers, as well as a connection to a common printer. "Servers expand the life of our computers and give us more versatility," Mr. Newcombe said.
Even so, with state lawmakers looking to pinch every dollar possible, putting budgets in constant flux, some school officials are reluctant to begin the often long process of purchasing new equipment. In New York last year, for instance, Gov. George E. Pataki proposed eliminating a state program that provided as much as 50 percent of the cost of new computers. The legislature later preserved the program, but not before some school districts decided to delay their technology plans. 
"A lot of schools were in no man's land," said Pete Reilly, the director of the Lower Hudson Regional Information Center, a consortium of 62 school districts north of New York City. "Without that state money, there was no way they could have afforded to buy that equipment." 
Faced with that uncertainty, many schools have decided to bypass state and local lawmakers altogether to subsidize their technology purchases. Some have turned to their own private nonprofit foundations, a new kind of parent organization that has gained in popularity in recent years, particularly in wealthier districts. The foundations help pay for items like playground equipment, music and art classes and technology. 
The Mount Laurel Public Education Fund in New Jersey, for example, donates $30,000 annually to the Mount Laurel school district, most of which is used for technology. "Sure the schools could survive without our money, but you could always have better equipment and better education," said Kevin Scarborough, the president of the foundation. It was created in 1994 and raises most of its funds from an annual golf tournament. Now its leaders are considering art and sports-memorabilia auctions to increase their donation to the schools. "Quite frankly, the better the education system, the better the town, the better the property values," Mr. Scarborough said. 
Although the money from the parents foundation is a drop in the district's $900,000 annual technology budget, "it's something I count on every year," said Ken Ruhland, an assistant superintendent in Mount Laurel. Because the donation, which this year paid for interactive whiteboards, comes in the fall, well after the district has planned its other computer purchases, it allows officials to buy "the latest in technology," Mr. Ruhland said. 
In other districts, officials are looking for donations of used equipment. When elected officials in the town of Mansfield, Mass., opposed a $200,000 request for new computers last year, Lincoln Lynch, the assistant superintendent of the 5,000-student school district, sent 300 letters to colleges and businesses in the region asking for their old machines. He has since received 346 computers. Students and local retirees refurbished about 250 of them and placed them in classrooms and labs, with the rest used for spare parts. 
To control the cost of overhauling the used computers -- a factor that leads many schools to refuse to accept second-hand computers -- Mr. Lynch limits his donations to Pentium II computers in groups of 12 or more. "We need computers, businesses and colleges need to get rid of hazardous waste, and colleges need students to be trained using the latest technology," said Mr. Lynch, who estimates that he has saved at least $150,000 by using donated machines. "To me, it's a win-win situation."
But not everyone sees it that way. Howie Schaffer of the Public Education Network, which coordinates community groups involved with schools, said that gifts from foundations and donations of used equipment allow schools to shirk their duties. "The fact of the matter is they are taking away a very critical district responsibility, and it will be almost impossible to give it back to them," Mr. Schaffer said.

(Photo by Tim Shaffer for The New York Times)(pg. F1); TRIAGE -- Nancy Couto, the technology director for a school district near Detroit, and her aging machines. She scavenges parts from dead computers to repair problems with machines that are still hanging on. (Photo by Jeffrey Sauger for the New York Times)(pg. F6)

HEADLINE: Dominican-Made Powder Remedy Is Poisonous, Health Officials Say 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA

 BODY:
A powder sold to Dominicans for years as a remedy for everything from body odor to foot fungus is highly poisonous, health officials warned yesterday, and New York City is trying to persuade botanicas, the herbal medicine shops that cater to Hispanic communities, to stop selling it.
 The substance, litargirio, contains high levels of lead, which can cause irreversible brain damage when it enters the bloodstream. Several companies in the Dominican Republic make it, distributing it as a yellow or orange powder in cellophane packets, and some have exported it to the United States for years. The powder is generally sprinkled on the skin, where it is not readily absorbed into the system, but once it is on the hands it can be ingested by accident. 
 Of eight botanicas in Washington Heights and the Bronx checked recently by the city's Department of Health and Mental Hygiene, five carried litargirio, the health commissioner, Thomas R. Frieden, said yesterday at a news conference in Washington Heights. Officials said the powder was also sold at some bodegas, pharmacies and beauty supply stores.
"There is absolutely no health benefit from using it, only danger," Dr. Frieden said. "If you're using it, stop right away, and go to a doctor to get a blood test for lead. If you have any of it, call 311, and we'll come and get it."
Litargirio is just a small piece of a vast economy of traditional ethnic remedies sold in little shops around the city, a trade conducted in various languages and without much official oversight. In Chinese neighborhoods earlier this year, stores that stock folk cures did a brisk business in herbal concoctions said to ward off SARS.
The unregulated trade in immigrant communities is not limited to curatives. City health officials said they had found unsafe levels of lead in imported cosmetics and ceramic pots sold in some areas.
There are so many such products being imported that Dr. Frieden said he was not surprised that the danger of litargirio had escaped official notice in this country, though it has been sold here for decades.
Moises Perez, executive director of Alianza Dominicana, a community service group, said that litargirio was widely used by Dominicans as a burn remedy and as a tonic for sore feet, among other things, but that no one knew how widely because it is unregulated. "It was news to us that it was dangerous, and that it had lead content," said Mr. Perez, who joined Dr. Frieden at the news conference. "But when we talked about it, everyone on my staff knew about it, knew someone who had used it."
Litargirio is legal because, until recently, the government was not aware of it, officials said. Now, the federal Food and Drug Administration is considering banning it.
City officials stressed yesterday that lead paint remained the main source of lead poisoning in New York, far ahead of litargirio. They said there were no particular cases they could attribute to litargirio. Dr. Frieden said that except in extreme cases, lead poisoning had no obvious symptoms, making it very hard to detect without a blood test.
The health officials said that they sent letters to stores several days ago asking them not to sell the powder, and that most of the businesses were cooperating.
At about 15 shops canvassed by a reporter in Washington Heights, where thousands of Dominicans live, merchants said that while they had heard of litargirio and knew of its use among Dominicans, they had never sold it. Workers and customers at several stores said a botanica at 182nd Street and Audubon Avenue sold it. But at that shop, a dank place lined with containers, a woman and a man who were separating dried plants near packets of powders insisted that they had never heard of litargirio.
"We don't know what that is, and we don't have it," the woman, who would not give her name, said in Spanish.
At a nearby pharmacy on St. Nicholas Avenue, a clerk said: "That's something they used back in the Dominican Republic. I've heard about it here, but not as much."
Litargirio first came to the attention of public health officials a few months ago in Rhode Island, when several people -- including adolescents who used it as a deodorant -- were found to have severe cases of lead poisoning. Some had lead levels in their blood above 40 micrograms per deciliter, four times the threshold for lead poisoning.
The F.D.A. looked into the matter and issued an advisory last month, warning people not to use the product.
In Rhode Island, officials found that one brand of litargirio was 79 percent lead. In New York, city officials said that the samples they found all had significant lead content, and that the highest was 42 percent.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The city health commissioner, Thomas R. Frieden, far right, and Moises Perez, executive director of the community service group Alianza Dominicana, warned consumers not to use litargirio, which is high in lead. (Photo by Michael Nagle for The New York Times)(pg. B6)

HEADLINE: ART GUIDE 

 BODY:
 A selective listing by Times critics of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. At many museums, children under 12 and members are admitted free. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free unless noted. * denotes a highly recommended show.

Art Fair

PRINT FAIR, Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and 67th Street, (212) 674-6095, through Sunday. If you appreciate fine art prints, you should not miss this show. Always a superior production, the International Fine Print Dealers Association's annual fair regularly offers a terrific abundance of graphic skill, ingenuity and imagination. In its 13th incarnation 87 dealers will display everything from Rembrandt and Durer to Picasso, Chuck Close and young, emerging contemporaries. The prices are as low as a few hundred dollars and as high as $1 million. Hours: today and tomorrow, noon to 7 p.m.; Sunday, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $15. (Ken Johnson).

Museums

* "BESIDE 'THE ROSE': SELECTED WORKS BY JAY DeFEO," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3600, through Feb. 29. The Bay Area legend Jay DeFeo spent eight years painting "The Rose," which accumulated nearly a ton of pigment, built up at its thickest to 11 inches. This show includes 25 works from a career that spanned 40 years, out of which "The Rose" was only the most conspicuous part. Weight, scale, material experimentation, surface modulation, muted color and centripetal form: these were among the conceptual through-lines of DeFeo's art, with mystical ideas conveyed (but never stated outright) via transparent signs of physical exertion. "The Rose" is like a mandala. It is also an artifact of intractable effort, with a beauty that you can appreciate only when you stand in front of it and see how light plays across its face, in which there seem to be buried pentimenti of color. Hours: Wednesdays, Thursdays, Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 1 to 9 p.m. Admission: $12; students and 62+, $9.50 (Michael Kimmelman).

* "EL GRECO," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710, through Jan. 11. The world is full of second-class El Grecos, but they are not in this first-class show. The portraits are fresh, true to life and understated. Elsewhere, El Greco emotes. The pitch hardly varies or drops. It's no wonder people tend to fall in love with him when they are young. Modern artists especially love him, as if he were a protomodernist. As the Belgian painter Luc Tuymans says of El Greco's work: "Everything goes upward. That's its mystical meaning. It's about the evaporation of material life." The show is also gorgeously installed. Hours: Sundays and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays, to 9 p.m. Admission: $12; students and 65+, $7 (Kimmelman).

* "PHILIP GUSTON," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710, through Jan. 4. A handsome, eloquent retrospective. Even now the late pictures, from the 1970's, have a shock value nearly unsurpassed in recent art. Guston let loose the demons and out they tumbled, like clowns from a Volkswagen. But in crucial ways, as this show demonstrates, Guston's work didn't change as much as people first thought. The transitional decade leading up to the late work may be Guston's most fascinating and underrated: soulful abstractions that have the rough, barely muffled anger of raised voices approaching from the other side of a closed door. Then the door bursts open. Just before he died, Guston painted a sweet, pathetic head, like a bandaged Olmec rock, gazing dubiously up a rubbly hill. It is his self-portrait as Sisyphus: the artist, an eternal pessimist, hoping against hope, awaits the avalanche that we can't yet see tumbling toward him. Hours and admission: See above (Kimmelman).

* "HUNT FOR PARADISE: COURT ARTS OF IRAN, 1501-1576," Asia Society, 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street, (212) 288-6400, through Jan. 18. Islam is constantly in the news now, but exhibitions of Islamic art are rare. This international loan show, of exceptional beauty, features objects from the Safavid dynasty, which began as a Sufi order and ended up ruling an empire. In the process, it developed an exquisite court art, which is sampled here. Included are pages from the great Book of Kings painted for Shah Tahmasp, a famous carpet from the Poldi Pezzoli Museum in Milan and an even more beautiful one from Boston. The piece de resistance is a glorious, mint-condition silk applique hanging, hidden away in Hungary and being exhibited for the first time in nearly a century. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays to 9 p.m. Admission: $7; students and 65+, $5 (Holland Cotter).

* "THE JEWISH JOURNEY: FREDERIC BRENNER'S PHOTOGRAPHIC ODYSSEY," Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000, through Jan. 11. Following the tangled trails of the Jewish diaspora over 25 years in more than 40 countries, the French photographer Frederic Brenner has photographed factory workers in Birobidzhan, Russia; sellers of Christian souvenirs in St. Peter's Square; village women in the mountains of Ethiopia; a wealthy merchant of Calcutta; and countless other examples of Jews who have developed roots in countries around the world. His intent, he writes, was "to document these permutations of survival in exile before they disappeared," and what he found inevitably poses the questions, what is a Jew and who are "the Jews"? Stereotypes tend to be dispelled by those who pass before his camera. The superb quality of his photographs, not only in their conception and composition but also in their technical finish, make this a show that demands a visit. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. (until 11 p.m. the first Saturday of each month). Admission: $6; students and 62+, $3 (Grace Glueck).

* "PETRA: LOST CITY OF STONE," American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West at 79th Street, (212) 769-5100 (through July 6). Petra, an ancient city in what is now the Jordanian part of the Negev desert, was at its zenith from the first century B.C. to the third century A.D. Prosperous, safe and abundantly supplied with water, it was the center of bustling trade in incense, ivory, textiles and other precious goods that flowed through it by camel caravan from points east to the Mediterranean. And it was a highly sophisticated cultural crossroads whose inhabitants carved from rock not only a lively metropolis but also a necropolis of monumental tombs for their kings and leaders. While learned diggers are still uncovering its ruins, this show, said to be the first cultural collaboration between Jordan and the United States, offers a generous glimpse of Petra's vibrant civilization through art objects, architectural elements, photographs and film. The installation, set up with the museum's usual expertise and helpful graphics, is one of the busiest around, but undaunted, Petra comes through. Hours: Daily, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m. Timed tickets to the exhibition are $19; $16.50 for students and 60+; $13 for children under 12 (Glueck).

* "JAMES ROSENQUIST: A RETROSPECTIVE," Guggenheim Museum, Fifth Avenue at 88th Street, (212) 423-3500, through Jan. 25. Notwithstanding the enormous size of many of his paintings, Mr. Rosenquist is a haiku master of the American psyche. Intermittently great, his show is spaciously installed but too big. He is an uneven genius. The early works look as good as ever. His lesser-known forays into sculpture and mixed media, a selling point for the show, don't serve him well here. Invaluable are the collages on which he based many paintings, tools of his trade that demonstrate his process of constructing a work, which, contrary to what you might think, is not mechanical but intuitive. Some of the recent works, with their confetti entanglements of cosmic scenery, fish and flowers, technically adept and erratically magnificent, have something of the psychedelic look of 60's commercial art. They can seem dated in a way the classic paintings refuse to be. A different possibility is that, as before, it will take time to catch up with Mr. Rosenquist, who still has a restless imagination, huge energy and an uncanny knack for spotting how two unlikely things go together. Hours: Wednesdays, Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Fridays, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m. Admission: $12; students and 65+, $8 (Kimmelman).

* SCHOENBERG, KANDINSKY AND THE BLUE RIDER, Jewish Museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue, at 92nd Street, (212) 423-3200, through Feb. 12. Did Arnold Schoenberg's controversial atonal music help Wassily Kandinsky break through to what he called "pure painting" in works like "Sketch for Composition V" from 1911? Perhaps. With paintings, musical scores, concert programs and photographs, this exhibition explores the mostly long-distance friendship between two giants of the early 20th-century avant-garde, and also includes works by other painters in Kandinsky's art collective, the Blue Rider (a fabulous landscape by Gabriele Munter, for example). But its visual coherence comes mostly from Schoenberg's aberrant lugubrious little paintings -- mostly self-portraits that are variously outsiderish, semi-abstract or conventionally representational. They flit in and out of the more stringently Modernist efforts like double agents, lagging behind, then zooming ahead, and have an inadvertent radicality that still astounds. Hours: Sundays through Wednesdays, 11 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Thursdays, to 8 p.m.; Fridays, to 3 p.m. Admission: $10; students and 65+, $7.50 (Roberta Smith).

* "TURNING POINT: ORIBE AND THE ARTS OF 16TH-CENTURY JAPAN," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710, through Jan. 11. A tsunami in a tea bowl; that was Japan in the late 16th century. The social and political tempests were very real. So were the tea bowls, funky, wild-style, fanatically valued little things that distilled the self-image of the Momoyama (1573-1615) period. This carefully shaped show of modest-size objects focuses on one of the era's most dynamic figures, the warrior and cultural arbiter Furuta Oribe, who directly or indirectly had a catalytic effect on art, particularly art associated with that most sacramental of all intimate social events, the tea ceremony. The show has dozens of funky-beautiful ceramic tea vessels in the squashed, pulled and racked Oribe style, along with resplendent genre paintings and texiles. Several objects will be rotated out, and new ones added, on Dec. 3. Hours and admission: See above (Cotter).

Galleries: 57th Street

JAMES BROOKS, Artemis, Greenberg Van Doren, 730 Fifth Avenue, (212) 445-0444, through Nov. 15. Rugged yet lyrical paintings from the 1960's and 70's by one of Abstract Expressionism's more self-effacing personalities: brushed, dripped and poured in unabashedly rich colors, Brooks's canvases have a kind of slowly simmering spontaneity. They are full of art-historical echoes -- Miro, Matisse, de Kooning, Motherwell, Helen Frankenthaler -- and they have an infectious spirit of hedonistic optimism. (Johnson).

* SALLY MANN, "Last Measure," Edwynn Houk, 745 Fifth Avenue, (212) 750-7070, through Nov. 15. In this elegaic visit to Civil War battlefields, Ms. Mann suggests the earth and its relationship to mortality, producing a group of retro-looking, painterly photographs whose minimal but eloquent imagery has the charge of somber poetry. The prints, blurred, often hazy and streaked and spotted with points of light, reflect the technical crudeness of the old camera equipment used by Mathew Brady and Alexander Gardner nearly 150 years ago in the Civil War (Glueck).

Galleries: SoHo

JAN GROOVER, Janet Borden, 560 Broadway, at Prince Street, (212) 431-0166, through Nov. 15. Ms. Groover, the Morandi of photography, continues to produce still lifes that are rigorously formal and evocatively enigmatic. Set against disappearing black backgrounds, her painted bottles, pieces of fruit and swatches of rumpled fabric gather into carefully arranged groups in which subtle relationships of color and texture are brought out by a cool, clear light (Johnson).

PHILIP GUSTON, BRUCE NAUMAN, RAYMOND PETTIBON, Brooke Alexander, 59 Wooster Street, (212) 925-4338, through Dec. 21. Converging from three directions -- Abstract Expressionism, Process Art and California Pop -- three artists arrive at a zone of mordant existentialism. Consisting almost entirely of black-and-white prints, the exhibition sets up an absorbing, triangular conversation among Guston's studio nightmares, Mr. Nauman's harsh wordplay and Mr. Pettibon's mix of hare-brained erudition and comic-book illustration (Johnson).

MICHAEL HEIZER, Peter Freeman, 560 Broadway, at Prince Street, (212) 966-5154, through Nov. 15. A sculptor known for his immense earthworks is here represented by four dryly analytic, gallery-scale works from the late 1960's and 70's. Two circular paintings have curved or angular cutouts, setting up a paradoxical interplay of the positive and the negative. A stone sculpture consists of a circle and sections of circles in smooth pink granite. And a wide, near-Minimalist painting offers a vaguely architectonic composition of rectangles (Johnson).

CHRISTINE HILL, "Home Office," Ronald Feldman, 31 Mercer Street, (212) 226-3232, through Nov. 15. Ms. Hill, a performance artist and conceptualist, has set up a "home office" for running a company called Volksboutique. Every day the artist is there at her desk managing whatever it is she does. Five open steamer trunks neatly display accouterments of her different jobs: reception, management, accounting, public relations and production. Whether this is earnest social activism, witty social satire or thecanny marketing of Ms. Hill herself is something to ponder (Johnson).

ALEX KATZ, "Cartoons," Peter Blum, 99 Wooster Street, (212) 343-0441, through Nov. 15. "Cartoons" in this case refers to an old master technique for transferring images to canvas, wall or panel. Mr. Katz's elegant charcoal drawings of trim, good-looking people on large sheets of brown paper are richly atmospheric, in part because of the burnt sienna pigment that he dusts over the fine perforations that follow the drawing's contours. Seeping through the pinpricks, the brown dust creates a ghost of the drawing on the underlying canvas for the painter (Johnson).

"READING BETWEEN THE LINES," Wooster Arts Space, 147 Wooster Street, (212) 777-6338, through Nov. 22. A six-woman show about meaning in art, organized by Joyce Kozloff. The best works are Julia Randall's grotesquely erotic, hyper-realistic tongues drawn in colored pencil. Also included are Ann Messner's floor mats branded with portentous texts by Edward Said, Salman Rushdie and Susan Sontag; Mira Schor's word paintings; Judith Henry's photographs of pedestrians mixed with brief quotes from their comical conversations; Barbara Zucker's steel cutouts based on wrinkles in women's faces and bodies; and Jeannie Crosby's cut-paper Rococo works hinting at sex and violence (Johnson).

Galleries: Chelsea

DAVID KIMBALL ANDERSON, "Winter Tracks," Linda Durham, 210 11th Avenue, at 25th Street, (212) 337-0025, through Nov. 27. Mr. Anderson, a West Coast sculptor who is 57, produces an intriguing, curiously moody blend of Modernism and kitsch. A rough, glassy, pale green surfboard hovers near the floor within a square framework of industrial steel parts; a pedestal sculpture mixes rusted steel Cubism, fallen leaves cut from steel and a small, glowing red electric light; and two plywood A-frame houses have roofs piled high with snow made of fiberglass and gloppy resin, a grungy winter fantasy (Johnson).

ADAM FUSS, Cheim & Read, 547 West 25th Street, (212) 242-7727, through Nov. 15. Childhood and death preoccupy this British-born photographer, who has come up with one of the season's more bizarre shows. Each in a group of daguerreotypes with mirrored surfaces presents a memento mori in the form of an eerily cheerful skull. Look at it and your face becomes part of the image. In a lengthy series of "gravestone cameos," fashioned into the ovoid shapes affixed to cemetery headstones, each bears a childhood image of Mr. Fuss. But the piece de resistance is a life-size sculpture of him as a toddler, clad in a fluffy white snowsuit made of ice. His technical tricks are impressive, but substance is apparently not a large issue (Glueck).

STEFAN KURTIN, "Something to Believe In," Alexander & Bonin, 132 10th Avenue, at 18th Street, (212) 367-7337, through Nov. 22. The modernistic architectural banalities painted by Mr. Kurtin, composed of modular bays, glass walls, picture windows and white or pastel exteriors, represent the house as a locus for middle-class hopes and dreams. Lush vegetation overcomes the starkness of these unpeopled housescapes, which are prettily tricked out with gold bronze paint and often overlaid with finely painted decorative screens that resemble grillwork. One work departs from this format: tucked into the foliage are birds, snakes, airplanes, pets, cottages, idols, mushrooms -- and pistols! It could be a satirical statement about the indiscriminate equations of the American mind-set (Glueck).

TAYLOR McKIMENS, "Day Old Bread," Clementine, 526 West 26th Street, (212) 243-5937,through Nov. 15. This young follower of R. Crumb has an amusing way with the comic abjection of everyday objects, which he paints in sickly pastels on shaped pieces of paper. He pictures hairy, slovenly people in their underwear -- in a broken-down house sculpture -- but there's more personality in the giant bologna sandwich covering one wall and smaller images like the spilled milkshake, the glasses with a shattered lens, the gnarly hot dog on white bread with a worm of mustard on it, the dripping pink soap bar and the melting ice cube (Johnson).

"MOTI MENTALI: MIRRORING VICTORIAN AND CONTEMPORARY PHOTOGRAPHY," Marvelli, 526 West 26th Street, (212) 627-3363, through Nov. 15. Two eminent English Victorians (Lewis Carroll and Julia Margaret Cameron) and three present-day women (Rineke Dijkstra, Ingar Krauss and Hellen van Meene) find common ground in suggestively enigmatic portraiture focused on girls, young women or androgynous teenagers. It is an interesting meditation on the timeless and the time-bound (Johnson).

"MY PEOPLE WERE FAIR . . . " Team Gallery, 527 West 26th Street, (212) 279-9219, through Nov. 15. This messy, intermittently exciting and irritating 39-artist show, organized by the independent curator Bob Nickas, ranges from things blatantly offensive and inept to things of genuine beauty, like Lucky de Bellevue's royal blue pipe-cleaner sculpture or the finely drawn hippie-visionary cartoons by Jeff Davis. It also spans some 40 years of bohemian nonconformity, from pioneers like Jack Smith and Paul Thek to newcomers like Paul P. and Jules de Balincourt (Johnson).

GEORGE NICK, "Plein-Air Meditations," Fischbach, 210 11th Avenue, at 25th Street, (212) 759-2345, through Nov. 15. Mr. Nick, who studied with Edwin Dickinson at the Brooklyn Museum of Art School in the 1950's, has been painting buildings in Boston with painterly verve and a keen eye for light for many years. Highlights here include pictures of Victorian town houses now occupied by fancy boutiques and a Hopperesque winter scene of an old rambling suburban house raked by a chilly afternoon sun (Johnson).

ERNESTO PUJOL, "Silence of Songbirds," Ramis Barquet, 532 West 24th Street, (212) 675-3421, through Nov. 15. A sculptor known for metaphorically loaded assemblages about sex, identity and history meditates on captivity in a series of large-format color photographs and a video of caged canaries. In the back room is an installation of smaller photographs, drawings of birds on Spanish dictionary pages and actual cages (Johnson).

JULIAN SCHNABEL, "New Indian Paintings and Selected Sculpture," PaceWildenstein, 534 West 25th Street, Chelsea, (212) 929-7000, through Nov. 16. The artist's talent for enlarging upon existing paintings and then disfiguring -- "Schnabelizing" -- them with abstract blurs is blandly recapitulated in canvases based on George Catlin's 19th-century paintings of American Indian chiefs. The bulky morose bronze sculptures from the mid-1980's are blatant instances of raging artistic ego made three-dimensional (Smith).

JESSICA STOCKHOLDER, "Table Top Sculptures," Gorney Bravin & Lee, 534 West 26th Street, Chelsea, (212) 352-8372, through Nov. 15. This two-for-one show contrasts the domestic and commercial by juxtaposing a stage-set living room, hung salon style with work by the artist and 30 colleagues, with a white cube presentation of her latest excursions into Color Field Assemblage. Given the domestic complications and quirky formal resolutions that abound in Ms. Stockholder's work, the homey installation, while generous in spirit, seems both redundant and undigested (Smith).

GORDON TERRY, "The Supernatural World in Which I Am Professionally Involved," Mike Weiss, 520 West 24th Street, (212) 691-6899, through Nov. 15. With their candy colors and swirly concentric rings or blobby cellular dots, Mr. Terry's puddles of paint on glossy plastic panels suggest psychedelic spontaneity. Yet the way they are arranged, like stickers for sale in an East Village boutique, bespeaks the overwhelming order of modern industrial economics. A throwback to the Neo-Geo-style commodity critique of the 1980's, his hyper-slick work elicits nostalgia more than sharpened critical consciousness (Johnson).

"TRILOGY," Jack Shainman, 513 West 20th Street, (212) 645-1701, through Nov. 15. This selection of works by the Dadaists Francis Picabia, Man Ray and Marcel Duchamp is not the best introduction to any of them, but fans will appreciate the show. Duchamp's retrospective in miniature, "The Green Box," is always good to revisit and his delicate etchings from the 60's are interesting. Picabia's mysteriously ham-fisted works are worth puzzling over. And Ray's small photographic portraits and snapshots of Surrealist luminaries have historical resonance (Johnson).

Other Galleries

SARAH BRAMAN AND BRIAN BELOTT, Canada, 55 Chrystie Street, Lower East Side, (212) 925-4631, through Nov. 30. These artists were made for each other, and for this moment of psychedelically flavored, busywork formalism in art. Ms. Braman's abstract geometric sculpures are like giant crystals in formation, one constructed from painted cardboard, the other from plexiglass. Mr. Bellot's collages fill the gallery walls. Most are paper-on-paper using clips from magazines, food wrappers, cartoons and children's books, with the occasional addition of paint, fabric and kitty litter. The ingredients join to create dreamlike landscapes, part fairy tale, part science fiction, though a little too weird to be utopian (Cotter).

* "DL: THE 'DOWN LOW' IN CONTEMPORARY ART," Longwood Art Gallery, Hostos Center for the Arts and Culture, 450 Grand Concourse, near 149th Street, the Bronx, (718) 401-7866, through Nov. 15. Longwood, housed for years in an old public school building in the Bronx, has moved to Hostos College. The move seems like a smart one, and is bound to have a salutory effect on a neighborhood that has begun to attract young artists and new galleries. The kickoff group strikes a scrappy, enterprising note by addressing a subject that the art world has pretty much overlooked: the African-American and Latino gay subculture referred to as the "down low." The show includes familiar artists -- Glenn Ligon, Kori Newkirk, Susan Smith-Pinelo -- but is notable for introducing a host of new ones, several of them making New York debuts. Karlos Carmaco, Alex Donis, Terence Koh, Ivan Monforte and Gigi Otalvaro-Hormillosa are some of the names to track (Cotter).

* "EVERYTHING MATTERS: PAUL KOS, A RETROSPECTIVE," Grey Art Gallery, New York University, 100 Washington Square East, Greenwich Village, (212) 998-6780, through Dec. 6. Mr. Kos's name rings too few bells here. He helped germinate the Bay Area Conceptual movement that pioneered video, performance and installation art in the late 1960's and early 70's. The spirit of his work is lighthearted and sly. One of his best early videos, from 1974, was shot in Wyoming: "Pilot Butte/Pilot Light" switches back and forth between that butte and Mr. Kos fashioning a lens out of a block of ice (you see him spinning the block on the inside of the lid ofa pot to get the proper curvature), then focusing sunlight through the ice to spark kindling. The constant is Mr. Kos's catholic approach to materials. He balances a candle and a bell on the tip of a broomstick, which he discovered one day would stand up on its own if he jammed the business end of the broom against the floor just right. Better late than never to remind New Yorkers that some of what we take to be fresh or our own discovery has been going on for a long time elsewhere (Kimmelman).

VINCENT LONGO, "Reflections on Abstraction," Hunter College Times Square Gallery, 450 West 41st Street, (212) 772-4991, through Nov. 22. A five-decade 160-painting retrospective celebrates Mr. Longo's retirement after 35 years of teaching at Hunter College. Starting out under the influence of Abstract Expressionism, Mr. Longo turned to the grid and never looked back. His evolutionary exploration of the tactile, optical and spiritual possibilities is consistently engaging all the way through (Johnson).

* NASREEN MOHAMEDI, Talwar, 108 East 16th Street, (212) 673-3096, through Nov. 20. Mohamedi (1937-1990) was born in Pakistan, spent time in London and Paris, and taught art in Baroda, India. She is best known for linear drawings that suggest perspectival Agnes Martins floating in the fourth dimension. This show presents her photographs from the 1960's and 70's. Abstracted images of places and things -- Islamic architecture; painted directional markings on Japanese streets; ocean swells after a storm -- have clear connections to her drawings and reflect an artist who broke with essentialist ideas of what Indian art should look like, engaged with the advanced international art of her day and left a deeply personal body of work (Cotter).

Last Chance

EVEREST HALL, Bellwether, 335 Grand Street, Williamsburg, Brooklyn, (718) 387-3701, through Monday. This young artist's first New York solo show is made up of graphite drawings and oil paintings with perversely unpalatable content. The work is based on found photographic images lifted from magazines or Internet databases that cater to marginal tastes, and the mix of frat-house humor, gross-out obsession and polymorphous sexuality makes a potent visual combination, particularly because each image is so masterly executed (Cotter).

KRISTINE MARX, "Approximation," Plane Space, 102 Charles Street, West Village, (917) 606-1268, through Monday. Works in this young video artist's first New York solo don't look like much at first. She projects nondescript images of herself and others walking through or sitting in mostly empty rooms onto gallery walls and multidirectional arrangements of panels. Look more closely and you discover curious disjunctions of space and time, making an intriguing electronic update of Cubist painting (Johnson).

MICHAEL NAJJAR, "Information and Apocalypse," Goethe Institute, 1014 Fifth Avenue, near 82nd Street, (212) 439-8700, through Thursday. A Berlin photographer and digital artist shows glossy computer-assisted images and videos about how the mainstream electronic media covers war in the Middle East. His point is that the facts always surrender to the imperatives of visual entertainment, so his staged images of sex and death in the desert have a vivid artificiality, like television (Johnson).

 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk; Pg. 30

LENGTH: 1508 words

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW; 
Finding Surprises as They Are Turned Up by the Karma Wheel

BYLINE:  By HOLLAND COTTER 

 BODY:
"Everyone Gets Lighter" is the good-news message on a billboard across the street from the Newhouse Center for Contemporary Art at Snug Harbor on Staten Island. The words, by the New York poet John Giorno, introduce a show titled "The Invisible Thread: Buddhist Spirit in Contemporary Art." And after a visit, you may indeed feel a little more buoyant than usual.
 To be honest, I'm surprised at how well this exhibition turned out, given the fact that it came together on a wing and a prayer. It is one of the best things I have seen at Snug Harbor's Newhouse Center for Contemporary Art. 
 Conceived as the centerpiece of a yearlong multi-institutional series of events called "The Buddhism Project," which began last winter, the show had high ambitions. But cash was tight (apparently there still isn't enough loose change to print a catalog). Loans were hard to nail down. And last-minute changes in personnel rocked an already tipsy boat. (One of the curators, Olivia Georgia, director of the Newhouse Center, left for the Bronx Museum of the Arts.) 
But as any Buddhist knows, change is life's only certainty, and a spin of the karma wheel can bring unlooked-for blessings. So it was here. When loans fell through, better ones materialized: how much more interesting it is, for example, to see Agnes Martin's only video, the 1976 "Gabriel," in place of unobtainable paintings that would have presented her in a familiar mode.
A roster of nearly 50 artists that looked unpromisingly eclectic on paper turns out to be a beguilingly unobvious mix. And almost all the work is seen to advantage in the Newhouse Center's oddball Main Hall exhibition space, once a dormitory for the retired seamen for whom Snug Harbor was built in the 19th century.
With so many wild cards in play, it makes sense that the show's shape is free-form. Neither a systematic survey nor a closely argued thematic essay, it is fueled by the "Buddhist Spirit" of the title, whatever that may be. While some of the artists are practicing Buddhists, as their work reflects, others come from somewhere else entirely. But everyone arrives at more or less the same place, a place where the incidence of negativity is low, the harmony level high. In short, however the spirit is defined, it's communal and contagious.
And at least one of its sources takes traditional form in a Himalayan-style brass sculpture of the Buddha himself. Borrowed from the Jacques Marchais Museum of Tibetan Art on Staten Island, it is set, bright as a lamp, at the start of the show.
The figure, seated on a celestial lotus throne but touching the earth with one hand, is a classical embodiment of the dharma, or the way, a path to salvation that lies in an immersive but unpossessive identification with every aspect of the natural world. The Buddhist sutra known as the Scripture of Inconceivable Liberation envisions this interactive connection in the marvelous image of the Diamond Net of Indra, an infinite field of faceted gems, each gaining its radiance from the light of the others.
On a less exalted plane, there's also some modern historical grounding in a gallery devoted to a group of artists who did much to nurture the Buddhist spirit in postwar American culture. The Zen-masterish composer John Cage is one of them, represented by written notations for a chance-generated score. (He is honored elsewhere in a charming video piece by Nam June Paik.)
Another is Thomas Merton, a Trappist monk deeply involved in Asian spirituality. Three of his calligraphic pieces are here, as is a painting of rocks by Morris Graves and a gorgeous little sea-and-shore photograph by Minor White. Two floor-hugging bronze Noguchi sculptures clinch an effect of raked-garden spareness.
Calligraphy, a touchstone of the Zen aesthetic, had a significant influence on Abstract Expressionism and continues to be a reference point for gestural painting. Louise Fishman's somber "Lifting, Moving, Placing" offers evidence, with its inverted stepped pyramid of vermilion strokes emerging from a gray-blue storm. So does Tattfoo Tan's "United We Stand," with its ribbons of blood red twisting across a landscape of mountains and exploding stars traced in gold on a dark ground and visible only close up.
Perceptual ambush, another Zen staple, animates a fountainlike piece by Tom Friedman. Made from a single clear plastic cup and dozens of linked drinking straws, it's some kind of masterpiece of idiot savant virtuosity. Nearby, pixilated, Zen-inflected Fluxus lives on in Yoko Ono's "Wish Tree," which invites viewers to tie handwritten personal requests to a potted ficus.
A ritual-intensive, icon-centered Buddhism is a model for other work: altarlike pieces by Top Changtrakul and Hoang Van-Bui, for example, and mandala-inspired installations by Arlene Schechet and Chrysanne Stathacos. Alex Grey's painting, "Universal Mind Lattice," with its glowing emblem of neural circuitry set in a Christian altarpiece format, exemplifies hybrid. interfaith "American Buddhism" that some historians of religion see as the way of the future.
If it proves to be so, it is a Buddhism that will necessarily encompass a political dimension, a degree of social awareness and critical self-reflection that complicates the meditative, soft-grained, interiorized Buddhism that predominates in this show.
Like every religion, institutional Buddhism has a dark side. Zen was a militant samurai religion, teaching warriors how to kill and be killed with unflappable self-composure; in Japan today, Zen temples accept lucrative contracts to provide obedience training for corporate employees. And in the United States, where the word compassionate, which carries specific ethical meanings in a Buddhist context, has been jingoistically linked to the word conservatism, Buddhism may need to rethink its self-presentation.
But changes are already under way. Maybe it means something that the show's single overtly political piece, Adelle Lutz's "Burkha/Womb Project," addresses the issue of international violence with an image from Islamic culture; and that one of the largest figurative pieces on view, a walk-in sculpture of the Buddha's head by Long-bin Chen, is composed of hundreds of New York City telephone directories, as if an entire polyethnic, spiritually diverse population were united under his protection.
Such art may hold the seeds of the Buddhist "planetary culture" envisioned by the poet Gary Snyder as an antidote to a now global Western culture, "economically dependent on a fantastic system of stimulation of greed which cannot be fulfilled."
As the Buddha himself implied, however, the personal and the political are inseparable. The only model for an ethical life he had to offer was his own stripped-down life, and he encouraged others to imitate it so they, too, might become Buddhas -- awakened beings -- in a process of self-transformation that, almost accidentally, generated universal beneficence. Something like this idea is suggested in a huge, air-filled fabric sculpture by Lewis deSoto, which depicts the reclining Buddha simultaneously dying and entering the energy stream of nirvana. The image is based on a revered stone image in Sri Lanka, but its face is a self-portrait of Mr. deSoto.
The piece, which looks as if it could drift up out of the gallery like a dirigible, is given plenty of breathing space. So is other work installed in the small rooms off the Main Hall on two levels, a layout vaguely corresponding to that found in the very early Buddhist cave monasteries in India, with their courtyards surrounded by monks' cells and chapels, all carved from rock.
The show's organizers -- Robyn Brentano and Lilly Wei, independent curators; the writer Roger Lipsey; and Ms. Georgia -- have supplied wall texts that often clarify individual artists' connection to Buddhism but too seldom address the specific work at hand, which occasionally needs some decoding. But this oversight is a minor flaw, as is the quotient of less than riveting contributions that almost inevitably comes with large-scale curatorial collaborations. 
What matters in the end is a gathered atmosphere, in this case stimulating and pacific. It tends to stay with you after you have left the show, like the scent of incense on clothing, and charges the outside air. I caught the ferry back at dusk, when Lower Manhattan was beginning to generate its own corporate jewel-net of light. During the trip, a sea-going street preacher paced back and forth through the cabin, exhorting us, his captive audience, to turn our attention to a certain path-marking spiritual leader of a non-Buddhist persuasion. "He is the way in no way!" the evangelist suddenly shouted. Several of us -- readers, dozers, daydreamers -- levitated in alarm in our seats; then at least one of us smiled at a pure Zen moment, American-style. 

"The Invisible Thread: Buddhist Spirit in Contemporary Art" is at the Newhouse Center for Contemporary Art, Snug Harbor Cultural Center, 1000 Richmond Terrace, Livingston, Staten Island, (718) 448-2500, through Feb. 29.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Large detail from Minor White's "Untitled (No. 5 From Song Without Words)." (Photos by Minor White Archive, Princeton University Art Museum, $;Princeton University); Lewis deSoto's "Paranirvana (self-portrait)" in "The Invisible Thread: Buddhist Spirit in Contemporary Art" on Staten Island. (Photo by Newhouse Center for Contemporary Art)

ORGANIZATION: PRINCETON UNIVERSITY (84%) NEWHOUSE CENTER FOR CONTEMPORARY ART (NYC) 

PERSON: COTTER, HOLLAND

SECTION: Section F; Column 1; Escapes; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 923 words

HEADLINE: JOURNEYS; 
After the Fires, Back in Business

BYLINE:  By CHRIS DIXON 

DATELINE: SAN DIEGO 

 BODY:
JUST a week ago, it looked as though Mountain High ski resort might not open at all this year. The ski area, 220 acres in the San Bernardino Mountains east of Los Angeles, is less than 10 miles from the reach of the Old Fire, one of the worst of the blazes that tore through almost 750,000 acres here in late October. Then the temperature dropped 40 degrees, snow started falling and, Monday morning at 8:30 a.m., the first skier of the season headed up on the chairlift.
 "We went from summer to winter in the course of two days," said John McColly, the mountain's marketing director. "It's actually our earliest opening ever." 
 But while Mountain High is welcoming skiers, the rest of California's tourism industry is still struggling with the impact of the fires -- and, even more, with the impact of the widely broadcast pictures of devastation that may have some travelers staying away.
"We're a huge state," said Jennifer Jasper, deputy director of the California Travel and Tourism Commission, which has just launched a publicity campaign aimed at convincing tourists to come back. "Ninety-nine percent of California has been unaffected by this fire," she said.
Indeed, even while the fires were burning, much of Southern California was largely untouched, other than a pall of smoke. At Disneyland "there were no operational impacts from the fires," said Bob Tucker, a Disney spokesman. "And no effect on our crowds." (Mr. Tucker would not reveal visitor numbers during the fires, but last year Disneyland and its adjacent California Adventure park together averaged 340,000 visitors a week.)
And Los Angeles hotels had one of their best weeks ever, said Carol Martinez, spokeswoman for the Los Angeles Convention and Visitors Bureau. "Walt Disney Concert Hall just opened," she said, "and we had a Microsoft convention in town. We had 8,000 people for that and only 53 cancellations."
Ms. Jasper said that hard numbers on the fires' effects on Southern California's $35 billion tourism economy would not be available for 10 days or more, but that the San Diego area was probably the hardest hit.
Many flights into and out of Southern California were canceled, diverted or delayed when the regional air traffic control center at Miramar Marine Corps Air Station in the San Diego hills was forced to close on Oct. 26. "It was getting hot in there and the place was filling up with smoke," said Donn Walker, a Federal Aviation Authority spokesman, who added that by Oct. 28 things had returned to normal.
But even with a thick blanket of smoke covering San Diego, hotels here were not necessarily emptying out. Craig Jacobs, the general manager of the landmark Del Coronado Hotel, said that cancellations during the fires ran about even with calls from local residents in need of places to stay. (The hotel gave burned-out locals rooms at half rate.) The bigger problem: smoke and ash soiling upholstery and carpets. Ash was also settling on the hotel's sprawling red roof. "We brought in a team of people to scrub," Mr. Jacobs said, and, by Wednesday of this week, "you really couldn't tell anything had happened."
NOT everyone was so lucky, of course. The smoke and the difficulty of getting around San Diego at the height of the crisis forced the closing of attractions like SeaWorld Adventure Park, which usually draws more than 70,000 visitors a week; Legoland California; and the 1,800-acre San Diego Wild Animal Park.
SeaWorld suspended operations for four days, Oct. 26 to 29. The animal park closed only briefly on Oct. 27, when the Paradise Fire came close to local roads, but reopened the next day, said Christina Simmons, a spokeswoman. And, she said, the warm weather that helped bring on the fire gave a boost to the park's annual fall chrysanthemum display, which is now in full bloom. The famous San Diego Zoo made it through without closing.
Dianne and David Reid of West Dundee, Ill., planned their family trip to San Diego for eight months but almost did not come because of the fires. "We were just waiting day by day to make our decision," said Mr. Reid, who works for a large accounting firm. When they called their hotel last week to check on the situation, Mrs. Reid said, the desk clerk told her, "Well, we're not wearing masks anymore."
"I thought, 'Oh, then it must be really good,' " she said. 
But it wasn't until Mr. Reid flew to San Diego on business on Monday that the rest of the family finally decided to come. "I could see it was a lot better," he said. 
So on Thursday morning, under clear sunny skies, the couple unloaded their three children from their rented car in the SeaWorld parking lot. In addition to seeing Shamu they were planning to visit Legoland and Tijuana, Mexico. Were they glad they came? Absolutely, Ms. Reid said. "It's 40 degrees back in Chicago right now." 
And at Mountain High, almost 2,000 skiers and snowboarders have been on the slopes each day, including Josh Montoya, a 20-year-old outdoor education instructor who spent opening day at the resort's Chisolm Terrain Park. "It's awesome to see all these people up here," he said. "The terrain's excellent for so early in the season." 
That's the kind of message tourism officials are hoping will get out, and soon. "Outside of fire-ravaged areas it's still the same," said Sal Giametta, a spokesman for the San Diego Convention and Visitors Bureau. "The message we're putting out now is much like we saw from New York post 9/11. We're here, we're open for business and what you could do for us now, would be to come out and visit."

HEADLINE: HAVENS; 
Mobs! Murder! Mayhem! (And a Few Good Deals)

BYLINE:  By KIMBERLY STEVENS and SARAH ROBERTSON 

 BODY:
LAST June, Baltimore police officers Karen Brzowsky and Timothy Beall were patrolling their beat in the city's Northern District when something caught their attention -- a middle-aged man walking along the street pushing a lawn mower to which he had strapped two bicycles and a handful of tools.
 Not a scene one usually encounters at 3 in the morning. 
 The officers stopped the man, George M. Wilson, 45, and asked him what he was doing with all those items. According to Officer Brzowsky, Mr. Wilson said that he had "found them on the street." 
A few hours later, though, when a resident in that neighborhood reported the theft of items much like the ones Mr. Wilson had been carrying, the officers went to his house and discovered what turned out to be roughly $2,500 in stolen property, including more bicycles, weed trimmers, tools and leaf blowers.
What the officers had stumbled onto was not just a one-time burglary. Instead, it transpired that Mr. Wilson had been repeatedly stealing property out of his neighbors' garages and homes -- roughly 40 burglaries in just over six months. Then, the police said, he would quickly sell the items at tag sales outside his apartment.
"It is almost the perfect crime," said Officer Brzowsky, explaining that the stolen items were often sold before the owners realized they were missing. Plus, she added, the very nature of tag sales -- with people coming and going and few records kept -- made it hard to trace stolen property, particularly the lawn-care equipment that Mr. Wilson seemed to specialize in. "These are all hot sellers at yard sales," she said.
Mr. Wilson was arrested and later pleaded guilty to theft, for which he was sentenced to six months in jail. The Baltimore police said that other theft charges are pending.
It used to be that yard sales were a quaint weekend custom, a place for neighbors to come by and pick over hand-me-downs while picking up the local gossip. If you actually came away with a bargain -- say, an Eastlake mirror for $35 -- so much the better. The events, sometimes called tag sales or garage sales, were mostly relaxed social occasions, a pleasant way to pass a Saturday morning.
That is changing. While grand theft is hardly a common occurrence at these events, police departments around the country report that these sales represent a growing crime problem in their towns, with trespassing charges, complaints about noise and crowds, and accusations of petty thievery and assault peppering their court dockets. 
Part of the problem is the sheer number of yard sales. Some people hold sales so frequently, according to officials around the country, that neighbors complain to city hall that they are running unlicensed businesses on their lawns. City streets are littered with homemade signs that are up for many days before and after the sales.
Meanwhile, sellers have to contend with early birds who line up on their property hours before the sale starts and shoppers who get into fights over items.
"Do I believe it's more aggressive now?" asked Sonia Weiss, a co-author of the Pocket Idiot's Guide to Garage and Yard Sales. "Yes, absolutely." 
The increased numbers of sales -- and the heightened competition among shoppers -- has brought out the "unseemly side of yard sale," said Christina Heiska, 40, a Lusby, Md., resident who has run the www.yard salequeen.com Web site for the last five years. She recently added a section on yard sale scams to warn people about the more unsavory characters they might encounter, like browsers who use small children to distract sellers while they shoplift a few items. 
"Maybe it's the economy or eBay, but I've heard all sorts of stories about people shoplifting, changing price tags and cheating people out of change," she said. "They attract the run-of-the-mill swindler, so it's important to keep an eye out." 
Andrea Checovich, 40, an antiques dealer who has had a booth at Christine's Crossing, a shared retail space in Rye, N.H., for more than two years, said that the competition has gotten much fiercer in recent years. She said that in her searches for merchandise she has seen arguments, near fistfights and women leaping over barriers in heels and skirts to attach "sold" stickers to the things they like. And, she said, angry yard-sale attendees complain bitterly when they arrive at a sale at the posted starting time only to find that "early birds" were let in early. 
"I notice it immediately," she said. "People get this look in their eyes. There is a certain etiquette that everyone tries to maintain, but once you give into bad behavior, the craziness begins. That's when I call it quits."
EFFORTS to slow down the proliferation of yard sales have popped up around the country. In Santa Ana, Calif., residents can only hold sales on four weekends every year, with strictly enforced hours of 8 a.m. to 5 p.m., while in San Jose, Calif., residents are restricted to just two sales a year.
"Activities like this are intrusive in neighborhoods," said Garry McLeod, a code enforcement officer for the city of San Jose. "Small issues become larger issues if you let them continue."
After officials in Westborough, Mass., prohibited sale signs on public property, residents advertised their sales by plastering their cars with signs and parking them in the heavily trafficked downtown. So the town then imposed a two-hour parking limit there. "The area is around funeral homes and churches," said Lt. Paul Donnelly of the Westborough police department. "It's not appropriate."
Josh Thomas, citizen information coordinator in Lake Oswego, Ore., said that his department was flooded with so many garage sale complaints -- including one about a woman who had nine sales in one month -- that city officials last December passed an ordinance restricting garage sales to two a year. Previously, homeowners there could have sales up to 14 days a year.
Yard-sale rules can be strict. Want to have a sale in Atherton or Ventura, Calif.? Make sure it is a gangbuster because you can have only one a year. In Lone Tree, Colo., residents are required to use special white and green signs provided by the city to advertise their sales. In New Holland, Pa., residents must have a permit to hold a sale and use the city's special signs, then take them down within 24 hours. Violations can mean a fine of up to $600.
"We've had to close yard sales down when they get too crazy," said Jessica Meihle, who handles the yard-sale permits for the police department in North Hampton, N.H., another hub of yard-sale activity.
In Collinsville, Ill., Marcy Basden, 38, a day care director, said that she had high hopes for her yard sale last fall. She bought a permit, placed an ad in the paper, and laid out all her goods. But she ended up making only $25 on the sale. Why? She was fined $83 for putting a sign on public property on the corner of her street. "It stopped me from having a sale this year," she said. "I'll just give my things to Goodwill." 
Trespassing and breaking and entering are not unknown in connection with yard sales. When Margaret Ponzer and her siblings decided to have a sale at her childhood home in Rye, N.H., they sorted through dusty boxes and painstakingly put price tags on old belongings. And then they listed the sale in the local newspaper a week in advance, which according to Ms. Ponzer was "a giant mistake." 
"I couldn't believe it when I came over to the house later that week to do some last-minute pricing and there was a dealer sitting in the middle of the living room with a pile of things she wanted and a handful of cash," said Mrs. Ponzer, who had left the house unlocked. After the initial shock of discovering a stranger in her home, and thinking of calling the police, Mrs. Ponzer said, she just told the woman to leave and come back during the sale.
Likewise, when Dan Hardee, of Vero Beach, Fla., had a tag sale in late June, he thought it was going to be "good, innocent fun." On the day of the event, he said, he quickly realized he was in over his head, beginning with the unexpected early start. "I heard noise in the garage at 6that morning and the sale was scheduled to start at 8," he said. "I couldn't believe people actually let themselves into the garage." (Which he had not locked.)
Things only got worse later in the day when he realized that someone had apparently helped himself to $600 that Mr. Hardee had briefly stashed under a ceramic bowl for safekeeping. Mr. Hardee considers that a hard-earned lesson. "I will have another sale, and I probably won't hire a security guard," he said. "But I'll definitely have a lockbox."
Detective Joe Flescher from the Indian River County Sheriff's office, who investigated Mr. Hardee's theft complaint, said that Mr. Hardee had not been prepared for the crowds or for the possibility of criminal activity. "People have become shameless over an old eight-track or a fishing rod," Detective Flescher said. "I think the only frontier left is the church bazaar." 
Gunfire and bloodshed are not what you would expect a yard sale to produce, but that's what occurred two years ago in Las Vegas.
Over the years, David Earl Reed often held yard sales in front of his Las Vegas home, doing a brisk business as neighbors and passers-by sifted through the dozens of cast-off items he had assembled. But when Gene Cattaneo came by late one November afternoon two years ago, he was not looking to pick up used patio furniture or a few pieces of Fiestaware.
Instead, Mr. Cattaneo started taking pictures of the items arrayed on the lawn, apparently agitated by the sight of all the merchandise displayed in the front yard. "It was not your normal yard sale," said Brian Rutledge, a deputy district attorney later involved in prosecuting Mr. Reed. "There were 20 different computer monitors out on the lawn, dozens of rolls of carpets, tables and tents." Soon, the two men got into an argument that continued later nearby, according to the police, and ended when Mr. Reed shot Mr. Cattaneo.
Shortly afterward, Mr. Cattaneo, 59, was pronounced dead at University Medical Center and Mr. Reed, then 61, was charged in his death. Last August, Mr. Reed pleaded guilty to voluntary manslaughter and was sentenced to up to 20 years in prison, according to his lawyer, Joseph Abood.
George Sherwood, a Las Vegas detective assigned to the case, said that the two men apparently didn't know each other, but that the constant yard sales seemed to bother Mr. Cattaneo, as well as many other neighborhood residents. "There was junk all over the yard and piled up," Detective Sherwood said recently. "It was your basic eyesore." 
Mr. Reed, he added, was "the neighbor you pray never moves into the area."
For Jeffrey Maybaum, of Wellington, Fla., holding a yard sale last spring was an experience that he said he was not eager to repeat. The event turned violent after he accused a shopper, who had purchased a painting, of stealing three others. Mr. Maybaum said that the accused man, fleeing in an S.U.V., struck him in the shoulder. 
Mr. Maybaum said that he called 911 and later pursued charges of aggravated assault with a motor vehicle. Eventually, however, Mr. Maybaum's four paintings were returned and he dropped his complaint. 
"It was immensely traumatizing," he said. "I will never, ever have a garage sale again."

HEADLINE: Flags Versus Dollars 

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN; E-mail: krugman@nytimes.com

 BODY:
Howard Dean's remarks about the need to appeal to white Southerners could certainly have been better phrased. But his rivals for the Democratic nomination should be ashamed of their reaction. They know what he was trying to say -- and it wasn't that his party should go soft on racism. By playing gotcha, by seizing on the chance to take the front-runner down a peg, they damaged the cause they claim to serve -- and missed a chance to confront the real issue he raised.
 A three-sentence description of the arc of American politics over the past 70 years would run like this: First, Democrats and moderate Republicans created institutions -- above all, Social Security and Medicare -- that provided a measure of financial security to ordinary working Americans. The biggest beneficiaries of these institutions were African-Americans and working-class Southern whites, and both were part of the moderate-to-liberal coalition that dominated American politics until the 1960's. 
 But the right opened an increasingly effective counterattack, with a strategy that included using racially charged symbolism to get Southern whites to vote against their own economic interests. All Mr. Dean was saying was that Democrats need to understand and counter this strategy.
I know these are fighting words. But the reliance of modern Republican political strategy on coded appeals to racism is no secret. Controversies over efforts to remove the Stars and Bars from the top of the South Carolina Statehouse, and to reduce its size on the Georgia flag, played a significant role in Republican victories in 2002. And the evidence that race is still a crucial factor is as fresh as Tuesday's election. 
The big story in that election was the victory of Republicans in Mississippi and Kentucky. The secondary story, however, was a string of victories by Democrats in affluent suburban areas in the Northeast. In my state, New Jersey, Democrats took firm control of the state's Legislature.
What this tells us is that some people -- either in New Jersey, Mississippi or both -- voted against their economic interests. For whatever you think of Bush's economic plan, it's clearly much better for New Jersey -- a rich state, which gains a lot from tax cuts tilted toward the affluent -- than for a poor state like Mississippi.
Consider, for example, the effects of estate tax repeal, a central feature of the 2001 tax cut. Almost nobody in Mississippi pays the estate tax. In 2001 only 249 estates in Mississippi paid any tax at all; raising the exemption to $5 million, which some Democrats suggested as an alternative to full repeal, would have reduced that to a couple of dozen. By contrast, New Jersey, with three times Mississippi's population, had almost 10 times as many taxable estates. 
Or consider the 2003 tax cut. It was also heavily tilted toward the affluent, and therefore toward rich states. According to Citizens for Tax Justice estimates, the typical New Jersey family got a $409 tax cut. In Mississippi, the number was only $165.
So did Mississippi voters support the Republicans, even though they get very little direct benefit from Bush-style tax cuts, because they -- unlike New Jersey's voters -- understand the magic of supply-side economics? If you believe that, I've got an overpass on the Garden State Parkway you may be interested in buying.
Now maybe New Jersey voted Democratic because of irrational Bush hatred. But I think it's a lot more likely that white Mississippi voters, unlike their counterparts up north, are still responding to Republican flag-waving -- and it's not just the American flag that's being waved. 
Yet the fact is that Mississippi, being relatively poor, will lose disproportionately if the right wins on its full agenda, which involves a big rollback of New Deal and Great Society programs. (I'll explain in a future column how Republicans are using the prescription drug bill to lay the groundwork for later Medicare cuts.) 
Mr. Dean wasn't suggesting that his party adopt the G.O.P. strategy of coded racial signals, and by and large African-Americans -- my wife included -- understand that. What he meant by his flag remark was that Democrats must make the case to working Americans of all colors that the right's elitist agenda isn't in their interest. And he's right.

HEADLINE: Catholics in Survey Seek Accountability by Church 

BYLINE:  By LAURIE GOODSTEIN

 BODY:
Three of every four Roman Catholics who regularly attend Mass say they want their church to be more financially accountable in the wake of its sexual-abuse crisis, according to a new Gallup survey, and one in four say they did not respond this year to financial appeals from the national church.
 But the survey also suggests that many Catholics who were angry about the scandal last year have begun to change their attitudes toward their local bishops. Forty-nine percent of the respondents said they felt that the bishops were doing a "good job" in handling the scandal, up from 35 percent last year. 
 Most also said they had not reduced donations to their parishes or local dioceses and bishops.
"They're blaming the bishops as a group rather than their own individual bishop," said Francis J. Butler, president of Foundations and Donors Interested in Catholic Activities, an association of philanthropists, which commissioned the survey. 
"They're making distinctions, cutting contributions to things that originate at the bishops conference, whereas things that originate at the diocese or the parish get a more positive reaction," Mr. Butler said in an interview.
The survey, conducted in October by the Gallup Organization, polled the same Catholics who answered some of the same questions in a similar Gallup survey last year. The poll last year included 656 parishioners, of whom 309 responded this year. The margin of error when comparing the two polls is plus or minus seven percentage points, because the group of respondents is small. 
It has been nearly two years since the sexual-abuse scandal involving priests first made national headlines in Boston, and the Gallup polls are the most detailed publicly available polls to gauge Catholic donors' opinions over the last two years.
The bishops say they are still instituting the policies they enacted in June 2002 to apprehend and discipline child molesters among the clergy. The United States Conference of Catholic Bishops meets in Washington next week.
Msgr. Francis Maniscalco, a spokesman for the conference, said that while some fund-raising appeals by the national church showed a slight drop in donations last year, others had slight increases. Among the national collections are the Catholic Campaign for Human Development, the Catholic Communications Collection and the American Bishops Overseas Appeal, Monsignor Maniscalco said. 
The survey results found that 75 percent of Catholics said the church should be more accountable on financial issues. 
Charles E. Zech, an economics professor at Villanova University who analyzed the survey results, said in an interview that "folks still want accountability."
"That hasn't dissipated, even with the sexual-abuse story off the front page," he said.
And two-thirds of those polled agreed in both years that "each diocesan bishop should give a full accounting of the financial costs and settlements arising from the sexual abuse by priests." 
The bishops have commissioned a study to find the extent of sexual abuse in the church and how much dioceses paid in settlements and legal fees. That study should be released in February, Monsignor Maniscalco said.
"The bishops are open to greater accountability," he said, "and they are in agreement with the laity that it is important to the church."
