HEADLINE: The Great Job Machine 

BYLINE:  By W. Michael Cox and Richard Alm; W. Michael Cox, chief economist of the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas, and Richard Alm are co-authors of "Myths of Rich and Poor."

DATELINE: DALLAS 

 BODY:
Apparently unconvinced by last week's eye-popping growth figures, economic pessimists remain fixated on the labor market. Today's release of the Labor Department's latest employment figures, we are told, will give a true picture of the pace of economic recovery. 
 But the monthly statistics, while relevant within the larger context of all economic indicators, don't tell the whole story of what is happening with Americans' jobs. Focusing on net employment gains or losses misses the real show, the long-running drama that drives the economy forward. 
 While it may seem that little progress is being made on the jobs front, beneath the surface the economy is doing what it's done for decades: orchestrating a relentless and enormous recycling of jobs and workers. 
Large-scale upheaval in jobs is part of the economy; the impetus for it comes from technology, changing trading patterns and shifting consumer demand. History tells us that the result will be even more jobs, greater productivity and higher incomes for American workers in general.
New Bureau of Labor Statistics data covering the past decade show that job losses seem as common as sport utility vehicles on the highways. Annual job loss ranged from a low of 27 million in 1993 to a high of 35.4 million in 2001. Even in 2000, when the unemployment rate hit its lowest point of the 1990's expansion, 33 million jobs were eliminated. 
The flip side is that, according to the labor bureau's figures, annual job gains ranged from 29.6 million in 1993 to 35.6 million in 1999. Day in and day out, workers quit their jobs or get fired, then move on to new positions. Companies start up, fail, downsize, upsize and fill the vacancies of those who left. It is workers' migration to new and existing jobs that keeps the country from sinking into some Depression-like swamp. 
Yes, this disruption can be very hard on some workers who lose their employment and have trouble adapting. But in the larger sense, the turmoil in the labor market is vital to economic progress. A good part of the turnover takes place in a handful of industries, like restaurants and retailing, but to greater or lesser extent the churning grinds on across the board, in bad times and good. Tallies of net jobs lost or gained capture only a fraction of the flux in the job market. As this plays out, most workers end up better off. 
Societies grow richer when new products emerge that better meet consumers' needs, and when producers adopt new technologies that reduce costs by making workers more productive. In a dynamic, innovative economy, these forces unleash waves upon waves of change. Some industries and companies prosper while others wither. Some companies find themselves with too many workers while others struggle with too few. A free-enterprise system responds by moving resources -- in this case workers -- to where they're more valuable.
For example, e-mail, word processors, answering machines and other modern office technologies are cutting jobs for secretaries but increasing the ranks of programmers. The Internet opened jobs for hundreds of thousands of Webmasters, an occupation that didn't exist as recently as 1990. Digital cameras translate to fewer photo clerks.
A century ago, 40 of every 100 Americans worked on farms to feed a nation of 90 million. Today, after one of history's most brutal downsizings, it takes just two agricultural workers out of 100 workers to supply an abundance of food to a nation more than three times as large. Suppose we'd kept 40 percent of our labor on the farm. Absurd, yes, but if we had, we wouldn't have had enough workers to produce the new homes, computers, movies, medicines and the myriad other goods and services of our modern economy. 
Likewise, the telecommunications industry employed 421,000 switchboard operators in 1970, when Americans made 9.8 billion long-distance calls. Thanks to advances in switching technology, telecommunications companies have reduced the number of operators to 78,000, but consumers ring up 98 billion calls. Let's face it: Americans are better off with more efficient long-distance service. To handle today's volume of calls with 1970's technology, telephone companies would need 4.2 million operators, or 3 percent of the labor force. Without the productivity gains, a long-distance call would probably cost 40 times what it now does.
Microeconomic failure is not macroeconomic failure. Quite the opposite, "failure" is the way the macro economy transfers resources to where they belong. It is the paradox of progress: a society can't reap the rewards of economic progress without accepting the constant change in work that comes with it. Efforts to soften the blows, by devising policies or laws to preserve jobs or protect industries, will lead to stagnation and decline, the biggest threat to American workers. 
Job losses for farm hands and telephone operators came so long ago that they don't sting anymore. Today we see the benefits clearly and forget the costs. That's harder to do in the short term -- it rightly distresses us to see newspaper photographs of laid-off industrial workers. But these are the economic forces that raise living standards. 
Since 1980, Americans have filed 106 million initial claims for unemployment benefits, each representing a lost job. Facing unemployment and rebuilding a life can be hard on families, but the United States today is better off for allowing it to happen. Even with the net decline in jobs over the past three years, during the past decade total United States employment has risen to 130 million from 91 million since 1980, a net gain of nearly 40 million jobs. Productivity, measured by output per worker, increased a staggering 56.2 percent. 
Some people tend to forget this. The almost daily drumbeat of reports and "expert commentary" about a so-called jobless recovery prompts the question, "What's gone wrong with the labor market?"
The surprising answer: nothing. 
Job growth will come, as it always has in the past. The economy, meanwhile, is as busy as ever in shifting labor from one use to another to make the country richer and more productive.

HEADLINE: Clark Proposes Transferring Military Operations in Iraq to a NATO Force 

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WYATT

DATELINE: ORANGEBURG, S.C., Nov. 6 

 BODY:
Gen. Wesley K. Clark said Thursday that military operations in Iraq should be turned over to a North Atlantic Treaty Organization force under United States command and that he would replace the civilian administration there with an international effort not under American leadership.
 General Clark, who is retired from the Army and who is seeking the Democratic presidential nomination, made the proposals to build international involvement and stabilize Iraq in an an address here at South Carolina State University. 
 It was the fourth in a series of speeches laying out his platform for the presidency, based on what he calls a "new American patriotism." He also said he would conduct a conference with leaders from Europe, Japan, the Arab world and other countries to enlist their support for a more international approach to Iraq. 
As part of that effort, General Clark said, he would recall the former Iraqi army and ask the cooperating nations to commit tens of thousands of troops to help the Iraqis in policing, police training, oversight and border control.
The creation of a new "reconstruction and democracy council" in Baghdad would be modeled, he said, on the international coalition that oversaw security and military operations in the Balkans in the 1990's.
While he struck themes that are common among the nine Democratic candidates -- saying the Bush administration's unilateral approach to Iraq has bred contempt for the United States -- he sought to capitalize on his experience as the former Supreme Commander of NATO forces in Europe, who prosecuted the 1999 war in Kosovo.
General Clark said his proposals would promote self-sufficiency among the Iraqi people. To foster that effort, he also called for "exchange programs in multiple fields so that Iraqis who have been isolated for years can see the rest of the world," learning about economics, education, health care and other elements of democratic societies.
"We can give the Iraqis a much bigger sense of ownership over their country and move much more quickly toward a government that answers to its people than the plan the Bush administration is currently pursuing," General Clark said. "Until Iraqis believe they can control their future, they will huddle in fear. They will watch others attack, rather than stand with pride, expose the guerrillas and stop the violence."
Senior officials on the Clark campaign said he chose South Carolina State for the foreign policy address because its R.O.T.C. program, in a state with a strong military presence, is one of the largest minority officer-training programs in the country. The program has commissioned more than 1,900 officers, most of them African-American.
In addition, three graduates of nearby Orangeburg-Wilkinson High School have been killed in the current war in Iraq, including Specialist Darius T. Jennings of the Army, who died this month after the helicopter in which he was riding was shot down near Falluja. 
Bridgette Frazier, a junior from Bluffton, S.C., who is president of the Young Democrats organization and who introduced General Clark, said the war in Iraq "has hurt the community."
"Of course, we applaud the efforts of our young men being over there," Ms. Frazier said, "but a lot of people here don't understand the reason for it."
South Carolina's primary on Feb. 3 is the first in the South, and General Clark is hoping it will establish him as the strongest rival to Howard Dean, the former Vermont governor, for the Democratic nomination.
Seeking to repair ties with European allies that he said have been damaged by the Bush administration, General Clark said he would propose "a new Atlantic Charter to reinvigorate our security partnership with Europe." 
He said such an organization would supplement NATO rather than replace it and would "define the threats we face in common, create the basis for concerted action from our allies to meet them, and offer the promise to act together as a first choice, not a last."
General Clark also said that the makeup of American military forces in Iraq should be overhauled, with more special forces and light units and fewer conventional infantry units, which require significant amounts of lightly armed logistical support units that also make tempting targets for attacks.
The military forces in Iraq also need more specialists in language and intelligence, he said. He proposed asking international inspectors to take over the search for unconventional weapons, which would free American linguists and intelligence specialists to work on efforts "to find the people who are killing our soldiers."
To help to close Iraq's borders to infiltration by terrorists, General Clark said, "We should engage with the Syrians, the Iranians and the Saudis, and we need carrots as well as sticks." 
"Unfortunately, this administration has made the region wary of working with us," he said. "I'll make sure as president that we don't ever get into a mess like this again."

HEADLINE: With U.S. Tax Checks Spent, Retailers Report Slower Gains 

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News

 BODY:
Wal-Mart Stores and the Target Corporation reported slower sales gains for October yesterday after a boost from federal tax-credit checks wore off and warmer weather limited the demand for autumn clothing.
 October sales at stores open at least a year rose 2.4 percent, according to the Goldman, Sachs retail index. 
 Sales at Wal-Mart, the largest retailer, increased 4.5 percent in October from October 2002. The figures were within Wal-Mart's forecasts. 
Shoppers curtailed spending after they spent tax-credit checks mailed in July and August and concerns lingered about unemployment. Many retailers have trimmed their inventories so that fall merchandise could be sold in time to open shelf space for the holiday season.
"Apparel softness is clearly tied to the warmer weather," said David Ritt, who helps run investments, including shares of Wal-Mart and the Gap, at ASB Capital Management. "It has to be considered a negative that consumers burned through the cash from the tax rebates."
Sales at Target's discount stores increased 1.6 percent. But at Kohl's, revenue fell 11.6 percent. 
Many shoppers are keeping their budgets tight amid job concerns. The Labor Department is expected to report this morning that unemployment remained at 6.1 percent last month, based on median forecasts. The rate has remained above 6 percent since April.
Some retailers said they expected third-quarter profits higher than forecast after they kept inventory low. Gap said earnings rose to as much as 28 cents a share, exceeding analysts' estimates. Federated Department Stores said profit would be slightly more than its forecast of as much as 33 cents a share.
Discounters like Costco and Wal-Mart benefited as shoppers bought more Halloween merchandise. Costco said sales rose 11 percent, buoyed by a 23 percent increase outside the United States. 
Retailers expect moderate sales gains in November as shoppers prepare for the holiday season. Wal-Mart said sales would rise as much as 5 percent, and Target expects sales at its discount stores to increase 4 percent to 6 percent.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Cisco's Strong Profit Propels Nasdaq to 22-Month High

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News

 BODY:
Stocks rose yesterday, led by technology companies, as Cisco Systems reported a record quarterly profit and the most sales in almost three years. The Nasdaq composite index closed at its highest in 22 months.
 "This is going to be a very positive sign," said Tim Leach, who helps oversee $140 billion at Wells Fargo Private Client Services in San Francisco. "If technology is recovering, it says a lot of good things about the market in general." 
 Benchmark indexes climbed in the last two hours of trading as some investors speculated that a government report to be released today would show that the economy gained jobs in October, which would be the second consecutive month.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 6.24 points, or 0.6 percent, to 1,058.05, with technology companies accounting for almost half the increase. The Dow Jones industrial average added 36.14 points, or 0.4 percent, to 9,856.97.
The Nasdaq, which gets 42 percent of its value from computer-related companies, advanced 17 points, or 0.9 percent, to 1,976.37. The index is at its highest point since January 2002.
Cisco, the maker of data-networking equipment, jumped $1.10, to $22.90. The company earned $1.09 billion, or 15 cents a share, in the quarter. Sales increased 5.3 percent, to $5.1 billion, their highest level since January 2001.
Shares of Cisco's rivals also gained. American depository receipts of Ericsson climbed 59 cents, to $16.57. Nortel Networks added 9 cents, to $4.42.
Stocks rose after the number of Americans filing for unemployment benefits dropped last week to the lowest level since January 2001 as faster economic growth prompted companies to retain workers, a government report showed. First-time jobless claims fell by 43,000, to 348,000, during the week ended Saturday, the Labor Department said.
Signs of an economic recovery "are now clearly there," billionaire investor George Soros said in a televised interview with Bloomberg News. "Today's employment number may be a bit of a fluke, but nevertheless, it shows a trend." 
Some money managers said investors were focused on today's Labor Department report. The economy may have gained jobs for a second month in October and the unemployment rate probably held at 6.1 percent, signals that the recovery will endure, economists said.
"Folks are just biding their time before the jobs report number tomorrow," said Richard Nash, chief market strategist at Victory Capital Management, which oversees $48 billion in Cleveland.
Telecommunications companies had the biggest percentage decline among the S.&P. 500's 10 industry groups. SBC Communications lost 46 cents, to $23.14. BellSouth dropped 49 cents, to $25.26.
The Federal Communications Commission may free consumers to move their home numbers to cellphones. An F.C.C. commissioner, Kathleen Abernathy, said that the agency might rule on the matter by the end of the week. On Monday, SBC and 70 other local carriers said such a rule would illegally favor wireless operators.
Janus Capital Group added 62 cents, to $14.28. The New York State attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, has been in talks with several companies, including Janus, Strong Capital Management, Bank One and Bank of America, to settle accusations that they allowed favored investors to make improper mutual fund trades, Bloomberg and Reuters reported.
Alliance Capital Management Holding shed 38 cents, to $30.15. The nation's biggest publicly traded money manager said the Securities and Exchange Commission might penalize the company for improper mutual fund trading.
T. Rowe Price Group, a manager of stock mutual funds, added $3.11, or 7.7 percent, to $43.56. The company may win clients from firms that have been accused of allowing improper fund trading, Guy Moszkowski, a Merrill Lynch & Company analyst, said.
T. Rowe Price has not been implicated in the investigation, he said, and its fund performance is among the best in the industry.
In the bond market, the 10-year Treasury note fell 15/32, to a price of 98 23/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 4.41 percent from 4.35 percent on Wednesday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond plunged 28/32, to 101 27/32. The bond's yield jumped to 5.25 percent from 5.19 percent on Wednesday.

PERSON: JEFF SOREF 

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES; 
A Keen Eye and Oh, Such Compelling Friends

BYLINE:  By ROBIN FINN

 BODY:
IN deference to the nervous Nellies who insure the extroverted contents of Jeff Soref's art-centric apartment on Gramercy Park, a scholarly itemization of his collection of African and Eastern sculpture, most of it carved in timeworn wood, is forbidden. But gawking is permitted. He is constantly asked which pieces he'd rescue in a fire: fortunately he has no spouse, kids or pets to further complicate things. He's inordinately fond of an ancestor figure, presumably a king, from Congo; it seems a good king is hard to find. Then there's the 11th century hermaphrodite from Mali. Decisions, decisions.
 Suffice it to say that the phalanx of statuary that guards the living and dining rooms, some of it life-size with expressions ranging from meditative to malevolent, makes a serious first impression on visitors, even those devoid of an artistic eye. Mr. Soref, the newest addition to the Lincoln Center board, and, according to his preliminary research, the first openly gay activist on the board of any of New York City's benchmark cultural institutions, takes glee in recounting the experience of a friend who borrowed his apartment and was so intimidated by the statues that he locked them in a closet. 
 "A lot of people have trouble appreciating African art," says Mr. Soref, 55. "People either find it scary or they just don't get it. I see a lot of humor in it. And elegance. And simplicity. There are no hidden agendas: for me, collecting art has been a great break from politics."
Mr. Soref, whose other hobby is philanthropy, traces his political activism to a hodgepodge of sources: a Bolshevik grandfather, a Democrat mother, a Republican father, a Vista stint in the rural black South, an affinity for the underdog, and the AIDS epidemic, which claimed a slew of friends and propelled him to the presidency of the board of the Gay Men's Health Crisis from 1991 to 1994. Bill Clinton, on hand to give him an award at an Empire State Pride Agenda dinner last month, respectfully referred to him as "a thorn in my side." Mr. Soref's seven years as co-chairman of the Pride Agenda ended on a festive note last December when, after a 31-year stalemate, New York passed a nondiscrimination bill.
"Certain issues need to be bipartisan," he says, scratching a hand through his silver-tipped hair. It mirrors his persona -- scrupulously bristly. Back when he wore it long, he tamed it with Vaseline. "Sure, Vaseline," he says. "What do you think Elvis used?" Smooth. No wonder Mark Green, Elizabeth Holtzman, and Senator Edward M. Kennedy enlisted him as press secretary or spokesman. "Sometimes it's not about ideology, it's about doing the right thing." 
WORD has it he's relentless when pressing a cause, be it government funding for AIDS research or government funding for the arts, now his mission at Lincoln Center; or half his mission. The other half is providing outreach to the gay and lesbian community; overdue, he says. As is -- listen up, Lincoln Center officials -- what Mr. Soref envisions as an "out" music festival.
"I've spent my whole life raising money for AIDS, and for the gay community," Mr. Soref says. "I made my reputation, such as it is, by being a gay activist, and the fact that Lincoln Center was willing to reach out to that is a significant breakthrough even if it wasn't intended to be a breakthrough. Given the involvement of the gay community in the arts, in performance, and in philanthropy, you kind of wonder how it can be that there's been no openly gay board member of a top-ranking cultural institution; typically they draw from the corporate world, or very senior government officials, and we know there's still a glass ceiling there for lesbians and gays." 
Reynold Levy, the Lincoln Center president, says his board was not necessarily looking for a gay activist, but he sounds thrilled with Mr. Soref: "Jeff brings to the board a highly refined sense of political skills, a broad network of friends and colleagues inside and outside the gay community, and a passion for the arts: that combination is extremely compelling." 
Mr. Soref grew up wealthy in Milwaukee; the family money came from his father's manufacturing firm, and when it was sold, Mr. Soref collected his share in a lump sum. He joined Vista after a medical deferment kept him from the Vietnam War, graduated from Brandeis University and, hoping to become a spy, graduated from the London School of Economics with a degree in Russian government in 1974. The great irony of his rocky romantic career -- he is, alas, single these days -- is that it was not his homosexuality but a love affair with a Czech woman during grad school that disqualified him from spy duty when he applied to the State Department. Back in the States, he devoted himself to politics and the civil rights of the AIDS-afflicted. When he became ill in the mid-90's, the scuttlebutt was that he himself was battling AIDS; actually, it was kidney disease. He underwent a transplant in 1994. 
Besides buying art in conjunction with the Metropolitan Museum of Art, he is a longtime patron of the Metropolitan Opera and a classical music buff; he says it was his passion for performance art, not his art collection, that swayed the Lincoln Center board. "They made me promise not to redecorate," he says in jest. "None of that queer eye for the straight guy stuff."

HEADLINE: Putin Says Oilman's Arrest Is No Threat to Private Enterprise 

BYLINE:  By SETH MYDANS

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Nov. 6 

 BODY:
President Vladimir V. Putin on Thursday cast the arrest of the country's richest man almost two weeks ago as part of a law and order campaign aimed at Russia's hugely wealthy oligarchs.
 Speaking heatedly at a news conference in Rome, he said: "People earned billions, I repeat billions, of dollars in the space of five or six years. This would not have been possible in any Western European nation." 
 He emphasized that the arrest of Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, who owns the giant Yukos Oil company, did not mean that Russia would reverse its policies of private ownership.
"I say officially that the Yukos case will not lead to revision of the Russian Federation's policy in the economic or political sphere," he said. "There are no plans of this kind."
As Mr. Khodorkovsky has sat in jail awaiting trial on charges of economic crimes, analysts and investors have debated whether his arrest signaled a broad crackdown or even a rollback in the privatization of state property in the 1990's.
Earlier, Mr. Putin downplayed the case as "an isolated criminal matter." On Thursday he said Mr. Khodorkovsky's arrest was the latest of many for economic crimes.
"High-ranking officials in the Interior Ministry were arrested too," he said. "Criminal cases were initiated against the heads of some regions of the Russian Federation. The investigation of a former federal minister has been completed and sent to the courts.
"Our actions are guided by a desire to instill law and order in the country and have everybody abide by the law and fight corruption."
The targets of the campaign are the hustling entrepreneurs who seized much of Russia's natural resources during the last decade, said Michael McFaul, an expert on Russia at Stanford University who is a senior fellow at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.
The men in the Kremlin who are behind the campaign "see themselves as restoring the Russian state after this period," he said on a conference call with worried investors.
Whatever policy issues are involved, Mr. Khodorkovsky has angered the Kremlin with his public activities, financing opposition parties and charitable foundations as well as academic institutions like the Carnegie Endowment.
Mr. Putin addressed that issue too. "They will of course spend millions -- tens and hundreds of millions -- in order to save their billions," he said. "We know how that money has been spent, on what lawyers, what public relations companies and what political figures." He said the government would fight back "tenaciously and toughly, no matter how these people try to defend themselves, by blackmail and other means."
The United States has expressed concern over the actions against Yukos, which precede parliamentary elections to be held on Dec. 7. On Thursday a regional court stripped one of the company's top shareholders, Vasily S. Shakhnovsky, of his parliamentary seat and his immunity from prosecution. He has been charged, like Mr. Khodorkovsky, with tax evasion.
In an odd development, the agriculture ministry of Sakha, a Russian region where Yukos operates, also took a swing, with a report saying cows and rabbits were beingmistreated at farms run by a company subsidiary. Among the rabbits it said, "Couplings take place unsystematically and no zoological-technological monitoring records are kept," according to the report quoted by the Interfax news agency.
Aleksandr Shadrin, the beleaguered Yukos spokesman, seized the light moment.
"The unsystematic coupling of buck rabbits at a farm of a company affiliate is an outrage, indeed," he told Interfax. "Those responsible will definitely be punished."

HEADLINE: BUSH ASKS LANDS IN MIDEAST TO TRY DEMOCRATIC WAYS 

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 

 BODY:
President Bush on Thursday challenged Iran, Syria and two crucial Middle East allies of the United States -- Egypt and Saudi Arabia -- to begin embracing democratic traditions, and to view the fall of Saddam Hussein as "a watershed event in the global democratic revolution." 
 "Sixty years of Western nations excusing and accommodating the lack of freedom in the Middle East did nothing to make us safe," Mr. Bush argued, in a critique that embraced both Democrats and Republicans who preceded him, "because in the long run, stability cannot be purchased at the expense of liberty." 
 The speech, before the National Endowment for Democracy, appeared to be part of an effort by the White House to change American and world perceptions of the Iraq occupation, describing it in far broader strategic terms than the ouster of a dictator.
But it came at a moment when Mr. Bush is struggling to create democratic institutions in Iraq itself, and when the daily casualties among the American and allied soldiers have led many in the region to question whether the United States is capable of transforming the nation it invaded. 
In the speech, the president sought to position the American experiment in remaking Iraq alongside the United States' efforts to spread democracy in Asia and Europe after World War II and to bring about the fall of the Soviet Union. He directly compared what he called his administration's new "forward strategy of freedom in the Middle East" to President Ronald Reagan's 1982 declaration in England that Soviet Communism had failed.
He identified four nations where he said dictatorship was doomed to failure: North Korea, Myanmar -- which he referred to by its former name, Burma -- Cuba and Zimbabwe, declaring that "these regimes cannot hold back freedom forever." He predicted that just as Nelson Mandela emerged from captivity in South Africa to lead his nation, "one day, from prison camps and prison cells and from exile, the leaders of new democracies will arrive" in the four countries.
Mr. Bush had sounded similar themes before, notably in a speech at the American Enterprise Institute a month and a half before he ordered the invasion of Iraq. But until Thursday's speech, he had not identified nations that he thought urgently needed to reform. For thefirst time, he also raised, gingerly, the issue of the absence of liberty in Saudi Arabia, one of America's major oil suppliers and a nation that has long been spared presidential rebuke.
"The Saudi government is taking first steps toward reform," he said, choosing his words carefully about a country that one of his senior aides said recently "is probably the most resistant to change of any nation in the region." He referred to its experiment with local elections, avoided any mention of the struggle within the Saudi royal family over whether and how to surrender some authority, and he offered the most gentle of encouragement.
"By giving the Saudi people a greater role in their own society," Mr. Bush said, "the Saudi government can demonstrate true leadership in the region."
He also pressed Egypt -- which receives upward of $2 billion annually in aid from the United States -- saying it "has shown the way toward peace in the Middle East, and now should show the way toward democracy in the Middle East." But later, his spokesman, Scott McClellan, said the president was not threatening any consequences for his Arab allies if they failed to heed his warning.
The pressure runs the risk of backfiring. In the Arab world, Mr. Bush's remarks about human rights and democracy are often viewed as hypocritical, and Arabs often compare those statements to the treatment of suspected terrorists held by American forces at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, or the president's reluctance to demand that Israel stop constructing its barrier along the West Bank. 
Some Arab intellectuals urging greater civil liberties say Mr. Bush's endorsement undermines them, because it paints them as stooges of the United States. 
But a scattering of experts feel that it is welcome pressure on governments that have been stuck in place for decades, and Tom Malinowski, the Washington advocacy director for Human Rights Watch, praised Mr. Bush for doing something the Clinton administration had been loath to do: identifying Middle East nations that have refused to liberalize. 
"They have ended the Mideast exception to American human rights policy," he said of the Bush administration. "It is welcome moral clarity in the service of a policy that still lacks moral authority."
Not surprisingly, Mr. Bush heaped the most scorn on Iran and Syria, which his administration accuses of seeking to undermine the Iraq occupation. "The regime in Tehran must heed the democratic demands of the Iranian people or lose its last claim to legitimacy," he said. 
He lumped Syria's leaders with Mr. Hussein, saying they had promised a restoration of ancient glories but instead left "a legacy of torture, oppression, misery and ruin."
By the time Mr. Bush spoke, it was already evening in the Middle East, and there were no official reactions from governments. But Imad Fawzi Shueibi, a Syrian political analyst and professor at Damascus University, suggested that Mr. Bush's message would be tainted in the Middle East by the widespread negative perception of the messenger.
"I don't think someone who violates the human rights against people all over the world and especially the Arab world can speak about freedom and democracy," he said. "How can we believe that Mr. George Bush wants us to enter the era of democracy and the era of freedom when he remains biased toward Israel despite its violations of human rights, despite its long occupation of Arab land and its apartheid system toward the Arabs in the occupied territories?" 
Others found plenty to praise. 
"It was exciting," said Omar Baghour, a Saudi economist and columnist at the newspaper Al Madina. 
The United States, he said, "is hated in the Arab and Islamic world because it has always been viewed as supporting repressive regimes." Mr. Bush has now turned, he said, to "a more moderate approach, a more rational approach to democratization in the Arab world rather than the threat of force."
Most notable about Mr. Bush's speech was his tone in discussing Iraq. In February at the American Enterprise Institute, he said with certainty that Mr. Hussein's ouster would make Iraq the democratic kernel at the heart of the Middle East. But on Thursday, he raised the specter of what a nondemocratic Iraq might look like in a post-Hussein era, though he assured listeners that success was inevitable. 
"The failure of Iraqi democracy would embolden terrorists around the world, increase dangers to the American people, and extinguish the hopes of millions in the region," he said. "Iraqi democracy will succeed, and that success will send forth the news, from Damascus to Tehran, that freedom can be the future of every nation."
Mr. Bush did not mention the issue of weapons of mass destruction. The possible threat from such weapons was the administration's chief argument for war against Iraq, but no evidence of them has been found. 
Two hours after the speech, the president gathered leaders of the House and Senate and his security team in the East Room and signed the legislation that provides $87 billion for military action and reconstruction in Iraq and Afghanistan. Flanked by Secretary of State Colin L. Powell and Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld, he called the money "the greatest commitment of its kind since the Marshall Plan."

HEADLINE: Brazil Eases Its Dependence on I.M.F. 

BYLINE:  By TONY SMITH

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Nov. 6 

 BODY:
Confident it has stabilized Brazil's economy, the country's left-leaning government said this week that its 12-month extension of a standby agreement with the International Monetary Fund signals an end to years of dependence on I.M.F. bailouts.
 Confounding market fears of just a year ago that he would lead Brazil into a free-spending dash for growth, President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva and his pragmatic economic team have succeeded in reining in inflation and public spending. Though Brazil has increased exports to earn much-needed hard currency to plug holes in the current account, the government still faces the daunting task of getting the economy growing again without upsetting the country's delicately balanced accounts. 
 Outlining the agreement Wednesday to extend Brazil's current $30 billion standby agreement that runs out next month, Antonio Palocci, the finance minister, said the government would draw on the new $14 billion I.M.F. package, which includes $6 billion of fresh cash and eases debt repayments terms over the next four years, only if absolutely necessary. 
"It's a sort of insurance policy against the ever present risk of external shocks and unforeseen difficulties," Mr. Palocci said. "We believe we should, after a long period, propose an end to this series of deals with the fund."
Anne Krueger, the I.M.F.'s first deputy managing director, said she would support the proposal before the I.M.F.'s board.
Brazil has been relying on I.M.F. aid since a currency crisis in 1998. The country has proved unable to wean itself off support as it experienced stop-start growth and a series of international financial crises that shook confidence in emerging markets.
But Mr. Palocci insisted there were now "real and effective" signs that the next economic recovery would be on the back of sustainable growth.
Whether such optimism is justified or not, the markets hailed the I.M.F. extension as a signal that Brazil would not stray from the path of fiscal and monetary orthodoxy. Fitch Ratings on Thursday upgraded Brazil's sovereign debt from B to B+.
"The I.M.F. agreement was just one factor in the upgrade," said Roger Scher, managing director and head of Latin American sovereign debt at Fitch in New York.
"Generally, there is a feeling the Lula government has been very successful in macroeconomic policy," he said. "Basically, they have made few mistakes and surpassed everybody's expectations."
But the success has not been without pain. The economy, anemic since 1998, is expected to grow just 1.1 percent this year. Spiraling inflation forced Mr. da Silva to increase interest rates to 26 percent early this year, decimating business and consumer confidence. Industrial output has slumped; the jobless rate has soared to 13 percent nationwide and is over 20 percent in Sao Paulo, the country's economic heart.
In recent months, however, the threat from inflation has waned and interest rates are ticking down. With a weak currency and feeble domestic demand, exports are booming. The trade surplus is expected to top $23 billion this year, leaving Brazil's current account in the black for the first time since 1993. 
In contrast to 12 months ago, when Mr. da Silva's leftist past and pugnacious election campaign sent markets into a panic, investors are returning to Brazil with enthusiasm. Sao Paulo's stock index, the Bovespa, is up 59 percent this year and the benchmark C bond is trading at more than 90 percent of its face value, after being below 50 percent last fall.
"This time last year, we were one step away from the abyss, now it seems we've taken quite a few steps back," said Rodrigo Azevedo, chief economist at Credit Suisse First Boston-Garantia in Sao Paulo. "So I think this is a good agreement. It creates a framework for better perspectives next year and, I hope, beyond."
Like Mr. Azevedo, many economists say the Lula administration must now get down to tackling potentially unpopular changes to make the economy more flexible and attractive to foreign investment.
Two crucial moves -- realigning Brazil's bankrupt social security network and its byzantine tax system -- have already cleared the principle hurdles in Congress, but smaller, yet important, measures await action. 
A bankruptcy law that would make it easier for banks to seize collateral to recoup the value of bad loans would ultimately allow banks to lower interest rates and should stimulate the economy. Liberalizing labor laws to make it easier to hire and fire workers is also seen as important, though that is bound to meet resistance from many members of Mr. da Silva's Workers' Party.
Another problem with a return to growth is that a revival of domestic demand will make a dent in the trade surplus.
Mr. Azevedo expects this year's projected $23 billion trade surplus to shrink to $16 billion next year if the economy recovers, turning this year's projected $2.6 billion current account surplus into a $6.4 billion deficit in 2004.
One answer to that would be to push the currency, the real, down against the dollar. As Brazil has stabilized, the real has gradually recovered, and is now trading below 2.9 to the dollar. Exporters say the currency must stay above 3 to the dollar to keep Brazilian goods competitive on world markets.
"Growth is the question," Mr. Scher said. "G.D.P. growth and export growth -- that's the onlyway Brazil can pay off its domestic and foreign debt."
If Brazil cannot guarantee growth, Mr. Palocci might be thwarted in his hopes of never knocking at the I.M.F.'s door again, Mr. Scher said.
"Brazil's balance of payments still remains quite vulnerable to external shocks," he said.

HEADLINE: Greenspan Hints at End To Low Rates 

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, offered a first hint on Thursday that the era of rock-bottom interest rates may be slowly drawing to a close.
 Acknowledging for the first time that the economy has grown at a blistering pace in recent months, Mr. Greenspan gave an optimistic assessment of the prospects for strong growth and a gradual reduction in unemployment. 
 The Fed chairman also departed slightly from the central bank's recent open-ended commitment to retain a policy of cheap money "for a considerable period." 
In a speech delivered to the Securities Industry Association, Mr. Greenspan said that the Fed was still more worried that inflation would be too low rather than too high and that the Fed could afford to be patient before changing monetary policy.
But he also cautioned that "no central bank can ever afford to be less than vigilant about the prospects for inflation."
The comments left little doubt that Mr. Greenspan wants to keep interest rates low for at least the next several months. But they also offered a guarded hint that the Fed's open-ended commitment to easy money may be waning.
"They know they have an exit problem," said William Dudley, chief United States economist at Goldman Sachs. "I think they want the exit to be gradual and smooth rather than abrupt and scary."
On a separate front, Mr. Greenspan bluntly criticized both President Bush and Congress for not reducing a federal budget deficit that could exceed $500 billion next year.
"Recent budget deliberations have not been encouraging," he said, pleading for a return to Congressional rules that make it much harder to cut taxes or raise spending without finding new sources of revenue.
"The current debate appears to be about how much to cut taxes or how much to increase spending," he continued. "No significant constituency seems to support taking the actions that will be necessary to move toward, and one hopes achieve, budget balance."
Mr. Greenspan's remarks were his first since the Fed decided on Oct. 28 to keep the federal funds rate for overnight loans between banks at 1 percent, the lowest level in 45 years. They were also his first comments since the government reported last Thursday that the economy surged at an annual rate of 7.2 percent in the third quarter, the fastest pace in nearly two decades.
The combination of rapid growth and exceptionally easy money has increased expectations among investors that the Fed will tighten the reins some time next year to keep the economy from overheating.
Before Mr. Greenspan delivered his remarks, the government released two reports that showed signs of an economy gaining strength.
The Labor Department reported that the number of new claims for unemployment benefits dropped to 348,000 last week, the lowest level since 2001.
Though weekly claims for unemployment tend to be volatile, the drop in claims was bigger than expected. Many economists believe that a level below 400,000 indicates that the job market is strengthening. 
On Friday, the Labor Department will release unemployment data for October. Most analysts estimate that the jobless rate remained about 6.1 percent last month but that the economy added 60,000 jobs.
The government also reported on Thursday that the nation's productivity -- the amount of goods and services produced per worker -- soared at annual rate of 8.1 percent in the third quarter of this year.
Productivity gains have been a two-edged sword for Mr. Greenspan and other top officials, just as they have been for President Bush. On the one hand, higher productivity makes it possible for companies to increase production and increase their profits without hiring additional people.
But productivity growth has been so fast this year that job creation has been stagnant and joblessness has remained stubbornly high. Fed officials remain worried that a weak job market and heightened job insecurities among workers could short-circuit the economic recovery. 
In his speech, Mr. Greenspan noted that per-hour output in the nonfarm business sector had climbed at an annual rate of 5 percent for the last two years. In the second and third quarters of 2003, he said , per-hour output climbed at a rate of 7.5 percent.
"If businesses are to spend and hire more vigorously, they will need to be convinced that economic growth can be sustained beyond the short run," Mr. Greenspan said. "One prominent concern is that, if the labor market remains weak, household confidence will suffer."
But in a nod to the mounting evidence of rapid economic growth, Mr. Greenspan said "the odds increasingly favor a revival in job creation."
Minutes from the September meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, which sets monetary policy, show that some Fed officials were already trying to rein in the open-ended commitment to keep interest rates low "for a considerable period."
According to the minutes, which were released last week, "the members generally agreed that the committee should not commit itself to a particular policy stance over some pre-established, extended time frame." But committee officials agreed to leave their language unchanged, citing the "unusual configuration" of economic conditions. 
In a speech on Thursday, a Fed governor, Ben S. Bernanke, contended that the Fed still had room to keep interest rates low, in part because rapid productivity growth has reduced the risk of inflation.
"Inflation appears subdued and likely to remain so," Mr. Bernanke said in Pittsburgh.

HEADLINE: Going Alone, Britain Lifts Its Key Rate To 3.75% 

BYLINE:  By ALAN COWELL

DATELINE: LONDON, Nov. 6 

 BODY:
Breaking ranks with other leading central banks, the Bank of England raised its benchmark interest rate by one quarter of a percentage point Thursday, bucking a global three-year trend toward lower borrowing costs.
 The bank's decision to lift its base rate to 3.75 percent, from 3.5 percent, was announced shortly before the European Central Bank in Frankfurt left rates in the 12-nation euro zone unchanged, underscoring the substantial distinctions between the more sluggish Continental economy and its faster-growing but more volatile British counterpart. 
 The decision by the European bank was the first under its new president, Jean-Claude Trichet of France, who succeeded Wim Duisenberg of the Netherlands on Saturday. Economists and investors had expected the British increase and the euro zone decision to keep interest rates at 2 percent. 
It seemed unlikely, though, that the British move presaged any imminent increase in global interest rates. "I wouldn't imagine many other major central banks following suit in the near term," Mike Taylor, senior European economist at Merrill Lynch in London, said. That view was reflected in remarks from central bankers.
In Frankfurt, Mr. Trichet said at a news conference, "We are pursuing a strategy of a stable euro, a strong euro and a euro which inspires confidence." In the United States, where the benchmark rate is 1 percent, the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, said Thursday that American monetary policy makers could afford to be "patient."
The United States and Continental Europe have pushed interest rates to their lowest levels since World War II in their quest for growth to create jobs -- a less pressing issue in Britain, where several years of growth fed by consumer spending have kept the unemployment lines at their shortest in memory.
Using measures defined by the International Labor Organization, Britain's unemployment is 5 percent, the lowest in decades, while the jobless figure for the United States is 6.1 percent by the same standard. Euro zone unemployment is the highest of the three at 8.8 percent, and the region's growth this year is forecast to be about 0.4 percent compared with an expected 2.5 percent in Britain.
Mr. Trichet said he expected a European recovery to gather steam in 2004. "We see additional signs of recovery in the euro area," he said, adding that "the medium-term outlook for price stability remains favorable."
The biggest distinction between the British and Continental European economies, however, lies in Britain's overriding dependence on consumer spending, which, coupled with a still-buoyant housing market, has left economists concerned about runaway inflation as boom gives way to bust.
Mortgage lending in September reached a monthly high, for instance, while mortgage lenders this week estimated annual average house price increases at 16 percent -- down from last year's highs of 25 percent but still much higher than the Bank of England's economists say is sustainable.
"The Bank of England has finally run out of patience with British consumers," said Graeme Leach, chief economist at the Institute of Directors, a business group. "Having waited patiently for British households to bring their borrowing under control, it has finally decided to intervene."
The Bank of England's Monetary Policy Committee said Thursday: "Neither household spending nor the housing market have slowed by as much as the committee expected. Underlying inflationary pressures are therefore likely to build gradually as demand strengthens and sterling's depreciation earlier this year feeds through."
In the euro zone, by contrast, Europe's inflation rate of 2.1 percent in October did not change from September or August, which surprised some analysts who had expected inflation to decline because of the Continent's sluggish growth.
"We anticipate some further stickiness of inflation rates in the shorter term, while the medium-term outlook for price stability remains favorable." Mr. Trichet said.
The Bank of England's mandate is to keep inflation at 2.5 percent, but it walks a delicate line among competing pressures.
Britain's manufacturers, for instance, had just begun to sense a revival when the prospect of a return to costlier borrowing emerged Thursday. Economists and traders are forecasting that Thursday's rate increase will be followed by more in early 2004, a possibility that manufacturers find worrisome.
"Despite more encouraging world growth, we should be clear that the economic recovery is still at an early and extremely fragile stage," said Digby Jones, director general of the Confederation of British Industry. "It would be misguided to opt for overly aggressive monetary tightening before that recovery has really taken hold."
Some economists worry that higher interest rates could begin to erode confidence by slowing consumer spending far more than the Bank of England intends. Hilary Cook, an economist at Barclays Stockbrokers, said the increase Thursday "will make consumers think more about the debt levels they have been accumulating."
Others, however, argue that even with further moderate increases next year, consumers are not likely to feel too much pain. "It would take rates of 4.5 percent or more before you start seeing a significant squeeze on the British consumer," Mr. Taylor at Merrill Lynch said.
Even with the increase Thursday, British rates are still lower than they were at the beginning of this year. But the increase was the first since February 2000, when the Bank of England raised its benchmark rate a quarter of a point to 6 percent. 
Since then it has been steadily cutting rates to keep the economy away from the slowdown that has afflicted much of Continental Europe. British rates hit their lowest in 48 years, at 3.5 percent, with the last reduction, in July. The increase Thursday was "just taking back the precautionary rate cut in July," Mr. Taylor said.

SUBJECT: CENTRAL BANKS (94%); ECONOMIC NEWS (90%); INTEREST RATES (90%); EURO (90%); MONETARY UNIONS (90%); TRENDS (90%); BANKING & FINANCE (90%); EURO ZONE (90%); MORTGAGE BANKING & FINANCE (89%); INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC ORGANIZATIONS (89%); ECONOMIC POLICY (78%); REAL ESTATE (78%); HOUSING MARKET (78%); MORTGAGE BANKING (78%); MONETARY POLICY (78%); PRICE INCREASES (78%); UNEMPLOYMENT RATES (78%); EUROPEAN UNION INSTITUTIONS (76%); PUBLIC POLICY (76%); EMPLOYMENT GROWTH (75%); PRESS CONFERENCES (71%); US FEDERAL GOVERNMENT (70%); HOME PRICES (69%); LABOR DEPARTMENTS (63%); JOB CREATION (63%); MORTGAGE LOANS (60%); WORLD WAR II (50%) Terms not available from NYTimes.

HEADLINE: Bertelsmann and Sony to Join Music Units 

BYLINE:  By MARK LANDLER

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Nov. 6 

 BODY:
Bertelsmann and Sony have agreed to combine their music divisions, becoming the latest partners in an industry roundelay that reflects the turbulent economics of recorded music.
 The nonbinding letter of intent signed by Bertelsmann, the German media conglomerate, and Sony of Japan envisions a 50-50 venture to be called Sony BMG. It would create a stronger rival to the industry's leader, the Universal Music Group of Vivendi Universal, with 25.2 percent of the global market and stars ranging from Britney Spears to the cellist Yo-Yo Ma. 
 The combination has echoes of a proposed joint venture of BMG, Bertelsmann's music division, and Time Warner's music division, which foundered two months ago when Time Warner decided to enter into talks with EMI. EMI is close to lining up financing for a cash-and-share bid of up to $1.7 billion for Warner Music, according to people involved in the proposal. 
The prospect of a competing merger may have prodded Sony and Bertelsmann to move quickly, according to industry executives. In an announcement vague on details, one point was explicit: the deal hinges on approval from antitrust regulators in the United States and Europe.
Many industry executives doubt the regulators would bless back-to-back mergers, which would shrink the number of major recording companies to three. By announcing their deal first, Bertelsmann and Sony could increase their chances of approval -- or even scare off Time Warner and EMI.
"It's not a disadvantage to be first," said Rolf Schmidt-Holtz, the chief executive of BMG, who would be chairman of the board of the new company. "In the end, the regulatory bodies will decide."
The European Commission has taken a hard line on music industry mergers, quashing two in the last three years. Given that record, a person close to the commission said that filing first was an advantage.
Sony and Bertelsmann also plan to keep their music publishing units out of the joint venture, removing an element that provoked regulators in Brussels in judging previous mergers.
Fusing two troubled music giants will not solve their problems with piracy and the peer-to-peer sharing of files, which have devastated the industry in the last few years. But it would enable Sony and Bertelsmann to cut costs by combining sales and marketing offices in dozens of countries. 
"We live in fragile and, for the record industry, very difficult times," said Andrew Lack, chairman of Sony Music Entertainment. "A partnership like this allows us to manage our way through the difficulties." Mr. Lack, a former television executive who has cut a wide swath as a music mogul, would be chief executive of Sony BMG.
Sony and Bertelsmann could still face internal obstacles. While they have agreed to value each other's assets equally -- a hurdle that tripped up Bertelsmann and Time Warner -- they have not yet performed due diligence on each other's accounts. In the music business, with its often-murky contracts for artists and star executives, that could be fraught with danger.
"It is mostly accounting issues, to my way of thinking," Mr. Lack said. "We may be a touch naive, but I don't think we are."
Mr. Lack said he and Mr. Schmidt-Holtz hammered out the deal over five weeks, using relatively few lawyers and investment bankers. While Sony's chairman, Nobuyuki Idei, and Bertelsmann's chairman, Gunter Thielen, were kept informed, they did not take part in the negotiations.
The speed of this deal surprised some people in the industry, who have become used to protracted negotiations that often end in failure. But analysts said the combination had an underlying logic.
"They have to consolidate because they can't afford the overhead," said Porter Bibb, managing partner of Mediatech Capital Partners, a media investment firm. "When you have the specter of vastly reduced profits, there isn't enough room for five or six major companies."
Both companies have felt growing pressure to stem the bleeding from their music operations. BMG reported an operating loss of $126 million in the first half, nearly triple its loss in the period last year. Sony Music had an operating profit of $2 million in the second quarter that ended in September, but sales slumped 8.9 percent, to $1.1 billion, from 2002.
Sony, which has also suffered from a slowdown in its consumer electronics business, announced last week a radical plan to lay off 20,000 workers and cut $3 billion in annual operating costs by 2006.
Bertelsmann, under Mr. Thielen, has concentrated on whittling down its debt and scaling back its ambitious forays into electronic distribution. A no-nonsense executive who rose through the bookbinding business, Mr. Thielen has said previously that he has few misgivings about placing Bertelsmann's music operations in a venture with a chief executive from another company.
Mr. Lack, a former president of NBC News and NBC, was brought into Sony Music in January by his former colleague, Sir Howard Stringer, the chairman of Sony's American operations, to shake up a culture that had been dominated by old-line music executives. Perks and lavish contracts abounded. Mr. Lack laid off more than 1,000 people and recast Sony's corporate culture to focus on digital distribution of music.
Mr. Schmidt-Holtz, a onetime television journalist and executive, said his shared background with Mr. Lack might have helped smooth negotiations. It also helped that neither man has a music pedigree, according to people at the companies, since that has been a hurdle in other negotiations.
Even now, as Time Warner and EMI negotiate to meld their operations, industry executives question whether Roger Ames, the chairman of the Warner Music Group, could co-exist with Alain Levy, the chairman of EMI Music, who was Mr. Ames's former boss at Polygram Records.
Mr. Ames, industry executives said, was pushing for a joint venture with BMG that would have him become chief executive and Mr. Schmidt-Holtz the chairman. In those talks, the stumbling block was not the relationship between the two men, but a distrust of Bertelsmann on the part of Time Warner's chief executive, Richard D. Parsons, after a publishing deal soured.
For Time Warner, the Sony-Bertelsmann announcement changes its calculus, but not necessarily in predictable ways. It could accelerate its negotiations with EMI in the hopes of presenting a deal to regulators at the same time that Sony and Bertelsmann make their pitch. Or it could drop EMI and take up a buyout bid made by a group of investors, including Edgar Bronfman Jr. and Haim Saban, a billionaire media investor.
Such a strategy would make sense if it appeared that regulators would not tolerate a music industry with only three major players. Selling Warner Music to Mr. Bronfman's group would not reduce the number of companies.
For EMI, the latest news is just one more twist in its perennial quest to find a partner. EMI, based in London, agreed to be bought by Time Warner in 2000, only to learn after announcing the deal that Time Warner had negotiated a $165 billion merger with America Online.
Regulators, who worried that the AOL-Time Warner combination would give the company undue control over content and distribution, agreed to approve it only if Time Warner abandoned its purchase of EMI. A subsequent merger of EMI and BMG was also snuffed out by regulators.
Shares of EMI fell 1.7 percent on Thursday, to 177 pence ($2.95). In New York, shares of Time Warner rose 25 cents, to $15.75, while American depository receipts of Sony fell 2.3 percent, or 85 cents, to $35.92. The New York Post and The Los Angeles Times reported on Thursday that a deal between Sony and Bertelsmann was imminent.
Mr. Schmidt-Holtz said the competitive landscape in recorded music had changed so drastically in the last two years because of piracy and file sharing that he believed that regulators would view this merger as much less of a threat. That view is shared by many outside analysts.
Indeed, Mr. Bibb, the media banker, said, "If the regulators take a step back, they would conclude there is no threat of monopoly, because essentially, these companies are in disarray, with no sound business model going forward."

Pentagon Approves Pact On Planes for Refueling
The Pentagon approved a compromise plan that paves the way for the Air Force to acquire 100 Boeing 767's for use as aerial refueling tankers, ending a controversy over a program that became a test case for the Pentagon's ability to lease major military equipment.
 The Pentagon will lease 20 Boeing 767's and buy 80 more in a deal that has cut billions of dollars from earlier estimates. Page C4. 

O'Donnell Tells Her Side in Court
Rosie O'Donnell took the stand in her trial against her publishing partner, Gruner & Jahr, in the legal battle over who bears responsibility for the demise of Rosie, the magazine. They had tried to transform the women's magazine McCall's into a publication based on Ms. O'Donnell's public persona. But it imploded in the fall of 2002 over a fight for custody of the magazine and its staff. C3.

Calpers Objects to Big Board Plan
California Public Employees Retirement System, or Calpers, urged federal regulators to reject the two-board structure for the New York Stock Exchange proposed by its interim chairman, John Reed, saying the main board would not be independent enough and would not be representative of investors' interests. C5.

College to Pay for Music Online
Pennsylvania State University agreed to cover the cost of providing its students with a legal method to download music from a catalog of half a million songs, departing sharply from previous efforts to curtail music swapping on college campuses. A1.

Drug Importer Shut Down
A federal judge granted the government's request to close Rx Depot and Rx of Canada, which help customers buy cheaper prescription drugs from Canada. C4.

Hollywood Lawyers Questioned
Several Hollywood lawyers have been questioned by the Federal Bureau of Investigation in connection with a grand jury inquiry into alleged illegal wiretapping by the celebrity private investigator Anthony Pellicano, according to two people involved. C4.

Retail Sales Rose in October
Retail sales at stores open at least a year rose 2.4 percent in October, according to the Goldman, Sachs retail index. Sales at Wal-Mart increased 4.5 percent, as shoppers curtailed spending after they spent tax-credit checks mailed in July and August. Many retailers have trimmed their inventories so that fall merchandise could be sold in time to open shelf space for the holiday season. C5.

Trying to Fill Jordan's Nikes
LeBron James, a basketball player for the Cleveland Cavaliers, is being paid as much as $100 million by Nike to wear and endorse the Air Zoom Generation sneakers until he is 25. The sneakers will go on sale Dec. 20. D1.

American Airlines is watching competitors start low-cost carriers and might eventually decide to start one of its own. C4.

National Public Radio has received a bequest worth at least $200 million from the widow of the founder of the McDonald's restaurant chain, Joan B. Kroc. E3.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times; 
Final Round for an Everlast Plant

BYLINE:  By DAVE ANDERSON

 BODY:
FROM the outside, it's a gloomy gray building in a gloomy gray industrial section of the Bronx, not far from the Triborough Bridge, about as far away as you can get from the casino glitz of a big fight these days. But inside, the Everlast plant is where most of the boxing gloves in a big fight have been made for decades -- Muhammad Ali's gloves, Joe Frazier's gloves, George Foreman's gloves, Larry Holmes's gloves, Mike Tyson's gloves, Lennox Lewis's gloves.
 "When my corner wanted me to jab," Holmes has said, "they would yell, 'Everlast.' " 
 But this Everlast plant is in its last days. Sometime next month, all of Everlast Worldwide's gloves, punching bags, headgear, boxing shoes, trunks and robes will be produced at its Moberly, Mo., plant, nearly a century after its original factory opened on the Lower East Side in 1910, long after Jack Dempsey and Benny Leonard popularized Everlast gloves in the years after World War I. 
"We're saddened we have to close the Bronx plant; nearly 100 workers will be out of a job," George Horowitz, Everlast's principal owner, was saying in the company's Midtown office, which will remain its corporate headquarters. "But our lease there is over, our union contract is over, our landlord wants to more than double the rent."
And New York will be losing another page of its boxing history. Once upon a time there were enough neighborhood fight clubs in the city to provide boxing six nights a week; there were big fights almost every Friday night at Madison Square Garden; there were occasional outdoor title fights at Yankee Stadium and at the Polo Grounds.
But now there are no regular fight clubs here, the Vitaly Klitschko-Kirk Johnson heavyweight bout on Dec. 6 will be the first boxing show at the Garden's main arena in more than two years, promoters never consider putting on outdoor title fights, and Everlast gloves will no longer be shipped from a Bronx plant, according to Horowitz, to about 80 percent of the professional boxers in some 80 countries.
"Ali had hands that hurt," Horowitz said. "He needed extra padding in his training gloves to protect his hands."
For decades, a pro boxer's gloves were stuffed with horsehair, but Everlast now uses foam rubber.
"In the Thrilla in Manila," Horowitz said, "it was so hot in that indoor arena the horsehair in Ali's and Frazier's gloves broke down. By the late rounds, the gloves were just pieces of leather flopping around. It was almost like fighting with bare knuckles. Foam rubber doesn't break down."
Ali wore large-size gloves, but Lewis, the reigning World Boxing Council heavyweight champion, who is taller and heavier than Ali, needs extra-large gloves. Lewis also wears the biggest boxing shoe, a 16 triple E."
At its peak, the Bronx plant's daily production included 50 pairs of pro gloves, 50 headguards, at least 400 speed bags and at least 700 heavy bags. In the countdown to closing, the output is less, but the workers, many of whom are Bronx residents who have been employed there for years, remain proud of what they do.
"I make all the gloves for Ali," Gloria Kitchens said Tuesday. "When he and others were fighting, I would see them on TV and say, 'Ooh, that's my gloves.' "
Kitchens is from Nicaragua, and when Ricardo Mayorga, the welterweight champion from Nicaragua, stopped by the plant not long ago, he asked Kitchens to bless his gloves. When the plant had an anniversary party last year, Frazier attended.
"He told me, 'Congratulations,' " Kitchens said. " 'You made my gloves for me. You're special.' "
But in another month, after 32 years in the Everlast plant, Kitchens will be unemployed.
"I've been happy here," she said. "Now I don't know what I'll do. This is all I've done."
Guido Parales, from Ecuador, has been stuffing gloves for 29 years on a metal device that appears to have been shaped specifically for the job who knows how long ago. "When I started, the stuffer was here," said Parales, 59, who will be looking for work elsewhere. "The day Ali came, he hugged me and told me that he appreciated the quality."
One of the last shipments of equipment from the Bronx plant will be addressed to Tyson.
"Mike just called," said Adam Geisler, the Everlast marketing director. "He ordered 10-ounce XL gloves, 22-ounce training gloves, three pairs of shoes, headgear and a 250-pound big bag. Mike has often told us that his original trainer, Cus D'Amato, loved Everlast so he'll always love Everlast. He wanted it all shipped to him in Hawaii because he said he's going into training there soon."
That's news. Could he be training for a fight yet to be announced? Maybe with Roy Jones Jr.?
But no matter where Tyson or any other boxer trains, in a few weeks the Everlast equipment will be shipped to them from Missouri, not the Bronx.

The plant will close soon. (Photographs by Ozier Muhammad/The New York Times)
